XML.Hansard-Body: The Legislative Assembly met at 9.30 am.
Mr Speaker (Hon. John Mickel, Logan) read prayers and took the chair.
For the sitting week, Mr Speaker acknowledged the traditional owners of the land upon which this parliament is assembled and the custodians of the sacred lands of our state.

Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, at the commencement of proceedings today I wish to acknowledge and highlight the plight of the people of Pakistan given the devastating floods that have ravaged the region. Pakistan of course is a member of the Commonwealth of Nations and, along with Queensland, is a member of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. I have sent a message of concern and condolence to a member of the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Provincial Assembly who is known to me. More than a month has passed since the rains commenced and the situation since then has only magnified and deteriorated. I urge honourable members to consider supporting the flood relief appeal effort through making a donation if they have not had the opportunity to do so already. The floods are one of the worst natural disasters on record. Suffering is immense. The number for the UNICEF Pakistan Flood Emergency Appeal is 1300884233. There are many other aid agencies involved in the flood crisis, and I commend all of those to honourable members.

XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.34 am): It is with great sorrow that I again rise in this House to pay tribute to three fine Australian soldiers from the Brisbane based 6th Battalion at Enoggera who have tragically lost their lives while serving in Afghanistan. The thoughts of all Queenslanders and all members of this House are with the families, friends and colleagues of these brave young diggers who died fighting for peace in the war on terror. On Friday, 20 August Private Tomas Dale and Private Grant Kirby were killed and two other Australian soldiers were wounded during an operation in the Baluchi Valley. Sadly, just four days later as the Royal Australian Army members in Tarin Kot were farewelling Private Kirby and Private Dale, their colleague Lance Corporal Jared MacKinney was killed in action whilst on patrol.

Private Kirby was born in Nambour in 1975 and is the father of two young daughters. His family are extremely proud of him, as are all Australians. Private Dale was born in the United Kingdom in 1989 and immigrated to Australia with his family in 2003. He lived in Adelaide before joining the Australian Defence Force in 2007. This was Private Dale’s first operational deployment with the Australian defence service and he leaves behind his loving parents, David and Karen, and two brothers. Lance Corporal MacKinney was a loving husband to his wife, Beckie, who we all know is expecting their second child in the coming weeks. He was a devoted father to his daughter Annabell. The deaths of these three soldiers is a tragic reminder of the dangerous and courageous work that our Defence Force members undertake in the service of their country and ourselves as citizens every day.

Today I wanted to acknowledge the friends and members of the Brisbane based 6th Battalion. These people have been selling wristbands in memory of their fallen colleagues. Thousands of bands have already been sold and around $15,000 has been raised. In acknowledgement of this worthy cause, our government is donating $15,000 in matching funds to their effort, and we are working with the organisers to ensure that the next round of the bands can be made available to electorate offices to distribute to the public.

I think we would all agree that it will mean a lot to those who have lost a loved one and a lot to those who have a loved one still serving to see this show of care and support across the broader community. I will advise electorate officers when the wristbands are available. All money raised from this effort will go towards supporting the families, the wives, the daughters and the sons of those 6RAR soldiers who have been killed or wounded in Afghanistan, including Privates Kirby and Dale and Lance Corporal Jared MacKinney. On behalf of the House, I extend our deepest sympathy to the family, to the friends and to the colleagues of these three fine young soldiers and I again pay tribute to our troops, who continue to carry on with the job at hand with absolute professionalism, true Aussie grit and determination that continues to inspire us all.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.38 am): Mr Speaker, I join with you in commenting on the terrible disaster that is afflicting the Commonwealth nation of Pakistan. The images that we have seen emerge from flood-ravaged Pakistan have been nothing short of horrific. This is a crisis of unimaginable proportions impacting on the lives of millions of people. Latest estimates are that more than 17 million have been affected, more than six million dependent on emergency food supplies and more than four million homeless. Reports this week said that one-fifth of the country had been engulfed and a million people have been displaced over the past few days alone as the flooding shifts south. Like other natural disasters of great magnitude, the floods have been deadly and indiscriminate. Young and old alike have been cut off and isolated without the basics of food, water and shelter. The threat of deadly disease hangs in the air, and right now just surviving is the biggest challenge. Thousands of children have become orphans.

Queenslanders have always dug deep and they have been incredibly supportive and compassionate when others are in need. Of course, many Queenslanders also understand the awesome power of rivers in flood and how they can destroy lives. Last week, as part of the international aid response, the Queensland government, on behalf of all Queenslanders, pledged $500,000 to the Australian Red Cross. The Australian Red Cross will use these funds to provide medical treatment, shelter, food and clean water to flood victims. I can also inform the House today that a senior medical officer from Cairns Base Hospital, Dr Mark Little, is also ready to be deployed as part of the relief effort. Dr Little will be part of the Australian aid effort coordinated by the federal government to provide much needed medical care to flood victims.

These are the worst floods to hit Pakistan in four decades. There is a very long road to recovery ahead and the immediate challenges, such as overcoming disease outbreaks and providing basics such as clean food and water, are immense. Our hearts go out to the people of Pakistan at this terrible time and we stand ready to offer further additional assistance as part of the Australian relief effort in Pakistan.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.40 am): Today, I am very pleased to join with the Minister for Transport in setting out plans for a rail revolution in South-East Queensland, with the Cross River Rail project as the linchpin of a world-class rail network. South-East Queensland’s passenger rail capacity under the plan will nearly triple by 2031 under our $123 billion transport blueprint. Connecting SEQ 2031: An integrated regional transport plan for South East Queensland maps a clear way forward for transport in our region. This plan is a clear statement of intent by a government with a clear vision for the future. The next 20 years will see a concentration on new railways and new services to manage growth in South-East Queensland. This rail revolution is the next stage of our journey towards a world-class public transport system.

It was in 1997 when a slightly more youthful member for Gregory, as the then minister for transport, laid out a vision under the previous integrated regional transport plan and that vision included the building of a dedicated busway system in South-East Queensland. At that time there was not a single kilometre of dedicated busway. Today, as a result of that plan, we have 24 kilometres of busways in Brisbane--more than any other city in Australia and more under construction right now. Like its predecessor, this new plan is visionary, but the experience of our first integrated regional transport plan shows that, when you have a clear plan for the future, you can make it happen.

This government has a strong record when it comes to delivering infrastructure and Queenslanders can see the evidence with their own eyes. They can look and see the South East Busway, they can catch a bus on the Northern Busway and they can walk or cycle over one of our pedestrian bridges. Queenslanders can see the Helensvale to Robina rail duplication, they can travel on the new rail line to our airports and they know all about the extension of the Gold Coast rail line to Varsity Lakes. They also can see the new Sir Leo Hielscher Bridges making a huge difference to the road network. They know about the Ted Smout Memorial Bridge and they have driven on the Tugun bypass and they have cycled the bikeways of South-East Queensland. They can undertake all of this travel with their go card, which has been recognised as the best integrated ticketing system in Australia and one of the best in the world.

In the face of doubt and cynicism, we set about delivering the plan that was outlined in 1997 and we will be just as focused on delivering the plan that we have outlined today. The 20-year blueprint maps out 207 kilometres of new railway lines, stretching our network to new suburbs and towns. It means that we will build a 15-kilometre rail line from Alderley to Strathpine, using the predominantly government owned north-west transport corridor. It means we will take rail further than ever before, with line extensions to Maroochydore, Coolangatta, Moreton Bay, Springfield, Ripley and Flagstone.

The Gold Coast Rapid Transit project on the Gold Coast will be extended 40 kilometres from Helensvale to Coolangatta and there will be an eight-kilometre Brisbane subway from Toowong to West End, to Newstead and to Bowen Hills with extensions to Hamilton Northshore, the airport village and Bulimba all possible in the longer term. Our plan also outlines revolutionary new services, including a new service to be known as UrbanLink, which will have more frequent services and higher capacity trains operating inbound of Darra, Strathpine, Loganlea, Ferny Grove, Manly, Springfield, Shorncliffe and the airport. A further service, ExpressLink, will have high-speed express services from Ipswich, Cleveland, Ormeau and Caboolture and CoastLink will link the capital city here with the Gold Coast and the Sunshine Coast, with high-speed European-style trains set to cut travel time by up to 30 minutes.

The Cross River Rail project, now the subject of a $25 million feasibility study, is a vital linchpin for the future of rail travel here. The Cross River Rail will transform South-East Queensland’s rail network by providing essential capacity at the core of the network that could double the number of train services from the suburbs to the city. It will allow us to provide higher frequency and improved reliability on all lines, making it possible for the rail network to move up to 240,000 people into and across the city during the two-hour morning peak, compared to the current 54,000. That is almost five times the current capacity. That is what is necessary if we are to achieve our vision of a world-class public transport system. The subway system that we flagged in November last year will support the overall rail revolution, helping to move commuters and enabling the city centre to be a place for people.

A fully loaded suburban train carries more than 700 people, taking about 600 cars off the road. That is equal to a line of cars stretching more than four kilometres. With a rail revolution, we can increase that capacity by deploying new trains that can carry more than 1,000 people each. Under this plan, our numbers of three-car trains would increase from 200 now up to 400 by 2031.

Our 20-year transport plan also includes ambitious targets for cycling in South-East Queensland, which includes a 3,000 kilometre network of cycleway by 2031, including new bikeways and walkways within a five-kilometre radius of major urban centres. There are plans to remove heavy vehicles from suburban roads and to provide a better system around Brisbane to navigate, including the new north-south tunnel connection between Toowong and Everton Park.

We will, of course, continue to build our successful busway network, with the construction of the Northern and Eastern busways to Bracken Ridge and Capalaba. There will be major freight investment to support the economy, including the full development of the Acacia Ridge freight terminal and a dedicated dual-gauge freight line from Acacia Ridge to the Port of Brisbane in the existing rail corridor. We will also introduce new technology to better manage road and public transport movements, such as information on travel options, real-time management of motorway flows and improved railway signalling.

This plan is a bold and visionary blueprint. It lays out a vision for better connected communities across South-East Queensland, where people can move with more ease between work, school, recreation and home. The plan will no doubt be met with cynicism by some. Great visions often are. But the simple truth is that we cannot make progress without a plan and our record speaks loudly and clearly of a government that delivers on its plans. This plan is underpinned by a single-minded determination, a clarity of purpose and the financial ability to rise to the funding challenge.

Our economic strategy has been the subject of renewed debate in the past week, and I welcome that. Few things could demonstrate the need for Queensland to restructure its finances more than the need for better transport options in communities right across Queensland. Here in South-East Queensland, population growth demands that we make the decisions necessary to build a stronger, better passenger transport system. That is why we have a clear economic strategy and our strategy is to invest in jobs and every one of these projects will be a job creator. Our strategy is to invest in skills and our new skill programs will equip people to drive these projects and our strategy includes the sale of some commercial assets, which will be better served by private investment so that we and future governments can invest in new transport assets such as those outlined in this plan today.

With this economic plan, we make clear choices and we unashamedly choose to invest in a modern public transport system that delivers to people, that delivers what Queenslanders need and, frankly, that delivers what Queenslanders deserve. We choose to put the Queensland taxpayer first by delivering better services for them and their families.

As many would know, this integrated regional transport plan has been the subject of a lot of work, in particular over the last 18 months. Consultation on the plan is now open. It is important that everyone has their say. I encourage all members who represent constituents right across the south-east to get involved. It is about our future; it is about the future of our families and the next generation of Queenslanders. I encourage people to get on the website, to get a copy and to give us some feedback.

Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Minister for Health)
(9.50 am): The Bligh government has a strong economic plan to invest in infrastructure and secure jobs for Queensland. We have the largest health infrastructure program--worth $7.33 billion--ever undertaken in the nation. The only state that comes near us is New South Wales at just over $2 billion. Over the life of this program we will deliver on more than 200 infrastructure projects that will build and expand hospitals and services from the Torres Strait to the Tweed and west to Mount Isa. It will secure close to 40,000 local construction jobs. In just 17 months--since April 2009--it has secured more than 7,580 construction jobs across the state. That is more than 7,580 Queenslanders who could wake up every day knowing they had a job to go to in one of the toughest economic times on record, knowing they had a job because we made tough choices in order to deliver a strong economic plan and knowing we would stick to it.

What is more, our $7.33 billion health infrastructure program will deliver more health services for Queenslanders. For example, it will deliver linear accelerators for the first time at the Gold Coast, Cairns, Rockhampton and the Sunshine Coast; additional linear accelerators at the Princess Alexandra Hospital and Townsville; and expanded cancer services at Hervey Bay, Bundaberg and Toowoomba. That means more cancer treatments for patients closer to their home. In Rockhampton, for example, when complete the new cancer centre will mean around 760 patients each year will no longer have to travel outside the district for cancer treatment.

In April this year I announced a $600 million investment to ramp up services, infrastructure and skills ahead of the Sunshine Coast University Hospital opening to deliver specialist services sooner than even the original date for the hospital. This includes a cardiac catheterisation laboratory, a vascular procedural suite and a new dedicated endoscopy procedural unit, outpatient neurosurgery and sustainable oncology services at Nambour Hospital. Just last month I announced that the new 96-bed ward block would be open for business a good three months ahead of schedule in early October.

Queensland was hit hard by the global financial crisis but we were determined to keep our foot on the accelerator in terms of our health building program. That is because we believe in public health care. We believe Queenslanders deserve more hospitals, more beds, more doctors, nurses and allied health professionals and more health services. The $150 million Nambour ward block directly secured more than 600 local construction jobs over the life of the project, with more than 200 workers on site every single day as construction peaked. Last Saturday at a special open day, Sunshine Coast locals got their first look at the new Nambour block ahead of its opening to patients. In addition to 96 extra beds, the new block will house new outpatient and antenatal clinics, a new special-care nursery, a new paediatric ward and allied health therapy rooms, as well as patient lounges on every one of its four floors. What is more, the new block also contains dedicated education and teaching facilities. This expanded capacity is great news for residents of the Sunshine Coast.

But what is more, because we did not take our foot off the accelerator, because we continued full steam ahead with our infrastructure projects, because we made tough decisions, not only are we delivering more health services for patients on the Sunshine Coast but also we are delivering them sooner. Also gearing up to take its first patients in September is the expanded Bundaberg emergency department. The second stage of the $45 million Bundaberg Hospital expansion will more than double the number of ED treatment spaces to 32, up from 13, and deliver an additional 14 short-stay beds, up from six, and a dedicated paediatric waiting area. Stages 3 and 4 will see the expansion of mental health and allied health services, as well as an extra 40 medical and rehabilitation beds.

We on this side of the House believe that we should be investing in vital public infrastructure and services such as health, education, transport and roads. That is why we made tough choices to deliver a strong economic plan that is building the health infrastructure for Queensland’s future and, importantly, for the future of regional Queensland.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development)
(9.54 am): The Queensland economic recovery is underway, but it does require further commitment and further work. It is not yet completely broad based and fully self-sustaining. It is sectoral and it is still relying, in part, on public investment. However, private sector capital expenditure data released last week was above the performance nationally, with a very strong result in business investing in machinery and equipment--up 48 per cent, in fact. That same release from the ABS said that business looked confidently to the 12 months ahead. The NAB report last week again pointed to the positive effect of our building program in highlighting the challenges our economic recovery faces. I expect tomorrow’s national accounts to tell a similar story.

During this time of economic uncertainty, we went to the people of Queensland promising a government focused on jobs. Above all else we said that our priority was jobs: protecting them, creating them, protecting Queenslanders and their families and creating jobs for Queenslanders. We were faced with difficult decisions to keep the focus on jobs, to focus on the Labor priority of providing the dignity of work for Queenslanders, as we faced up to the ravages of the global financial crisis. We said that we were for jobs, not cuts. The alternative proposed was across-the-board cuts to jobs--12,000 of them--to schools, to hospitals, to the services that Queenslanders rely upon. In contrast, this government is delivering jobs.

There has been 12 straight months of jobs growth. For four months in a row we were right out in front, leading the nation on jobs growth. In recent weeks we have announced more businesses voting with their feet to set up shop and take a stake in the future of the Queensland economy. We are more than halfway through our commitment of 3,000 people getting a chance through the Green Army initiative. We are ahead of target, ahead of schedule. We are more than halfway past our target of generating 100,000 net new jobs across this term. Again, we are not yet halfway through the term of this parliament. Our building program--the choice we made to build, not stop, to fund new infrastructure by divesting some commercial infrastructure--is sustaining more than 100,000 jobs across the Queensland economy. On building sites around this state, in particular in regional centres around this state, thousands of workers, contractors, tradies and their families are in a job today and that is no accident.

We made our choices. Our choices were clear. The choice today remains clear. To choose the alternative would be to devastate the Queensland economy and devastate thousands upon thousands of Queensland families by consigning them to the indignity and misery of unemployment. We have made our choice as a government and it is a choice that we stand by. We are resolved as a government, as a team, to continue. Our eyes are firmly on Queenslanders whose daily livelihoods are at stake.

Our strategy is delivering; it is delivering jobs just like we said it would. But now is not the time to coast and it is not the time to engage in recovery-killing capital works freezes like those opposite so callously suggest. Of course there are challenges--as ever. There always has been, even in times of plenty. Those challenges are the ones that we confront today. We confront them today as a Labor government with a single focus on jobs, on the prospects of the young unemployed struggling to break in and get their first job, on the livelihoods of Queensland families and, above all else, the reality that we said we stood for jobs, not cuts, and that is exactly what we are going to deliver.

Hon. RG NOLAN (Ipswich--ALP) (Minister for Transport)
(9.57 am): The Queensland government has already committed $556 million through to 2026 for the development of cycle routes under the South-East Queensland Principal Cycle Network Plan. But we are not stopping at that. South-East Queensland’s growing bikeway network is set to expand even further under the Queensland government’s 20-year Integrated Regional Transport Plan set to be released shortly by the Premier.

The active transport section of the plan contains ambitious targets for cycling in South-East Queensland, including 3,000 kilometres of cycleway by 2031. The plan outlines walking and cycling paths within five kilometres of major activity centres, for example the Logan Hyperdome, and within two kilometres of local schools and universities. It also includes end-of-trip facilities like bike storage, showers and lockers in public transport centres and new buildings similar to the existing facilities at King George Square and the Royal Brisbane and Women’s Hospital. The plan will see trials of green pods at select rail stations. These green pods are end-of-trip facilities for up to 28 cyclists all in an area the size of a single car-parking space.

This plan is about getting more people out of cars and onto bikes. If we give cyclists a network of connected bike and walking paths, separated from busy roads, I firmly believe that people will choose to cycle more often. Currently, only 10 per cent of the 9.2 million trips South-East Queensland residents are taking each day are by walking or by riding a bike. We want to double the share of walking or cycling trips from 10 per cent of all trips to 20 per cent over the next 20 years. Our government’s integrated plan will help us reach this target. Here in South-East Queensland, nearly 90 per cent of us live within five kilometres of a major business or employment centre and half of all of our car trips are for journeys of five kilometres or less. It takes only 15 to 20 minutes to cycle five kilometres. Compared to driving, battling traffic and finding a car park, cycling for those short trips is a really viable alternative. That is why we are working on a strategy to get more South-East Queenslanders on their bikes and off the roads.

Hon. RE SCHWARTEN (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology) (10.00 am): By supporting the Queensland construction industry through the global financial crisis and its aftermath, this government has saved thousands of building workers’ jobs. We are spending over $17 billion to build infrastructure such as hospitals, roads and schools and are creating over 100,000 jobs in the process.

The home building industry has been hit particularly hard by the GFC and home builders have been put under extreme pressure. Unfortunately, some builders have cut corners or have gone out of business, leaving homeowners in the lurch. Their home is usually the largest investment that most people ever make. This government will not tolerate builders who do the wrong thing.

We are protecting homeowners during these difficult financial times. In the 2009-10 financial year, the government’s Building Services Authority paid out a record $42 million in claims under the Home Warranty Scheme. This $42 million was a 50 per cent increase on the $28.5 million in claims paid last year. In other words, it doubled in the space of a year. In 2007-08 the BSA approved $32.4 million and $26 million in 2006-07. That serves to illustrate just how significant the payouts are this year.

Our record $42 million allowed the homes of 1,705 Queensland families to be repaired or completed, thanks to our unique Home Warranty Scheme, which is the best government home warranty scheme in the world as far as I know. These families would have struggled without the very strong consumer protections put in place by Labor governments.

Last year, the Home Warranty Scheme paid out an average of $10,700 on each defects claim, $38,000 on each non-completion claim and $24,700 on each subsidence claim. Honourable members should think about the effect that has on ordinary Queenslanders’ lives who are struggling to pay for a home. Suddenly their home is not completed and the BSA insurance makes up the difference. Just imagine the turmoil out there in Queensland if 1,705 Queenslanders could not move into their homes because they had not been completed and they could not afford to have them finished. If the LNP cuts the number of Queensland building projects, as it admitted it would do last Friday, I expect many more problems in home building and a further big rise in claims from homeowners.

I also would like to highlight a case brought by the BSA in the Mackay Magistrates Court on 20 August. A builder who failed to rectify work in accordance with directions issued by the BSA was ordered to pay $70,000 and meet the BSA’s legal costs or face six months imprisonment. So much for the tag that some members of this House would give the BSA of being a toothless tiger. I congratulate the court on strongly backing the BSA and consumers.

On a different matter, I wish to advise members that QFleet has taken delivery of a new zero emissions electric vehicle, the Mitsubishi i-MiEV. The i-MiEV, which is being trialled in Queensland conditions, will be on display in the front forecourt of the House today between noon and 2.30pm. If any member wishes to take it for a drive, please let us know. I am quite happy to arrange that.

Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (10.04 am): Last week the Queensland government announced a new policy framework for the long-term protection of Queensland’s best cropping land. This land, known as strategic cropping land, is the best of the best. More importantly, it is a finite resource. The Bligh government understands this and that is why it must be managed and conserved for long-term food production.

Currently, Queensland’s best cropping land is increasingly subject to a range of competing land uses including agriculture, mining and urban development. This new framework is essential for striking a balance between these competing interests as the Bligh government continues to build tomorrow’s Queensland.

I am pleased to note that the new policy framework has been well received by organisations such as the Queensland Farmers Federation, AgForce and FutureFood Queensland, who have all gone public in their praise of the policy framework. As of Monday--a week since the launch of the policy--the strategic cropping land content on the Department of Environment and Resource Management’s website had received almost 2,000 visitors. The policy framework document itself has been downloaded 679 times.

The Bligh government has engaged in extensive consultation in developing the new framework, with nearly 400 submissions received on a consultation paper released in February. In addition, key stakeholders from the agricultural, development and resources sectors have been extensively consulted through a stakeholder advisory committee. As part of the new framework, the government will develop a new act to be introduced in early 2011. The new act will establish definitive strategic cropping land trigger maps and will outline the criteria for validating whether land is strategic cropping land. This process of assessment will be conducted state-wide and will apply to both resources and urban development proposals.

Resource developments will only proceed if they can demonstrate that the land can be restored to its previous cropping capability at the completion of a project. If there is evidence that a development will permanently alienate strategic cropping land, it will not gain approval to proceed. Strategic cropping land will also need to be considered when land is designated for urban development. Urban developments on strategic cropping land will be subject to the same standard of assessment as resource developments.

The government will continue to work with key stakeholders from the agricultural, development and resources sectors over the coming months to further refine the framework and develop the new act. The deadline for public comment on the strategic cropping land policy framework is 30 September. I urge all interested parties to take the opportunity to register their views.

Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training) (10.06 am): The Bligh government is giving all Queensland students a flying start to learning and life. As we sit here today, more than 30,000 year 12 students are undertaking the Queensland core skills--QCS--test in world-class education facilities delivered by a Labor government. I know I speak on behalf of all members in wishing students across Queensland the best of luck for the two-day exam. I have a 17-year-old sitting for the exam. As a parent, I have a close familiarity with the challenges of this two-day period.

The QCS will assess the broad range of skills that students have developed during that schooling. Student results will contribute to the calculation of overall positions and field positions for tertiary entrance. Although sitting for tests can be stressful, I am confident that our year 12 students will do well, and I wish them all the very best.

This is a major step on the road to giving these students a flying start to learning and life. The QCS is an important part of learning, but it is not the only option for students in our schools. Queensland has 45 per cent of Australia’s school based apprentices--the highest in the country. Much of this is thanks to the Labor government’s investment in school trade training centres, which the Liberal National Party proposes to cut.

The state government recently undertook the Next Step Survey to look at what year 12 graduates from 2009 were doing six months after completing their year 12 studies. Almost nine in 10 were studying or in paid employment, six in 10 continued in education or training and more than one-third were enrolled in a university degree course. Approximately one-quarter were doing vocational study including apprenticeships and traineeships. Overall, the trend continues to improve. This shows that Queensland students are using the flying start they have received from their schools to find work and study. As Queensland education minister, I am proud of every young Queenslander, no matter whether they have decided to study or to work.

Unlike the member for Surfers Paradise and the Liberal National Party, the Bligh government has a plan for making major improvements to the Queensland education system. The Queensland Labor government has a strong leader, supported by a united team, working to give every young Queenslander a flying start in learning and life.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! I call the Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services.
Hon. NS ROBERTS (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (10.09 am): Thank you, Mr Commissioner.
Honourable members: Ha, ha!
Mr SPEAKER: Be careful what you wish for.
Mr ROBERTS: I was harking back to my days as an industrial relations advocate, Mr Speaker.
Mr SPEAKER: So was I.

Mr ROBERTS: Last week, the Commissioner of Police took decisive action to address concerns about the alleged behaviour and misconduct of some police on the Gold Coast. The commissioner announced a range of initiatives that will strengthen supervision and tighten existing policies in a range of areas. Significant and immediate reforms will include the upgrade of the OIC position in the Surfers Paradise division to the level of inspector, with an evaluation to identify whether upgrades are required at other similar sized establishments across the state; doubling the number of front-line district duty officers on the coast from five to 10; appointing two additional professional practice managers to focus on ethical standards and practices; a new policy on the use of police vehicles to address claims of inappropriate usage; and a state-wide review of recruitment policies and procedures. While these initiatives are clearly focused on addressing identified concerns on the Gold Coast, they are also about supporting the overwhelming majority of honest and decent police whose reputations can be tarnished by the actions of a few.

As part of Operation Tesco, the Crime and Misconduct Commission has announced that it will be conducting public hearings on the Gold Coast in September. The government and the Police Service will consider other policy changes as required and recommended by the CMC following the release of its report. The Police Service of today is worlds apart from that which existed in the pre-Fitzgerald era. The Queensland Police Service of today is characterised by a commitment to professionalism and ethical standards, and also a powerful and growing culture of intolerance towards inappropriate behaviour and towards those who do not accept the high standards expected and required. Therefore, it is no surprise that around one-quarter of all complaints now lodged about inappropriate behaviour are made by police against police.

Other initiatives announced by the commissioner include the development of new policies on inappropriate associations and gratuities; enhanced training programs for supervisors; and enhanced recognition of good work, leadership, professional and ethical practice and consistent performance. Queenslanders, quite rightly, expect high standards from their police officers. The government stands by the commissioner in his actions to restore public confidence and not let the actions of a few tarnish the reputation and morale of the overwhelming majority of police who are doing the right thing.

Hon. PJ LAWLOR (Southport--ALP) (Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading) (10.12 am): The Bligh government has said ‘enough is enough’ to alcohol related violence. We want to see an environment where people can go out, have a good time and return home safely. That is why we are declaring special Drink Safe precincts under a $4.2 million plan in Fortitude Valley, Townsville and Surfers Paradise. The Drink Safe precincts will have increased police numbers, better supervised taxi zones, more support services and the creation of special safe zones. We will also legislate for new powers to ban troublemakers from these areas. The use of ID scanners by clubs will also be supported under the plan. In the area of transport, the Drink Safe precincts will feature better access to bus and train information, and the opening hours of the Fortitude Valley Railway Station will be extended. In the health area, we will introduce new legislation to ensure fresh drinking water is provided free to patrons in pubs and clubs. The existing lockout laws will stay in place to provide certainty to both licensees and patrons, and also give the new measures a chance to work.

This is a trial. We will assess what worked and what did not, and if trading hours need to change then that could be back on the table. Unfortunately, there are those who are criticising from the sidelines before the trials have even started. Meanwhile, the Bligh government is committing $4.2 million to make this work and bring about a safer environment. These measures are long term, community based and holistic and will be continuously monitored. None of the measures will be a quick fix and will need the support of the community, industry and government to be effective. It will take time to inspire change in a problematic drinking culture. This is not only an issue for Queensland but also an issue for Australia. However, I am confident that if government and community work together we can achieve our goal such that people can go out, have a good time and return home safely.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Regional Development Initiative, Funding; Ballantyne, Mr I
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. TS MULHERIN (Mackay--ALP) (Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland) (10.14 am): Today I am pleased to announce that five projects promoting regional economic development in key regional areas will receive combined funding of nearly half a million dollars. As part of the Queensland Regional Development Initiative, projects in Mackay/Whitsundays, Wide Bay/Burnett, Darling Downs/Surat and South-West Queensland will receive $435,000. The funding is part of $7.52 million of funding over the next four years to support regional economic development projects. Funding for projects was increased in this year’s budget by $1.26 million for the four-year life of the program. The increased funding is another example of the Bligh government’s commitment to growth in regional and rural Queensland and to making our regions attractive places for Queenslanders to live, work and raise families. QRDI provides funds to regional development organisations to deliver key projects such as developing skilled labour, creating job opportunities and promoting a region as an attractive place to live for both residents and new workers.

In this round of funding, Enterprise Whitsundays will receive $100,000 for its capitalising on the horticulture industry project, which is very timely following the catastrophic seedling poisoning that recently devastated vegetable crops in Bowen. The Mackay Whitsunday Regional Economic Development Corporation has been granted $65,000 for its green industry diversification project and $55,000 for the retail skills attraction strategy. The Burnett Inland Economic Development Organisation has been allocated $115,000 towards its clean and clever Burnett inland project. The south-west regional economic development remote area development organisation will receive $100,000 to identify and brand the region as the home of the natural sciences.

QRDI has encouraged economic growth, generated jobs and supported local business in Queensland since 2005. Through regional partnerships and programs like QRDI, over the next 18 months the Bligh government will work with stakeholders on population and prosperity led strategies for boosting the liveability, sustainability and economic viability of our regions. This is another initiative promoting business and population movements to regional Queensland.

While I am on my feet, I take this opportunity to acknowledge the retirement of the CEO of Canegrowers, Ian Ballantyne. Ian has been a passionate advocate for the industry for the past 20 years. During Mr Ballantyne’s time as CEO, the industry has undergone huge changes including expansion, deregulation, low prices, price increases, floods, droughts and diseases such as orange rust and sugarcane smut. Throughout his career Mr Ballantyne has been held in high esteem within the industry. I wish Ian the best in his retirement.

Hon. CR DICK (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations) (10.18 am): On 1 January this year, a range of new State Penalties Enforcement Registry enforcement powers came into effect, giving SPER expanded options to recover unpaid fines from individuals who refuse to meet their obligations. Introduced by the Bligh government and supported by all sides of this House, these powers included a wheel-clamping trial and the expansion of driver licence suspensions to non-motor vehicle related offences. The broadening of driver licence suspensions is proving to be an effective tool in collecting unpaid fines for a wide range of matters, including court ordered fines for drug or break-and-enter offences or to recover compensation for offences such as assaults. The funds that SPER is collecting are being used to assist all Queenslanders to pay for roads, schools and hospitals and to hire extra teachers, nurses and police.

However, in the past eight months it has also become clear that some fine defaulters are still struggling to appreciate that they have an obligation to pay their outstanding fines or risk further sanctions. Responsible Queenslanders view driving as a privilege, not an entitlement, and they meet their obligations to society by paying their fines on time and keeping their address up to date, as they are obliged to do by law. Yet there remain some people who are not prepared to meet these basic obligations, even with the express threat of licence suspension hanging over their heads and even after being sent at least four notices. Losing your licence is a tough penalty, but it is a penalty that this government and every member of this parliament have agreed must be available as a sanction for those individuals who continue to purposely avoid meeting their obligations. It takes only one phone call, one letter, one email or one visit to enter into compliance. It is not a difficult hurdle to clear to retain one’s privilege to drive.

There is no doubt that the new measures are having an effect. A record $166.4 million was collected by SPER last financial year. The expanded driver licence suspension provisions have contributed to this, as have the new wheel-clamping and seizure-and-sale provisions. As at last week, SPER had 38,878 driver licence suspensions in place, with only about one-third of these for non-motor vehicle related offences. Getting a suspension lifted is easy: just pay your fine or enter into a payment instalment plan and SPER will lift your suspension the same day. During 2009-10, almost 40,000 suspensions were lifted as a result of debtors paying their fines or making arrangements to pay them off in instalments.

As I mentioned earlier, these new driver licence suspension provisions took effect at the same time as our 12-month trial of wheel clamping for high-value fine defaulters. Both of these enforcement mechanisms will be reviewed early next year as part of our ongoing commitment to continually improving the SPER system. We want this system to be fair and we are happy to evaluate the effectiveness of the new enforcement powers to ensure they are operating effectively and fairly. Nevertheless, I also want to reassert the government’s determination to continue its pursuit of fine defaulters. If you simply refuse to pay or avoid paying an outstanding fine, you face the risk of tougher penalties. However, with one call to SPER on 1300365635 these tougher sanctions can be easily avoided.

Hon. KL STRUTHERS (Algester--ALP) (Minister for Community Services and Housing and Minister for Women) (10.21 am): The Bligh government is a job creator, building a better future for all Queenslanders. In my portfolio, that means creating more than 3,500 construction jobs around Queensland through our social housing rollout in 2010. It means getting on with the job of building more than 3,000 new social housing dwellings by the end of this year across the state. It means a record investment in housing for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities.

Just last week in Cairns I met face to face with 15 mayors from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities to plan the next stage of the housing rollout in their communities. During the current financial year, we plan to deliver 120 new homes and 444 upgrades to these Indigenous communities using $95 million in funding from the Bligh government. This comes on top of our $1.1 billion 10-year partnership with the federal Labor government which will deliver 1,200 new homes over the next 10 years. That means that this year alone we will deliver 67 new houses and 454 upgrades.

A key feature of the investment is that at least 20 per cent of the labour used to deliver the homes must be Indigenous labour. I know that the member for Cook, Jason O’Brien, is absolutely committed to creating jobs on the cape. He will be pleased to know that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander workers are taking up the opportunities on offer through 243 projects that are currently underway.

That workforce includes 14 Indigenous employees working and earning on projects in Woorabinda, 30 Indigenous employees working and earning in projects in Hope Vale, 14 Indigenous employees working and earning in projects on Palm Island, 22 Indigenous employees working and earning on projects in Wujal Wujal, and every other community has a positive story to tell.

The Bligh government is committed to closing the gap on Indigenous disadvantage. One of the best ways we can do that is to deliver more housing and that is what we are doing. The opposition treasury spokesman has confirmed that the LNP would ‘reassess’ building and infrastructure projects like our housing rollout.
Mr Cripps: Why has your department cancelled a million dollar social housing project at Ingham?
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable member for Hinchinbrook.

Ms STRUTHERS: That means that the opposition is putting at risk each of these jobs I have talked about today and taking a great step backwards when it comes to closing the gap on Indigenous disadvantage.

Hon. A PALASZCZUK (Inala--ALP) (Minister for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs) (10.24 am): According to the Australian Longitudinal Study on Women’s Health, 72 per cent of young women aged between 18 and 22 years want to weigh less and only 25 per cent of those in the healthy weight range are happy with their current weight. The 2005 National Health Survey reported that nine per cent of females aged 18 to 24 years were classified as underweight. A 2006 survey of young people by Mission Australia found that body image was a significant concern for close to 30 per cent of young Australians both male and female.

Frankly, these statistics are staggering. When it comes to body image many Queensland women struggle with self-esteem issues and feel growing pressure to be thin. Images of rake thin, airbrushed models do nothing to help our young women chart the often difficult journey through adolescence. The Bligh government wants young Queensland women to start feeling good about themselves. We want young women to enter adulthood confident and determined to achieve their best--not to be held back by concerns about how they look. I am pleased to announce today two important projects to help our young women develop a healthy body image and positive self-esteem.

The Eating Disorders Association will receive $100,000 to undertake research to reach out to families and young people affected by an eating disorder and provide them with information and support about services available, how to deal with young people and body image, how to promote healthy eating and how to deal with self-esteem issues experienced by young people with eating disorders. The Minister for Health and I have contributed $50,000 each to this project. This will complement the $223,000 in recurrent funding that the organisation will receive from the Department of Communities for 2010-11. We want to ensure that Queenslanders suffering from eating disorders receive the best treatment possible. But to do that we need to ensure that we have proof that we are channelling our funding into the right area. We are determined to do more.

Today I am pleased to announce that we will also give $29,000 to Isis--the Eating Issues Centre to offer a series of workshops aimed at schoolchildren and community groups promoting healthy eating, body image and self-esteem. This initiative will give young people the support they need to seek help early in the hope of preventing hospitalisation for an eating disorder.

The mental health of Queenslanders is an issue that the Bligh government is working very hard to address. We need to act early to stop these young people entering our hospitals. We want to give them the support that they need, we need to help them with their self-esteem and we need to ensure that they do get the very best start in life.

Hon. KJ JONES (Ashgrove--ALP) (Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability) (10.26 am): This government has a proud track record when it comes to protecting the environment. Queensland has the most unique biodiversity in the world and we are committed to ensuring that it is protected now and into the future. That is why we have a plan to increase the area of national parks to 7.5 per cent of the state by 2020. I am proud to advise the House that we are continuing to deliver on this plan.

Our government has created 17 new national parks and expanded a further 20 across this state in the past 12 months. That is more than 79,500 hectares added to our national parks in just 12 months. From Cape York to the Gold Coast, pristine land of the highest biodiversity values has been protected. The gazettal of the 7,700 hectares Humboldt National Park in Central Queensland last year preserved a number of important, endangered regional ecosystems. In June we created more than 7,600 hectares of new national park in North and Far North Queensland. That included more than 5,000 hectares of important cassowary habitat in the new Macalister Range National Park, north-west of Cairns. Also in June, the iconic Glass House Mountains National Park--
An honourable member: Hear, hear!

Ms JONES: I take the interjection from the local member and thank him for his support. It was expanded by 2,100 hectares, protecting another four mountain peaks, as well as 500 plant and animal species.

The total area of national parks in Queensland now stands at more than 8.1 million hectares. That is more than double the combined areas of Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide and Canberra. But we are not stopping there. This state government’s commitment to environmental protection is as strong as ever. Just recently we announced that sandmining on North Stradbroke Island will be phased out and that 80 per cent of the island will be transitioned to national park. Mr Speaker, you would not get this kind of protection for Queensland’s unique biodiversity under an LNP government. The LNP are divided over the future of North Straddie, they oppose the expansion of our national parks, they oppose the protection of the Great Barrier Reef and Moreton Bay. While we protect, they destroy.

I would like to finish by passing on my best wishes to Ian Ballantyne, who is retiring as the CEO of Canegrowers. He has been there for almost 20 years. Ian and I did not always see eye to eye on particular issues, but I would like to put on the public record--
Mr Cripps interjected.
Ms JONES: You do not support Canegrowers?
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable the minister. Member for Hinchinbrook, I have been very patient with you this morning.

Ms JONES: I want to put on the public record that I hold him in great esteem. We worked very well together in delivering significant reforms in the Great Barrier Reef Protection Bill. I wish him all the best for his retirement.

Hon. JC SPENCE (Sunnybank--ALP) (Leader of the House) (10.29 am): I wish to advise the House that the Minister for Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships will be absent from question time today. Minister Boyle is opening the 2010 Local Government Association of Queensland’s annual conference in Mackay.
Mrs MILLER (Bundamba--ALP) (10.30 am): I table the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee’s Legislation Alert No. 10 of 2010 .
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Scrutiny of Legislation Committee, Legislation Alert No. 10 of 2010 [ 2846 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind) (10.30 am): I give notice that I will move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House notes:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1 In 2005 Retired Supreme Court Judge Geoff Davies in the QLD Hospital Commission of inquiry at page 27--2.22 says:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent1: “In consequence, Queensland has become highly dependent for a number of years on doctors from developing countries. This state employs well more Overseas trained doctors than any other Australian state and, at least by 2003, the proportion of Resident Medical Officers who were overseas trained doctors across the State was approaching 50 per cent ...”
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 2 Judge Davies also wrote with regard to years 2002-03 ...
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent1: “Over the same period, the proportion of doctors originating from India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Malaysia, the Philippines, Bangladesh and ‘other’ increased from 9.6 per cent to 37.3 per cent. Queensland authorities often know little about the training standards at particular medical schools in those countries”
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 3 That in 2010 Dr Ross Cartmill from the AMA states that:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent1: “The Government or Qld Health prefers hiring Salaried Doctors rather than V.M.Os even if this means employing overseas trained doctors rather than well trained Australian specialists.”
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: And calls on the Premier to end the policy of preferencing the hiring of over seas trained doctors in QLD Health and restart negotiations with the AMA regarding the employment of Australian Trained VMO’s.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Order! Before I call question time, I advise the House that today we will be visited by parents, students and teachers of the Belmont State School in the electorate of Chatsworth, the Childers State School in the electorate of Burnett, the Charlton State School in the electorate of Condamine and the Coolum Beach Christian College in the electorate of Nicklin. Question time will end at 11.31 am.

Mr LANGBROEK (10.31 am): My first question without notice is to the Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology. There appears to be a dispute between the Premier and the Premier’s parliamentary secretary about whether or not leadership was raised at yesterday’s caucus meeting. The Premier claims leadership was not raised, yet the parliamentary secretary is adamant that it was raised. On behalf of the thousands of departmental employees that he represents, will the minister advise the House who is telling the truth?
Mr SPEAKER: Order! I want to get advice as to whether that falls within the purview of the minister’s portfolio. It is out of order.
Mr LANGBROEK: I rise to a point of order, Mr Speaker.
Government members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: I will hear the point of order.

Mr LANGBROEK: These were meetings that were held at the Executive Building. These meetings were held where the minister is responsible for a department and the Premier is clearly the leader of the state. Therefore, the question that I asked is certainly relevant and should be answered by the minister.
Mr Schwarten: I beg you, Mr Speaker: can I answer the question?

Mr SPEAKER: The problem is that it is not within the standing orders. It must come within the honourable minister’s portfolio. I cannot see how that question is within the minister’s portfolio. I will ask the member to ask his second question. The question is not within the portfolio of the honourable minister.

Mr LANGBROEK: My second question without notice is to the Premier. The Premier could not tell the truth about fuel tax, could not tell the truth about privatisation and could not tell the truth about electricity prices, so let us see whether the Premier can tell the truth about leadership. Was the Premier’s leadership raised at yesterday’s crisis caucus meeting of the Labor Party?

Mr SPEAKER: Let me explain to the House the differentiation in allowing this question. The Premier is the leader of the state but is also the leader of the political party. Accordingly, I am allowing the question on the basis that the Premier is the leader of both. I call the honourable Premier.

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. I am very pleased to have an opportunity to clarify what seems to be some misunderstanding among some people reporting on what was a normally scheduled caucus meeting yesterday. I am happy to put on the record comments by the Leader of the House.

Let us be very clear about one thing. The Leader of the House in Labor caucus has a very specific role, and that is to speak to the media after every caucus meeting and advise them of matters of significance that would be of public interest. For example, the Leader of the House advises the media at the end of every caucus meeting of those bills that have been approved by the caucus meeting for introduction into the House and on any other matters that might be of particular public interest. There is nothing unusual at all about what the Leader of the House did. That has been the case in Labor caucuses for decades. There was nothing different about that yesterday.

The Leader of the House and I were asked two different questions and we gave answers that are entirely consistent. I am happy to read from an interview that the Leader of the House did on ABC Radio this morning. She stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Clearly the support of the whole caucus was behind Anna Bligh yesterday. There were no challenges, no suggestions of any challenges. People are confident that she is the person to lead us. I think it is--
XML.Hansard-Body: Opposition members interjected.
Ms BLIGH: Do you want the answer? She continued--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I think it is wrong to say that we are at odds on any of these issues.
XML.Hansard-Body: Let us apply just a little bit of common sense to this. Were the issues that were raised by a pretty extraordinary federal election debated by my caucus? Of course they were. People in the street are talking about these issues. I want a caucus that is engaged in the big issues. I want a caucus that is engaged in the public issues of our time. I would have thought there was a pretty big message there for all major parties. It seems extraordinary to me that there does not seem to be any analysis on the other side of the House about what it might have meant for that side of politics. I do not think it is without a message there as well.

Were there issues raised about how we could do better, including me as leader? Of course there were. But was there a question about my leadership? Was there any doubt about any challenge? No. I thank the honourable member for the opportunity to clarify that on the record. I would suggest to the Leader of the Opposition that there were pretty big messages sent to major parties at the federal election. I would expect that not only would my caucus be debating them but also that it would be a good thing if members opposite did the same.
Mr Schwarten interjected.
Mr Lucas interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The Deputy Premier and the Minister for Public Works! I call the member for Chatsworth.
Mr KILBURN: My question without notice is to the Premier. Could the Premier outline some of the real benefits that the government’s plan for the rail revolution can deliver to Queenslanders?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for his question. I thank him for his interest in managing world-class public transport in one of the fastest growing areas of Australia. Under our plan, timetables will eventually become a thing of the past with turn-up-and-go public transport services under our 20-year transport plan. It will mean high-frequency, high-reliability services operating along core rail and bus routes. It is members like the member for Chatsworth who understand how important reliable, fast, high-speed, high-frequency services are in providing absolute certainty and confidence to the people who live in suburbs like his. If they have that confidence they will use the public transport.

If they are using public transport, they are leaving their cars behind. If they are taking their cars off the road, that is a benefit to all of us. It is a benefit to everybody who does have to use their car because it frees up road space and it also reduces the emissions that we are putting into the atmosphere, and that is a benefit for all Queenslanders. So I thank the member for his interest in this.

What we will provide under the turn-up-and-go network will include frequencies of 15 minutes all day, seven days a week, quality bus shelters and rail shelters and passenger information, and simplified high-frequency network maps with no need for a timetable. New services called UrbanLink will mean more frequent, higher capacity rail services travelling to the city from the outer suburbs, and that is good news for families buying their first home out in some of the outer suburbs--faster rail, better rail, better confidence in the public transport system.

Our Integrated Regional Transport Plan is a plan that has a very clear line of sight over the next two decades--one where, as we work through each budget, this government and subsequent governments can have a clear vision, and that is what this does. I know there will be cynicism, but the simple truth is that you never make progress without a plan and we are a government with a strong track record of delivering on those plans.

But what about those opposite? The shadow Treasurer let the cat out of the bag on Friday. What did he say? He said that an LNP government would reassess projects. Beware the word ‘reassess’, because if you are reassessed--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!
Mr Seeney: What do you think we’re going to do? Just keep going the same as you?
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Stop the clock. I will wait for the House to come to order. I call the Premier.

Ms BLIGH: I take the interjection from the member for Callide, who confirmed the shadow Treasurer’s view when he just said, ‘What do you think we’re going to do? Keep up the projects like you?’ No, we do not.
Mr SEENEY: I rise to a point of order. I find the Premier’s childish attempt to verbal me offensive and I ask that it be withdrawn.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable gentleman has asked for a withdrawal. Please withdraw.

Ms BLIGH: Mr Speaker, I withdraw. The proposition here is very clear: you simply cannot imagine the future if you are focused on delaying the present, and that is what the LNP stands for--cutting the projects. Which electorates? Which projects? Come clean!
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Leader of the House, Sale of Public Assets
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPRINGBORG: My question without notice is to the Premier. Last week Labor MPs were running around Queensland telling everyone that they opposed privatisation, but the Premier’s parliamentary secretary, Judy Spence, has told the media that no-one spoke against asset sales at yesterday’s caucus meeting. Premier, is that true?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for the question. I have made a number of public comments about the caucus meeting that was held yesterday. I think they have been very clear. Members consistently spoke about some of the concerns being raised by their constituents, but at the end of the day they understood that cutting infrastructure projects in their electorates would be devastating. They one after another indicated that they are not prepared to support cutting the building of new hospitals, new schools, new roads and new rail in their electorates. And why? Because they understand that those projects are delivering jobs. They understand that they are delivering job security. They understand that they are keeping local companies afloat when there is no private investment.
Mr Springborg: So they speak against it in the media and the community but not in the caucus?
Mr SPEAKER: Order! I call the Premier.

Ms BLIGH: The contrast between the two sides of politics in Queensland is as stark today as it was at the election in 2009. We said that we stood for jobs. We said that we would deliver jobs. What did we get from the LNP? It would deliver--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my left will cease interjecting. I call the Premier.
Ms BLIGH: The LNP went and promised cuts, and what it has reaffirmed in the last five days is that that is still its economic strategy.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my left will cease interjecting. I call the Premier.
Ms BLIGH: The LNP went to the election last time promising cuts and it reaffirmed those cuts on Friday.
Opposition members interjected.

Ms BLIGH: And the shadow Treasurer confirms it again this morning--cut jobs, cut projects. That is the strategy. We will not back it. We will make the decisions that need to be made. When Queenslanders need a team that will stand up and fight for them when they need it, Labor is the team. You will hide under the bed.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Stop the clock. Resume your seat, Premier. I will wait for the House to come to order. I call the Premier.

Ms BLIGH: As I said, when Queenslanders need a team that has the courage and the determination to make the difficult decisions to create a future for the next generation of Queenslanders, it is Labor that has that kind of backbone. What we have is a government that is prepared to take on some of the difficult decisions. Those opposite will not even back their own party policy on this, and therein lies their weakness. Everybody knows what your party policy is on this. You are implausible. You confirmed your weakness at a time when Queensland needs strength.

Mr WATT: My question is directed to the Premier. Premier, you have stated that the government can do more to listen and understand the issues facing Queenslanders. Can you please advise the House of any ideas presented which you intend to adopt?

Mr SPEAKER: Order! I would ask the honourable member to rephrase the question. This practice of ‘you’ is coming in again. I should have warned the House this morning that I will not tolerate it. Rephrase your question or I will rule it out of order.
Mr WATT: Thank you, Mr Speaker. Premier, you have stated that the government can do--
Mr SPEAKER: Righto. I call the honourable member for Maroochydore.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Member for Bundamba, Sale of Public Assets
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms SIMPSON: My question is to the Premier. Yesterday a letter to the editor was published signed by four union delegates claiming that the member for Bundamba, Jo-Ann Miller, should be congratulated for her principled opposition to the sale of Queensland Rail. Premier, given that the member for Bundamba has never once voted against privatisation in this House and given that we are told no-one opposed privatisation at yesterday’s caucus meeting, is the Premier aware of any other occasions when the member for Bundamba has opposed her government’s privatisation program?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for the question. As I have said, I have made public comments on the matters that concerned my caucus meeting. I do not intend to continue to go into detail about who said what. What I do intend, though, is to talk a little bit about the sorts of decisions that faced our government and the sorts of decisions that we had the strength to make and we have the strength to see through.
Mr Seeney: So you’re not going to answer the question?
Mr SPEAKER: Order! I will wait for the House to come to order. I call the Premier.
Ms BLIGH: Thank you, Mr Speaker.
Mr Seeney: Do you want her to repeat it?
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Member for Callide! I call the Premier.
Ms BLIGH: Thank you, Mr Speaker. Our caucus was faced, as a government, with the most difficult economic circumstances Queensland had faced for three-quarters of a century.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Stop the clock. I will wait for the House to come to order. I call the Premier.

Ms BLIGH: Thank you, Mr Speaker. Did we debate those issues in our caucus at the time? Of course we did. Were there people who expressed some concern and disagreement? Of course there were. It would be implausible if there was not a debate, and I never want to lead a caucus where there is no debate. I never want to lead a caucus that runs out of ideas and does not have the stamina to stand up and debate them. So I am proud of my caucus. I am proud of its ability to grapple with big ideas and to grapple with new ideas. That is what we did on this issue, and that is well known. But it is the hallmark of our caucus that once we have that debate and once the majority makes the decision, that is how this government will operate, and that is how we have operated. There is nothing new about that. It is the platform of the Australian Labor Party. It is one of the fundamental core values that has seen us as one of the longest serving political parties in the history of Australia.

So it is that stability and that unity that is delivered by that sort of discipline. I do not have a problem with members of my caucus talking in caucus about their views. I never will. That is the place where they should debate and that is the place where they debate ideas. What we saw yesterday was, yet again, a caucus putting Queenslanders first, a caucus delivering on hard decisions so that Queenslanders will have a strong, bright future.

Today we see that future outlined when it comes to public transport--the strong vision of our government determined to deliver more to the passengers on our public transport network. How do we deliver that? We make the decisions necessary so that coal companies can invest in the transport of their product to market so that governments do what governments should do and that is deliver better passenger transport on rail and on buses.

Mr HOOLIHAN: My question is to the honourable Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. Would the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health update the House on how the government’s strong economic plan is delivering more hospital infrastructure across the state?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. The Bligh government is sticking to its strong economic plan to deliver more jobs, to build infrastructure and to invest in Queensland’s economic recovery. Of course, one of the things about investment in health is that you get the capital investment from building the infrastructure, the jobs for those people who are building the infrastructure and, of course, hospitals are very labour intensive in their ongoing operations. Interestingly, there has been some debate about government assets. I make the point that the increased employment in doctors, nurses and allied health professionals in Queensland Health since 2005 has massively outstripped the employment in those agencies that are being looked at for sale. That is what the future of government is. That is what government is about in the 21st century. Frankly, the future government employee will be a doctor, a nurse, a teacher, a social health worker, or a disability worker. That is what the future of government service delivery is. That is where the growth is. Budgets are about choices and we make no apology for making those tough decisions on behalf of Queenslanders. They expect us to do that and, ultimately, whether it is health infrastructure or the $372 million flyover to the airport, it is all about choices that governments make on behalf of people.

Our Health budget this year has grown by 10 per cent on last year’s Health budget against a population increase of 2.6 per cent. Of course, with a $7.33 billion infrastructure program major projects are underway: upgrading EDs at the Logan, Redlands, QE2, Caboolture, Ipswich and Toowoomba hospitals and building a dedicated paediatric emergency department at Prince Charles Hospital. There are also big hospital projects--and you only have to look down the coast to see the strength of the regions of this state--at Cairns, Townsville, Mackay, Rockhampton and Bundaberg. There is also our commitment to the Sunshine Coast. There is not only the capital infrastructure on the Sunshine Coast but also the early rollout of services there in direct response to discussions with clinicians--those people who really want to know.
But what did the member for Clayfield say last Friday? He indicated that all building projects would be reassessed under the LNP.
Mr NICHOLLS: I rise to a point of order. This is just another cheap attempt at verballing. I find the minister’s comments offensive and ask that they be withdrawn.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable member has found the words offensive. He has asked for a withdrawal from the minister.

Mr LUCAS: I withdraw them. Of course, the opposition is extremely sensitive to this fact. The simple point is this: when you seek to distinguish yourself, you let the cat out of the bag. This government has distinguished itself by the fact that it will make the tough decisions so that it can deliver more health services. What you are now saying--and you were caught out at the last election because of it--is that you want to make choices that involve negatively impacting on health services.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable the Deputy Premier will address his comments through the chair.

Mr LUCAS: The other side of the House wants to make those decisions that will negatively impact on the delivery of health services and other services throughout Queensland. They cannot have it both ways. The Liberal Party and the National Party are ideologically wired, whether it is in Queensland or in other states or federally, to sell and they will do so.

Mr GIBSON: My question is to the Premier. Maxine McKew blames the federal election loss on the Labor Party’s failed campaign, for which the Premier is the national president. Julia Gillard, however, blames dud state Labor governments, and the Premier leads one. Does the Premier accept responsibility for the loss as the ALP national president or as a dud state Labor Premier?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for the question and I have to endorse the comments of others here. I have rarely seen so much boasting with so little to be proud of from those opposite. It is pretty extraordinary that for every week of the campaign those opposite raised the view that, as federal president, I had no role in the campaign and now they are saying that I ran it. There was press release after press release about how I was having no role in the campaign.
Mr Lucas: You sidelined yourself.

Ms BLIGH: Yes. This comes from someone who, of course, was hidden. Where was the member for Surfers Paradise? If I were the member for Gympie I would be a lot more worried about the comments from the shadow Treasurer. I note his sensitivity so I will quote from the ABC transcript on Friday. The shadow Treasurer was invited by the compere, Madonna King, to say how he would fund the budget without asset sales. He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... so what we said is you need to reassess these projects.
XML.Hansard-Body: He is condemned by his own words. I am happy to add that one of the projects the shadow Treasurer said should be reassessed was the Traveston Dam. He seems to have forgotten that it was totally reassessed last year and does not exist and is not in the program. Reassessing a non-existent project is not going to fund the ring-road in Townsville and it is not going to fund the hospital upgrades.
Today seems as good a day as any to remind a few people over there, including the shadow Treasurer, of their own views on privatisation--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: They are all desirable aims arising from the privatisation of the electricity industry in Queensland.
Indeed, one has to wonder why, if privatisation is so good, it has taken so long ... why not sell the poles and wires ... Why not sell the generators...
XML.Hansard-Body: We know where the shadow Treasurer’s heart lies on this issue. We know what he tells the boardrooms and what he has told this parliament. That is what he has said on the record. He speaks with forked tongue on this issue.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: ‘Walk a day in my shoes’ Program
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms DARLING: My question is to the Premier. Can the Premier inform the House what the government plans to do to better understand the issues facing Queenslanders and to listen to their concerns?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for her question and I thank her for her very constructive contribution to our discussions yesterday. As I outlined in my post-caucus media conference last night, there were a lot of ideas put forward by what I regard as a very talented team.
