I am very happy to advise the House today that one of the ideas that we discussed in some detail, and which we have resolved to take forward, is a program that has been developed by labour unions in the United States. It is a program designed specifically to ensure that elected members of parliament have a much better understanding of the reality of the working lives of the members of their organisations, particularly those in low-paid workplaces. It is a program that some members may have heard of. It is called ‘walk a day in my shoes’. Quite simply, it is a challenge to elected members of parliament to spend the day in the shoes of a worker, particularly in an industry where they may not have much familiarity with and where there is low-paid employment. We resolved as a caucus that we will implement this program in a comprehensive way. I have had discussions with the trade unions.
Mr Gibson interjected.
Mr Horan interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: The member for Gympie and the member for Toowoomba South will cease interjecting.

Ms BLIGH: I have had preliminary discussions with trade unions about their involvement in this program. Some Australian unions have already started putting this program in place. We also resolved that we would be looking not only at large workplaces but also at small enterprises, many of which we know are not unionised but are dealing with real issues out there--industries like tourism, for example.

Every member of the caucus will be involved in a comprehensive, well-planned program between now and Christmas where we will set out to walk a day in the shoes of workers in our electorates. Some of us will have more than one opportunity to do this. I certainly commit myself to that task--not only here in the south-east but also in regional Queensland. This is a very useful program to ensure that members get a real-life experience--not just five minutes in a shopping centre talking to someone but a whole day talking to people in their workplaces with their delegates in the lunchroom, as well as getting a sense of the sorts of days and work opportunities that people are experiencing.

This is a chance for us to connect in different ways. We do not believe that everything that has been done in the past is the only way forward. We are happy to embrace new ideas. We are happy to look around the world and find the best of what is happening. We are not frightened of ideas. We embrace the future, unlike those opposite.

Mr SEENEY: My question without notice is to the Premier. I refer to the Premier’s statement yesterday when she said that she would resign as Premier if she was a liability to the Labor Party, and I ask: has the Premier consulted with Arch Bevis to find out if she is a liability? Has she consulted with Jon Sullivan, Brett Raguse, Kerry Rae or Chris Trevor? In fact, has the Premier--
Government members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Those on my right will cease interjecting.
Mr Lucas interjected.

Mr SPEAKER:
The honourable the Deputy Premier, I have asked for silence from those on my right.
Mr SEENEY: My question is: has the Premier consulted with any of the federal members who were defeated last weekend to see whether they think she is a liability to Labor in Queensland?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for the question. I am very happy to outline for the member for Callide the comments that I made in the days after the federal election because I think, frankly, they are worth repeating. There was a very clear message sent by the electorate at the federal election. In the first instance, I believe it was a message to both major parties. Secondly, there is absolutely no doubt--and I do not resile from it--that it was a message to Labor. Part of the message was to state Labor and part of that message was to federal Labor.

What is my responsibility? What is the responsibility of my members? It is to be out there listening to people, hearing the message that they want to give us. That is what we will be doing with new programs like ‘walk a day in my shoes’ and others that we will develop over coming weeks. It is equally important, and I say this as the national president of the federal Labor Party, that federal Labor hears what the electorate has to say. I think this does go a little bit to the member for Callide--those who do not listen to these messages, those who are seeking to point fingers at everyone other than themselves, run the risk of not hearing the message the electorate is sending.
Mr Seeney interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!

Ms BLIGH: I do not walk away from the hard, cold facts on this issue and I have not in any way, shape or form. What I do say is that what is important is that we listen, we find new ways of connecting and we redouble our efforts to deliver better services for Queenslanders. In doing that, we will not be resiling from what is a strong economic strategy that will deliver a stronger Queensland--a Queensland with better hospitals, better schools, better roads, better transport; a Queensland that is well equipped for the future; a Queensland that is inoculated to a much larger degree from future economic shocks.
Mr Seeney interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: The member for Callide will cease interjecting.
Mr Schwarten interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: The minister will cease interjecting.

Ms BLIGH: I can only say again that when the electorate speaks as loudly as it did about major parties I think it is important to note that this sort of hubris, this sort of arrogance, this sort of puffery is not in the interests of the democracy that we all serve.
Mr Springborg: What was the message?
Mr SPEAKER: The honourable the Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
Government members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Those on my right will cease interjecting.

Ms BLIGH: I can say that it was not a bursting hunger for the member for Southern Downs! I do not think there is any message along those lines in the result. As we know, they have had their opportunity to speak on that issue and they have spoken loudly three times.
Mr Seeney interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: The member for Callide will cease interjecting.
Ms BLIGH: How many times are you going to warn him?

Mr SPEAKER: Premier, I have not warned him because there are problems on both sides of the House. I have asked for order on both sides of the House. I try to adopt an even approach with this. I am seeking the cooperation of both sides of the House.
Mr PITT: My question is to the Treasurer. Will the Treasurer update the House on initiatives the government has implemented to help diversify and strengthen the economy in Far North Queensland?

Mr FRASER: I thank the member for Mulgrave for his question. He, like all the other members from Cairns, knows that this government has stood square shouldered with the Cairns council, the business leaders of Cairns and government representatives in Cairns to support the Cairns economy in its hour of need. That is why the member for Mulgrave supports the choices that we have made in order to keep funding programs like the Lotus Glen expansion that kept hundreds of people in work; in order to keep funding building projects like William McCormack Place, the new office building, that kept people in work. It is why we have been able to commit to the cruise terminal development down at the wharfs to keep people in work and provide jobs for the future and it is why we have been able to commit to the new arts precinct in Cairns. We have the courage to commit to the jobs and economy of the future. Those are the choices we have made in order to invest in infrastructure and jobs.

When I was in Cairns last week I spoke at the TropLinks conference which aims to gain a slice of the expanding tropical economy, a part that Cairns can play so well into the future. At that conference I was joined by the shadow Treasurer who also supports the notion that the tropical economy represents an opportunity. But that is where the road diverges. That is where we take a different road. Since last Friday the shadow Treasurer has reverted to type. He has gone back to what he has always believed in. He is trying to protest here today, but what did he say on the record back in December 2008--just at the tipping point of the global financial crisis? He said on the record at the ABC, ‘I have indicated to you that some projects will be scrapped.’ The reality is that he has always believed in cutting capital works programs and he is just reverting back to type.

When the shadow Treasurer said last Friday that they are looking to reassess, reassess is the new ‘de-necessary’. He is practising, getting ready for the leadership. We know that he is there trying to muscle. He is trying to pretend that he is new, urbane and enlightened, but he just reverts back to type as a typical tory: there to get his hands on the throat of the Queensland economy; there to take Queensland workers by the scruff of the neck, committed to turfing people off job sites, making sure that they all lose their jobs.

What do you know? The choice is still clear. On that side there are cuts. On this side there are jobs. On that side they are pulling up the Capital Works Program. On this side we are building Queensland’s future. On that side they are saying no to young people trying to get into the labour market for their first job. On this side we put in place projects to give young people a chance to get their first job. On that side there is not a policy, no leadership and no plans for the future. On this side there is an economic plan that has been delivering jobs for 12 straight months; there are the policies and the plans to build a recovery and to deliver jobs. The big difference is that we have a leader who is going to do it.

Mr NICHOLLS: My question is to the Premier. The Premier’s director-general has imposed a ban on the opposition office taking out newspaper advertisements seeking feedback on the government’s privatisation agenda. Given that Labor has announced it will be embarking on a talking and listening offensive to tell Queenslanders that something they do not want and something they detest is actually good for them, can the Premier assure Queenslanders that not one cent of taxpayers’ dollars will be used for this campaign, including her ‘walk a day in my shoes’ campaign?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. I am very happy to have an opportunity to talk again about the advertising provisions for the opposition. Let me just give a little bit of history here. Firstly, this opposition has more resources than any other opposition in Australia and it has the only opportunity of any opposition in Australia to use taxpayer funds to run its advertising. It has been an almost unfettered right, and the opposition abused it and abused it for political purposes.
Mr Nicholls interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Honourable member for Clayfield, you have asked your question. I am hearing the Premier.

Ms BLIGH: It is not that hard to distinguish between material that is party political in nature and other material. It is reasonable in a democracy like ours for the opposition to have access to resources to put forward their policies or to advertise, for example, where they might be as a shadow cabinet. However, the sorts of campaigns that it was expecting the taxpayer to fund were party political from top to bottom. There is no opposition that we can find in the Westminster system anywhere that is funded by taxpayers to do that. The new rules are now in place, and I am happy to table those later today or this week so that everyone can see them. They are consistent with the federal rules and they are there as a recommendation of the Integrity Commissioner.

I would have thought that was a pretty spectacular own goal by the Leader of the Opposition. He had a right that was generally unfettered and he abused it. He abused it to the point where it has now been dragged back to where every other opposition in the rest of the country and in other parts of the Westminster system rightfully is. If the Leader of the Opposition believes that abusing taxpayer funds for party political reasons--
Mr Nicholls interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable member for Clayfield!

Ms BLIGH: In the entire history of our government it has never used taxpayer funds to attack the LNP, to attack a leader of a political party or to in a party political way campaign against another member of parliament. That has never been done by our government and never would be because it is an abuse of taxpayer funds. That is what the LNP expects the Queensland taxpayers to pay for. That is what its party should pay for.

My members will be on a listening offensive. They will be out there communicating. They will be developing new connections. That is their job as members of parliament and that is what they will be doing. I am very thankful for the question.

Mrs KEECH: My question is to the Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology. Can the minister inform the House about a new threat to jobs in the Queensland construction industry?
Mr SCHWARTEN: Yes. The greatest threat sits opposite in this chamber. The old ‘silver spoon from Clayfield’ is the greatest threat to the construction industry.
Mr Nicholls interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The member for Clayfield! You have had a fair go.
Mr SCHWARTEN: The greatest threat is the member for Clayfield. I just pause for a moment to observe--
Opposition members interjected.

Mr SCHWARTEN: Here they go again. Members of the opposition are sticking their chests out like some sort of demented scrub turkey, giggling away like hyenas. You would think they had something to be proud of. You would think the federal election was a great big win for the LNP. Last time I looked--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Resume your seat. I will wait for the House to come to order. Order!

Mr SCHWARTEN: At the moment they are dependent upon a man, whom they have despised in this parliament, by the name of Bob Katter. From the way they have behaved in here this morning, you would think there had been a landslide--judging by the hubris and the arrogance. I heard the shadow Treasurer say this morning ‘when we win the next election’. That is what they believe. They should just keep doing the same as they are doing now.
I will tell them what we are going to do. We are going to get out to every job site in Queensland, as I have been--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SCHWARTEN: My word I have. We have been out to people that the member for Clayfield would never, ever have met. My challenge to him is this: come with me to--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SCHWARTEN: Okay, he’s on. I will take him to the building sites on the Gold Coast. He can stand before 650 members whose jobs depend upon this government--
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The House will come to order.
Mr SCHWARTEN: --and we will stand in front of the people that the opposition intends to put out of work. He can stand in front of those people and say, ‘We are going to reassess your jobs.’
Mr Springborg interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Minister, resume your seat. The honourable the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I have warned you a number of times today. I now warn you under standing order 253A.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I know why they are upset. It is because they do not want to confront building workers in this state with the grim reality of what they intend to do, which is the same as the tories did in 1929, and that is to cut the Capital Works Program and put all those people out of jobs. The 650 on the Gold Coast and the 600 at Maroochydore would all be out of work. In 1996, when I came into this portfolio, there was $500 million worth of capital works frozen, thanks to the people who sit opposite. They have form. I am delighted to take any of them onto a job site. They can stand in front of the BLF, the CFMEU and all those other unions and tell them that they intend to reassess their jobs.

Mr CRIPPS: My question without notice is to the Premier. According to the federal department of employment, when the Premier made her 100,000 full-time breadwinners’ jobs promise, from which she has now backflipped, there were 25,629 long-term unemployed Queenslanders. According to the latest figures, that number has now increased by nearly half, and I table the supporting documentation. What does the Premier have to say to these 37,025 Queenslanders who are suffering from skyrocketing costs of living while the economy falters under her leadership?
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Table of job seekers receiving Newstart Allowance and Youth Allowance (Other) by state [ 2847 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms BLIGH: I am very pleased to at last answer a question on jobs from a side of politics that is remarkably disinterested in them. Firstly, I say to the member who asked the question that this government has in no way walked away from, resiled from or backflipped on our jobs promise. We promised 100,000 jobs and guess what? We are delivering them.
Mr Cripps interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Member for Hinchinbrook, again I warn you under standing order 253A(1). I have asked you several times today, so there will not be a repeat. The next time you are gone.

Ms BLIGH: We are delivering on our jobs promise, we are delivering it ahead of time and we are absolutely determined to continue not only to achieve it but also, if we can, to go beyond it. To those Queenslanders who are still looking for work, to those Queenslanders who are still looking for a job, I say that this government will never, ever sleep on the job when it comes to finding jobs for Queenslanders. We will continue to invest in our building program to create jobs on our work sites. We will continue to invest in our building program so that companies in regional Queensland can keep their heads above water. We will continue to invest in our jobs programs like the Green Army, which are delivering jobs to young people who would be on the scrap heap under those opposite.

We will spend the next 18 months telling every Queenslander that under the LNP they will get job cuts. That has been now confirmed. We now have confirmation from the shadow Treasurer that their economic program will mean cuts. It will mean cuts to the building program and cuts to jobs. Over the next 18 months we will be talking to Queenslanders about jobs. We will be talking to them about how to get jobs, how we can help them, how our government programs will give them a chance to get off the dole queue and we will be telling them that those opposite--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my left will cease interjecting.

Ms BLIGH: We will be telling them in detail how every project they are working on is now under threat, confirmed by the member for Clayfield. He was on the record in December 2008 and he is on the record in 2010. That is their policy and it will put more people--more Queenslanders--on the dole queue.

Mr MOORHEAD: My question is to the Minister for Main Roads. I refer to the $3.3 billion roads budget and I ask the minister to give a guarantee that he will maintain the momentum in rolling out road projects to build a safer and more secure road network and, importantly, to protect the jobs of Queensland’s road workers.

Mr WALLACE: My answer to the member for Waterford is: yes, I can and yes, Labor will. Labor will continue our record capital expenditure on roads and we will continue to employ thousands of Queenslanders across our great state. However, I cannot vouch for the members of parliament opposite. They have the Grim Reaper’s calling card. They want to reassess building projects being rolled out across Queensland. As we heard this morning, the LNP’s chief bean counter has spilled the beans, and we know what that means. It means that important road projects will be put at risk and thousands of road workers will face a very uncertain future, all because the LNP’s infrastructure hit list has been finally revealed.

In the electorate of the member for Gregory, over 40 projects are at risk. I am talking about $6 billion worth of road projects and thousands of jobs in jeopardy. It is time for another road trip, but this time there will be no joy for me because those are the jobs that are at risk. In the Far North, in Cairns, where things are so tough at the moment, $280 million worth of roadworks and 900 jobs are at risk. In North Queensland, in Townsville, $500 million worth of roadworks and 2,000 jobs are at risk. The member for Mount Isa will be interested to know that, in the north-west, a $14 million program and 96 jobs are at risk. In the Wide Bay area, which is a fast growing area of Queensland, $314 million worth of roadworks and 1,800 jobs are at risk by the opposition. In the south-west, 112 jobs are at risk. Members who represent the south-west should speak out in their party room and say that they will stand up for jobs in their electorates.

On the Sunshine Coast, 900 jobs are at risk, but we hear nary a peep from that side. On the Gold Coast, $1 billion worth of roadworks and 3,500 jobs are at risk. Members opposite who represent Gold Coast seats should tell their constituents that 3,500 jobs are at risk from the Leader of the Opposition and his cronies. In the Fitzroy, 1,000 jobs are at risk through their job cuts. This side supports roads, this side supports jobs and I will be standing up for road workers in Queensland.

Mr McLINDON: My question without notice is to the Premier. Will the Premier commit to hosting a bipartisan ideas forum and invite key union leaders, economists, experts and entrepreneurs such as Sir Richard Branson in a genuine effort to prevent the sale of Queensland’s assets?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. When it comes to ideas forums, I am pleased to advise the member for Beaudesert that some time ago the Queensland government funded the Ideas Festival. It happens every two years. It is a very good program and I encourage him to look at it and to be a part of it.

In relation to asset sales, firstly, the last time I looked Richard Branson owned a private airline; he does not run a public airline. He also owns a private railway. In fact, he may be a good speaker to talk about private investment into transport as a very good way forward. If Richard Branson were here, I think he would say that one of the biggest impediments to his company doing well and employing more people is government owned airlines, which still operate in some parts of the world and which are unfair in the competitive market. Not for one minute do I worry about Richard Branson talking to us about these things.

What we hear from the member’s question and what we hear from those opposite is that in our budget deliberations we should engage in a process that would effectively remove our obligation to govern. Let us look at asset sales in recent history. When the Hawke and Keating federal Labor government decided to embark on a program of asset sales for assets such as Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank, they did not put it to a referendum; they governed. They did not take it to an election. They faced the financial circumstances they encountered and they governed. When Rob Borbidge and Joan Sheldon were elected, they did not take the privatisation of Suncorp Metway, the state bank of Queensland, to the election as an election commitment. They did not take it to a referendum. They dealt with the financial circumstances with which they were faced and they governed. Under John Howard the privatisation of Telstra was not the subject of a public summit or a referendum. He dealt with the circumstances he found himself in and he governed. He then went to the people and the people judged, as they did with Hawke and Keating, and as they did with Borbidge and Sheldon. When Peter Beattie privatised the TAB, he did not take it to an election and he did not put it to a referendum; he governed, because that is what he needed to do.

Our government faced the financial circumstances and did what every other government on all sides of politics has done. We made the decisions and we are governing. That was the mandate that we were given in March last year and that is what we have the strength to do. On this issue our record is identical to every other government faced with similar circumstances and our financial strategy, our budget, is not open to some sort of talkfest. That is not how you govern.
Mrs ATTWOOD: My question is to the Minister for Education and Training. Could the minister please update the House on new school infrastructure projects being delivered in Queensland?
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable the minister, you have two minutes.

Mr WILSON: I thank the honourable member for the question. Unlike the Liberal National Party, the Bligh government is committed to building world-class infrastructure--buildings and new facilities--for our young people, our apprentices and our trainees. That is why our $850 million SSOT program is continuing, as well as $500 million a year into the non-state school sector, $2.1 billion into new schools and school facilities from the BER program and $60 million into the solar program. Imagine my astonishment to hear that the shadow Treasurer has said that they are going to review all of the building programs. We now know that that is the mask for cuts--building program cuts. The razor gang is out.

I want to know whether the member for Clayfield, as shadow Treasurer, has written to his electorate telling them, for example, that the Eagle Junction State School’s $3 million new resource centre will be gone; the Ascot State School’s $3 million classroom program, gone; the Aviation High’s redevelopment program, gone; Kedron State High School’s $2 million language program, gone. Why don’t they stand up for state schools and for education and training? They stand, however, in contrast to this side of the House, for cuts to the building program, for cuts to jobs. It is in their DNA. If we go back to 1995, that is when they did it. They said it before the 2009 election, and they have said it again. They stand for cuts, cuts and cuts. They have no education policy and no building program. We have, in stark contrast to them, a real plan for the future--an economic plan--real policies and a real leader for Queensland.

Mr SPEAKER: Order!
The time for question time has ended.
