XML.Hansard-Body: Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (11.32 am): Today we have seen the technique of the Premier and this government. What we are going to see in the lead-up to the next election is a scare campaign about cuts. That is all they have. They have tried it before, just as Julia Gillard and federal Labor tried to do it about Work Choices. But they could not con the Australian public and neither will this government be able to con the people of Queensland again.

The Premier in her last answer to a question from the member for Beaudesert literally said that she justified the stance on privatisation. This is a desperate attempt to stave off her political assassination. She tried to have us believe that there was no discussion about privatisation and no discussion about leadership at yesterday’s caucus meeting. In fact, once again there was a very clever use of words between her and her parliamentary secretary to analyse what was said. That is what the Premier has tried to be so clever about.

Last week the Premier claimed to have a mandate to govern. That is not what Queenslanders think. I ask honourable members: was there a mandate to sell Queensland Rail? No. Was there a mandate to sell off the ports? No. Was there a mandate to hike up the cost of power, water, rego, land rents, tolls and petrol? No. Was there a mandate to mislead, deceive and betray Queenslanders? No, there was not. Queensland Labor lost its mandate long ago.

The mandate disappeared when the spineless and witless caucus members condoned the wholesale deception that followed the last state election. They are the words of the Treasurer, the member for Mount Coot-tha, speaking about his own members in the Labor caucus. He called them spineless and witless. The mandate disappeared when the sycophantic, submissive and obsequious Labor caucus last night erased for all time any memory of a mandate from Queenslanders by yet again ignoring them. They say they are listening. They say they are hearing. But in the same breath we hear the Premier saying that she is not going to change anything.

Labor members will not stand up for their electorates. Labor members will not stand up for the rank and file. Labor members have not kept the promises made to Queenslanders. Labor is the party of the timid, the treacherous and the tactless. Labor is hopelessly divided, and it leaves Queenslanders without hope. Labor is internally at war. Yet those who protest the loudest in their electorates come into this place and do as they are told. As I said, in the words of the Treasurer, he called them spineless and witless. He is so charming. I note that he is not here today with his normal charming interjections.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable Leader of the Opposition, I have ruled before that you will not refer to a member who is absent. There may be good reasons why they are absent.

Mr LANGBROEK: I apologise, Mr Speaker. These sorts of utterances about his own side show why Queenslanders cannot stand the Treasurer almost as much as they cannot abide the Premier. Two-thirds of his own electorate in Mount Coot-tha do not vote for him. What about the honourable member for Murrumba, who I see here today, described as spineless and witless, or the member for Bundamba, or the member for Mundingburra, or the member for Keppel, or the member for Brisbane Central, or the member for Sunnybank? It does not matter who the Labor Party leader is. Queenslanders know that the Labor Party MPs are responsible for deceiving them.

The federal election result in Queensland was a wake-up call to the Premier and the Labor Party. The LNP performance was greater than in any other state, with a swing of over 5.6 per cent and eight seats changing hands, including the long-time Labor held seat of Brisbane. The Labor vote in Queensland collapsed by nine per cent and that should come as no surprise.

On polling day before I went to my electorate I was at polling booths in Townsville. Union members were turning up and refusing ALP how-to-vote cards. One bloke was wearing a CFMEU shirt proclaiming on his shirt, ‘Qld not for sale.’ That said it very succinctly. ‘You sold us out,’ he told the ALP booth workers as he walked past, and he told me to keep up the good work. He was a lifetime Labor voter, yet he voted for the LNP because Queensland Labor has deceived him. I am determined that those people who voted for the LNP at the federal election will do it for the second time at the next state election.

There may be a change in the leadership of the Labor Party after the disastrous result in Queensland, but the problem is that Bill Ludwig will decide who is the leader, just as he and his union decided that it was time for Kevin Rudd to go. He decided that Julia Gillard would be Prime Minister and he will decide who replaces Anna Bligh. Labor can change the parliamentary leader, but it is the same old faceless union leaders who will decide who the replacement is. Big Bill Ludwig gets the final say on who leads the Labor Party, just as factional union heavies like Karl Bitar and Paul Howes knifed a sitting Prime Minister, ignoring the rights of the electorate to pass judgement on a hopeless and hapless federal Labor government.

Of course now we have a former union leader, the member for Brisbane Central--another one of the spineless and witless, according to the member for Mount Coot-tha--running around trying to get the numbers together for the ABA ticket--anyone but Anna. That is right. The member for Brisbane Central has looked at the booth results. She knows what is coming--baseball bats. But she is only interested now that it is her job on the line. She was not interested when it was the jobs of thousands of her former workmates on the line. There is only one number that the member for Brisbane Central needs and that is big Bill Ludwig’s. Get on the blower to big Bill if you want to knock off the most unpopular Premier in Queensland’s history.

It does not matter how unpopular the Premier is with Queenslanders. That is not what counts. The survival of the Premier comes down to how popular she is with Bill Ludwig. Labor members are too spineless and witless to do anything about it unless Bill Ludwig gives them the okay. If he told them to go picking water lilies in the Brisbane River, they would be over there doing it, led by Paul Lucas. I bet he is getting plenty of attention these days. His phone must be running hot with the Premier and the spineless and witless pretenders to the throne--and of course the numbers woman from Brisbane Central--all trying to impress the one-man selection panel for Labor Premier. Whoever takes over from the Premier will have voted for the sale of Queensland Rail, the ports, the forestry and the motorways. Whoever is chosen by Bill Ludwig to knock off the member for South Brisbane will have been at the cabinet table or nearby when they decided to betray the trust of Queenslanders.

No matter who leads the Queensland Labor Party, Queenslanders know they cannot be trusted. No matter who leads the Queensland Labor Party, they too have sold Queenslanders out. No matter who leads Queensland Labor, they have endorsed the huge rises in water, power, rego, tolls and charges. No matter who leads Queensland Labor, they gave us a fuel tax when they promised not to before the election. No matter who leads Queensland Labor, they too have been up to their ears in the deception, dishonesty and deceit played out on honest, decent, hardworking Queensland families.

Queensland Labor can no longer claim to be the party of the worker. It is the party of George Street carpet strollers who have never had a proper job. It is the party of union hacks who have made careers out of impeding private enterprise. That is what they are afraid of. Those opposite do not understand it. They have never filled out a business activity statement. They are only good at spending other people’s money.

Queensland Labor is the party of high taxes, high charges and extremely low standards. It is the party of debt, deficit and deceit. It is the party of arrogance, hubris and conceit. It is the party of spineless and witless MPs, so detached from reality that they have repeatedly sold out their heartland. It is time that those opposite realised that Queenslanders have had enough of Queensland Labor.

They deserve better. Only an LNP government can deliver a better Queensland and a fairer go for them and their families. Queensland families know the only party that really cares about them and understands how difficult it is to manage a budget with all of Labor’s cost of living increases is the LNP. The LNP is the only party that will look after families. The LNP is the only party that will get business moving again. The LNP is the only party that will bring state costs and charges under control. The LNP is the only party that can turn the Queensland economy around to make this state the best performing once again. The LNP is the only party that can get back the AAA credit rating and restore Queensland economic creditability. The LNP, in contrast to the Premier who just wants to embark on a scare campaign that will not work again, is the only party that can deliver a fresh approach, a new vision and a prosperous future for Queensland.

The message for the spineless and witless Labor MPs opposite is clear. Queenslanders do not care who they choose to replace their current lame duck leader. Labor lame ducks are all the same. For the next state election Queenslanders have put Labor duck on the menu. In the meantime, we are going to keep working in the LNP to provide a new, fresh and strong vision for the people of Queensland and say that politics can and will be different. We will say things before an election that we will stick to afterwards. We will get rid of the cynicism about politics. The message for Labor is clear: the people of Queensland are waiting for them and they have had enough.

Ms FARMER (Bulimba--ALP) (11.42 am): On the first Sunday in August the remaining two lanes of the Sir Leo Hielscher Bridge opened to traffic. This is a milestone in the Bligh Labor government’s $2.5 billion upgrade of the Gateway corridor. It means that traffic is now flowing on all six southbound lanes of the new bridge.

The Gateway Upgrade Project is Australia’s largest road and bridge project. Since it opened its effect has been, and will increasingly be, to slash travel times and ease congestion for thousands of busy motorists who use the bridge every day. It means less time spent in traffic and more time for commuters to go about their business. Every extra lane of this project means an extra 1,400 vehicles an hour can cross the river.

A major revamp of the northbound lanes of the Sir Leo Hielscher Bridge is expected to be completed by the end of the year. By that time motorists will have 12 lanes across the river--six northbound and six southbound. This will be achieved six months ahead of schedule. When all the Gateway works are completed by mid next year motorists will save up to 20 minutes on a trip from Nudgee in the north to the Pacific Motorway in the south.

This project and all its aspects is not just about easing traffic congestion in our rapidly growing region and slashing travel times for the 200,000 motorists expected to drive across it every day. It is not just about planning for and managing growth. In the bigger picture, it has been about jobs for Queenslanders. It has been about generating jobs for workers in road construction and related industries at a time when jobs and job security are more important than ever--creating in its time between 5,000 and 6,000 direct and indirect jobs for workers.

Quite simply, the completion of the Gateway Upgrade Project will mark the delivery of one of the many vital infrastructure projects that are underway across Queensland as a result of this government’s responsible economic management of the worst financial crisis in the last 70 years. The Gateway Upgrade Project is one of the major tranches of the government’s $18 billion infrastructure program--a plan which the government has been determined to complete, despite strong opposition from the LNP, to make sure Queensland is ready for the future. The program has been put in place to serve the growing needs of our state and has provided much needed stimulus to our economy.

Implementing it has not been easy. The global financial crisis affected every economy around the world. The crisis cost the Queensland economy $15 billion in future income--a loss that would have effectively stopped vital works like the Gateway Upgrade Project unless funds could be found from other sources, though this is the action the opposition tells us we should have taken.

The government’s infrastructure and jobs plan is working. According to the July ABS data, Queensland had locked in its 12th straight month of jobs growth. It has now led the nation in jobs growth for the last four months. In July, 5,600 new jobs were created in Queensland. That was more than a third of the nation’s total jobs growth of 16,700. Delivering 12 months straight jobs growth shows the Queensland economy is headed in the right direction. We are yet another step closer to creating the 100,000 net new jobs that we promised at the last election. The jobs target is now down to 38,800, meaning a net total number of jobs of 61,200 have been created since the promise was made by the government.

The Bligh Labor government is about jobs. That is why it was particularly distressing to have heard the comments of the opposition Treasury spokesmen, the member for Clayfield, about what the LNP thinks about the infrastructure projects we have put in place to create and protect jobs. The member for Clayfield made it clear that if the LNP wins government at the next election it will reassess these building projects.

The member for Surfers Paradise just tried to tell us that the LNP is the only party that can look after families. I suppose that if the LNP was reassessing building projects then that would have meant the Gateway Upgrade Project would have been looked at as well. If it knocked that project back then I would like to know what it would have said to the families of the almost 6,000 people who had jobs as a result of this massive project. I would like to know what it would have said to families of the people who have benefited from the flow-on effect into the local economy of the project of about $450 million in wages and salaries.

The Bligh Labor government knows that times are tough for people. What it also knows is that there is no better way to help a family deal with its finances than giving it a job. In tough economic times we need to build projects, not cut them, to build strong economies and protect jobs. That is what the state Labor government has done and will continue to do.

Anna Bligh has got a tough job and she is doing a great job. I congratulate the Premier on her ambitious plan to make sure Queenslanders have jobs. I thank her for her commitment to a strong future for our state.

Mr MOORHEAD (Waterford--ALP) (11.47 am): The Bligh Labor government is dedicated to giving the families of Logan a helping hand when they need it most. This promise is being delivered with the Helping Out Families initiative. Along with Desley Scott and Margaret Keech, I was delighted to join the Minister for Community Services, Karen Struthers, and the Minister for Child Safety, Phil Reeves, in launching the initiative in Logan and Beenleigh.

The launch was appropriately located at the Beenleigh Community Health Centre at Mount Warren Park. The Beenleigh Community Health Centre is the base for Beenleigh’s child health program within Queensland Health and a team of child health nurses. These are the same child health nurses who will be the key to the Bligh government’s Helping Out Families initiative.

At the moment, parents of newborn children are given the opportunity to attend child health clinics at local hospitals and community health facilities. The Bligh government’s commitment to improving these services to families in Logan is clear. Mothers and newborn babies will now receive up to six visits from nurses based at facilities like the Beenleigh Community Health Centre. Parents and children who are identified as needing extra support can access up to 15 child health nurse visits.

The initiative also follows through with parents who need extra help by providing support from the Family Support Alliance services through non-government organisations such as the Benevolent Society and Lifeline. These organisations will provide intensive support to families when they need it most. This support will include practical in-home support such as assistance with parenting, home management, budgeting and meal preparation as well as visits from health workers. Families will also benefit from help in life management skills, individual and family counselling and, if they need it, specialist services.

This is a $55 million investment in strengthening families and giving Logan and Beenleigh children a flying start. It means that we can focus on developing the great potential of every child rather than having to react through our child protection system in the worst cases.

This is the type of investment the LNP will cut. It cannot claim to support families and then oppose important spending initiatives like this. These are initiatives that invest in our future. I know that every parent in my area wants the best for their children, but sometimes parents need a helping hand in one of the greatest responsibilities of life--raising children in a safe and supportive environment. The Bligh government is looking over the horizon with strategies that build a long-term future for our state. As well as building roads, hospitals and schools, we are building stronger families and stronger homes through early intervention programs. This is the fair thing and smart thing to do for the future of our state. It simply makes common sense to give parents the support they need at the earliest stage of a child’s development. Every parent wants to raise their children to their best ability, but some parents may not have the support networks around them that they need.

When I have discussed initiatives like this with parents at my local schools, parents have told me that there has traditionally been a gap in family support between the end of child health clinics and the commencement of kindergarten programs. With the Helping Out Families initiative, the Bligh government is now trialling a program that provides families with opportunities for seamless family support from birth, through early childhood to kindergarten and beyond. The Bligh government’s commitment to early childhood does not end with this initiative. We have committed to funding levels of the Kent Street community kindergarten with the introduction of the new funding program for kindergartens. We have also seen four of the Bligh government’s 240 new kindergartens announced locally, with kindergarten services coming to Meadowbrook and Waterford and two kindergartens at Logan Reserve State School.

On top of an extra year of prep schooling introduced in 2007, Logan families will see a rollout of kindergarten education opportunities for children in the year before prep. This government is investing in the things that matter for our future. Taxpayer funds investing in early childhood support and education means long-term savings and a brighter economic future for our state. It means Queensland will be a state that is supporting families to develop Queenslanders who are prepared for the jobs of the 21st century. This government is not only delivering jobs to Queensland through these tough economic times but also ensuring there are jobs for generations of Queenslanders to come.

Dr FLEGG (Moggill--LNP) (11.52 am): Recently we saw the release of the Orgill report--the interim report by the implementation task force into the Building the Education Revolution program--and it could be best described as damning. The BER program was implemented by the Rudd government for the stated purpose of stimulating the economy, yet in the interim report we find that 40 per cent of Queensland’s projects are yet to begin--two years after the global financial crisis for which this was supposedly part of the solution. Perhaps the Queensland government is holding back its economic stimulus. At the same time as we see the Reserve Bank ramping up interest rates to try to slow the Australian economy, the Queensland government is holding its projects in reserve.
Mr WILSON: I rise to a point of order. What the member says is untrue. I find it offensive and I ask for him to withdraw it. The Queensland government is not holding back its program.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order! That is enough, Minister. Member for Moggill, you have been asked for a retraction.
Dr FLEGG: I was not aware that I made any personal reflection, but I withdraw if I did, Mr Deputy Speaker.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: No, you will unreservedly withdraw.
Dr FLEGG: I withdraw.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Thank you.
Dr FLEGG: I note that the minister is here in the House with us now, and I would lay down the challenge to him: is he going to--
Mr WILSON: I rise to a point of order.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Member for Moggill, please take your seat. Minister, the point of order?
Dr Flegg: Can we pause the clock, please, Mr Deputy Speaker?
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order!
Dr Flegg: This is deliberate time wasting!
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Member for Moggill! Minister.

Mr WILSON: I find what the member has said has created an inference that is personally insulting. I ask him to withdraw it. The inference was that I was not in the House when he started his speech. I have been in the House from the outset.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: He has asked for a withdrawal.
Dr FLEGG: That is a load of rubbish, Mr Deputy Speaker! There is no such inference.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Member for Moggill, take your seat, please.
Dr Flegg: Can we pause the clock?

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Member for Moggill, take your seat. I will seek advice. The second point of order will not be taken as a point of order. The member for Moggill has the call and I ask him to resume.

Dr FLEGG: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I challenge the minister in this place to address the recommendations of this report--a report funded by his own federal Labor government. The first of those recommendations, headed ‘Immediate actions’, states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In the interest of transparency and public accountability, the Taskforce recommends that each education authority publish school specific project cost data related to BER P21 in a nationally common structure with consistent definitions.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is something that this government has consistently refused to do, and one of the reasons such a massive amount of money has been wasted out of education in this state is that it will not look at the costings of individual projects. The task force recommends further measures: that school stakeholders should be given more say in the decisions, that they should be using a business-as-usual approach to saving money and that they should save some money out of the exorbitant fees they are charging and put them back into school building projects.

The task force also criticised governments for using BER money for backlogged maintenance and refurbishment. I note that in Queensland we paid an average of $2,829 a square metre in the public system to build these school halls when the Queensland Catholic system was able to build similar projects for $1,789--figures that this minister has constantly refused to supply for the people of Queensland.

While talking about school building projects, I note that EQ did a study on the Broadbeach State School because it wanted to get its hands on a valuable three-hectare waterfront site and examined selling it off to a developer and then housing our children in a 50-storey high-rise as an experiment. This is a broke government to look at things like this. We do not want experiments with the children of Queensland stuffed into 50-storey high-rises instead of schools!

Ms JARRATT (Whitsunday--ALP) (11.58 am): Nothing is more important than our health, and as a government we spend more money on health care than any other portfolio area. The Bligh government commits nearly one-quarter of the state’s annual budget to ensure that our health system meets the public’s expectation of immediate expert medical attention for every individual in the state. As part of this record spending program more doctors, nurses and allied health staff are being employed by Queensland Health, and this strategy is already paying off. We now have some of the shortest elective surgery waiting lists in the country and our throughput in emergency departments is climbing every year.

We are also spending unprecedented money in this state to build and redevelop our hospitals. For example, Mackay Base Hospital is the beneficiary of a $405 million redevelopment that is occurring as we speak. Importantly, the Mackay Base Hospital redevelopment is not a piece of planning pulled out of the top drawer of Queensland Health; it is a response to a process of community consultation and a clinical services plan that ensures that it will meet the needs of the community tomorrow and into the future.

The Mackay Base Hospital redevelopment is just one of numerous hospital renewal projects occurring across the length and breadth of this state but, despite this enormous focus, Queenslanders remain among the most unhealthy people in the nation due largely to the prevalence of chronic disease. More than one-third of all deaths in Queensland are the result of chronic disease such as heart failure, stroke, respiratory disease, diabetes and kidney disease. An estimated seven in every 10 patients seen by a GP have at least one chronic disease and chronic disease is largely preventable.

It is little wonder then that, in drawing up the Toward Q2: Tomorrow’s Queensland document that sets out our goals for a better future, prevention of chronic disease is embedded in the goal to make Queenslanders the healthiest people in the nation. It is an enormous task, but the benefits of tackling chronic diseases are that, ultimately, it will save the government money, save the community lost production and reduce the pain and suffering of thousands of people.

Therefore, I was understandably excited to discover recently that the focus on chronic disease management and prevention is alive and well in my own community. Last week I attended a community and hospital interface education forum at the Proserpine Hospital to hear firsthand how Queensland Health staff are working to reduce the human impacts of chronic disease through both inpatient and outpatient services. Often the first contact with a person suffering from a chronic health problem is when they present at the emergency ward in an acute condition. Of course, the hospital has a well-established inpatient response program for dealing with the pointy end of cardiac-pulmonary issues. The real work, however, often starts after the acute phase has been managed and a program of rehabilitation is designed for the patient. The real message in this speech is that you do not have to wait until you are admitted in an acute condition to access help. The rehabilitation and chronic disease programs are available at any time to anyone who would benefit from participation.

The programs largely focus on addressing lifestyle issues, including exploring healthy attitudes to eating, developing physical activity goals, managing stress and making long-term behavioural changes to support healthy lifestyles. That is not rocket science, you say, but the best bit is that most of these programs are group activities. So as well as realising you are not Robinson Crusoe in dealing with chronic disease, you are also provided with an additional opportunity for social network which, for some people, will have benefits well beyond the formal program time frame. Although the programs are serious in addressing the impacts of chronic diseases, some of the content is a lot of fun. Take the Tai Chi lessons, for instance. This is a great way to address issues such as stress reduction, fall prevention, arthritis relief and relaxation, but it is also a great way to meet people and address the issues of social isolation.

We know that the incidence of type 2 diabetes is greater among men than it is in women. So the hospital offers a program called Pit Stop that is designed specially to appeal to men by being delivered within a framework that they can relate to. This program can be delivered in the workplace and uses the analogy of a car receiving a service to explain how we can look after our bodies by understanding its needs and the appropriate responses.

We have been very lucky to have benefited from great leadership at the Proserpine Hospital. We now welcome a local doctor, Dr Shaun Grimes, to the position of director of medical services. One of Dr Grimes’s first actions has been to establish a regular program of community and hospital interface education sessions like the one I attended last week. These sessions are aimed at educating the community about the services provided by the hospital and to hear back from the community. It is a great idea and I encourage everyone in the Proserpine district to become better informed by attending these sessions.

Mr SEENEY (Callide--LNP) (12.03 pm): This morning we heard that, after 12 years, the Labor government is finally going to start listening. Its new policy approach is to start listening to the people of Queensland. It has taken the government a long time to listen to the people of the Surat and Bowen basins who have been affected by the development of the coal seam gas industry in those areas. But finally the government and the minister are starting to get the basics in place. This morning in the parliament we saw the minister patting himself on the back for finally starting to get the basics in place that that industry needs to be the success that it should be for the people of that region and for the people of Queensland generally.

I refer to measures such as the move to protect the best of the best of our agricultural land. The strategic cropping framework that the minister announced last week should have been announced last year. It is at least 12 months overdue. Certainly, it is welcomed by all of the stakeholders, but had it been introduced in a timely way, had the government understood the issues surrounding the industry, had the government listened to the concerns that were expressed by all industry stakeholders, all community leaders and all members in this parliament who represent that area, then a lot of the angst and a lot of the concern could have been avoided.

Similarly, the resource reform package that was announced last week by the minister recognised that the government has a role--a role that I pointed out to the minister at the estimates committee hearings, a role that I have pointed out consistently to the government--and that there is a very big difference between administering an industry such as this on the Darling Downs and the more traditional resource extraction areas of the Cooper Basin and the north-west minerals province. The reform package that the minister put in place allocates 20 staff to the area to respond to groundwater and environmental complaints. As I said to the minister at the estimates committee hearing, the government needs to have boots on the ground--it needs to have people in the field. Once again, although this initiative is welcomed, it is long overdue. It is two years overdue and a lot of angst and a lot of community concern could have been avoided.

Similarly, with the coal seam gas consultative committees, it was obvious from day one that the communities in these areas needed to be involved. They needed to have information. They needed to have confidence. They needed to be able to address issues in a consultative way. Finally, the government has put in place the consultative committees that, once again, should have been in place for a long time. As I said in the parliament during the last sitting week, the new land access laws that finally passed through this parliament last week were similarly long overdue.

But the debate now has to turn to the other issues that have not yet been addressed--the issues of dealing with the massive development, the growth, the population increase and the economic activity that will come with the development of this export industry. Those regions of Queensland deserve to have the infrastructure in place before a crisis develops. They deserve to have a government that will foresee the need for basic infrastructure and ensure that that infrastructure is in place in those communities before the demand that this industry will bring develops on the ground.

The coal seam gas industry provides an enormous opportunity for communities that have done it hard for decades, for areas of Queensland that have struggled economically for a long time, to build a bright economic future for generations to come. But it will take a government with foresight and planning to ensure that the people in those communities--those people who live in those regional areas and the people who will move to those regional areas--have the infrastructure and the services that other Queenslanders take for granted. Simple things like the construction of roads, hospitals and schools should be addressed now. The Warrego Highway--the main access road--is an absolute disgrace. The Dawson Highway from Gladstone is not much better. It is an indictment on this government that it is years behind in planning and developing that infrastructure, just as it was behind in planning and delivering the administrative regulation that was required to make the industry a success.

The government has released the Surat Basin future directions statement. It is long on rhetoric but very short on detail. The government needs to be working with the communities in the Surat and Bowen basins to ensure that the coal seam gas industry provides the economic future that it has the potential to and that it ensures that the people in those regions can take full advantage of this industry and can use the industry to build their communities, to build their economic base for generations to come.

Mr CHOI (Capalaba--ALP) (12.08 pm): I welcome the announcement by the Premier this morning of her government’s plan for a rail revolution in South-East Queensland. According to the Premier, South-East Queensland’s passenger rail capacity will nearly triple by 2031 under our new $123 billion transport blueprint. This is fantastic news. Connecting SEQ 2031: An integrated regional transport plan for South East Queensland maps a clear way forward for transport in our region. This plan also includes duplication of the track from Manly to Cleveland and a plan to run an express train from Cleveland to Manly. I would encourage everybody to have their say on this plan.

The Cleveland train line services the Redland city region with stations at Thorneside, Birkdale, Ormiston, Wellington Point and, of course, Cleveland. The Cleveland train line is the third busiest on the TransLink train network just behind Caboolture and Ipswich. With the high demand for public transport in my electorate, I will continue to lobby for public transport services. That is why I welcome the recent announcement of doubling the carriages for the 7.55 am service from Cleveland to the city.

I know that the opposition will say that this is only a plan and it takes too long. This is a major expenditure of mammoth proportions and no-one, irrespective of their political colour, can implement this project without a plan and long-term financial commitment. This $123 billion project cannot and will not be built overnight. I welcome the Premier’s announcement of this forward-thinking plan. I look forward to discussing this fantastic initiative with my constituents.

I catch the train into the city a few times a month. From Birkdale station it is not a short trip; it takes about 40 minutes. However, it can be an extremely productive 40 minutes and can provide some quiet time. That is why I welcome the recent announcement by the Minister for Transport that commuters will be able to enjoy a more peaceful journey to and from work with the launch of a three-month quiet carriage trial on South-East Queensland train services. The trial was a result of customer feedback regarding quiet areas. Commuters have been telling us that they would like quiet areas on trains. This government is listening, and the trial is a direct response to commuter feedback. During the trial, the last carriage of all train services will be a designated quiet carriage. The trial initiative will allow commuters to read a book, work on a laptop or simply enjoy a quiet atmosphere while travelling to and from work. Of course, for the trial to be successful it relies on commuters respecting the guidelines of the quiet carriages. The trial of quiet carriages will be held on all South-East Queensland services until 22 November.

This government has a good record of building things and a good record of delivering on public transport plans. The state government is undertaking the biggest upgrade of South-East Queensland train stations since services began in the 1960s, with $200 million allocated to undertake upgrades to almost one-third of train stations right across South-East Queensland. Part of this allocation of funds and commitment to station upgrades includes park-and-ride upgrades in the Redland region.

I was pleased to hear that work on the $465 million Eastern Busway stage 2 is now three months ahead of schedule, with the project due for completion late next year instead of early 2012. While the project seems a way from Capalaba, cutting down inner-city congestion can shave 10 minutes from a trip in and out of the city, and I hope that the rest of the busway can be progressed as smoothly and as quickly as possible. I call on the federal government, irrespective of who takes office in the next few days, to assist the state in funding the Eastern Busway.

On the topic of public transport, the LNP must explain to the people of the Redlands which projects it will cut after the opposition Treasury spokesperson let the cat out of the bag yesterday about their intentions. He told ABC Radio that the LNP plans to reassess projects. Which project will it cut? It will probably want to cut the construction of the new park-and-ride facility in Capalaba--a $3.4 million commitment--let alone commit to making any plans for the future. The LNP is choosing to subsidise multinational coal companies’ profits over protecting Queensland jobs and building better schools, hospitals and public transport systems. While those opposite continue to squabble, we are planning for Queensland’s future and will continue to deliver public transport infrastructure and protect jobs that the other side wants to cut.

Mr ELMES (Noosa--LNP) (12.13 pm): On 22 July, during DERM’s estimates deliberations, the acting minister tabled stage 1 of the Fraser Island Dingo Population Study. This is yet another attempt by this discredited department to sanitise and cover up its neglect. Fraser Island is loved by all those who have visited there, and even those who have not know and understand that it is a special place. It is relatively untouched by introduced species of plants or animals. It has high recreation values for walkers, four-wheel drive enthusiasts, fishermen, naturalists and conservationists. It is the home of about 100 locals, yet it is visited by 380,000 tourists a year whose stay on the island is, on average, four nights. That is an enormous strain on a fragile ecosystem.

Earlier this year, with Ted Sorensen, the member for Hervey Bay, I released a discussion paper on Fraser Island so I could not just understand the difficulties facing the island but also start putting together solutions for its future. I have come to understand that this state department, the administrator of the island, is at best incompetent and at worst duplicitous in overseeing the systematic destruction of our native dog. Section 16(1)(a) of the Nature Conservation Act 1992 states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (a) protect the area’s exceptional scientific values and, in particular--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (i) to ensure that the processes of nature continue unaffected in the area; and
(ii) to protect the area’s biological diversity to the greatest possible extent
XML.Hansard-Body: The department at best rates a D minus when compared against what should be its bible, the Nature Conservation Act. We have finally seen the introduction of tag-along tours, yet this proposal was first put to government around 10 years ago. How many accidents and deaths could have been avoided? The island’s water quality continues to be degraded due to human activity. Both human waste and chemicals from suncreams affect some of the perched lakes, while human waste and rubbish left in the bush behind camping areas along the beach at Indian Head and elsewhere have become a pollution and health problem.

By far the greatest discussion point has been the fate of the dingo population. There are many representatives on my side of the parliament who come from rural areas and who have little love for the dingo. I understand their views. Overwhelmingly, mainland dingoes have interbred with domestic dogs so, with one possible exception, the only remaining pure strain of our native dog exists on Fraser Island. Instead of being concerned about their survival, we have a department engaged in the ruthless and cruel--some would say deliberate--destruction of the species.

The report released by the acting minister during estimates refers to 97 dingoes being removed from the database because of their known deaths--the report says from a variety of causes. I can inform the House, because I have read and seen nearly all of the autopsy reports, that the causes of death include lethal injection, shot, run over, poisoned, starvation and others. One autopsy lists under possible cause of death ‘rifle-itis’, while another states ‘half an ounce of hot lead’. Labor’s interim report shows happy snaps of a dingo family, dingoes on the beach, dingoes frolicking in the water, a dingo running up the beach with a fish in its mouth. On a normal day, those dingoes would be hazed by rangers--that is, shot with a clay pellet, moving them away from the beach and away from their main food source.

The battle for Fraser Island is now being fought in the media. We have a state government peddling information, which it still considers credible, that goes back to 1990. A couple of weeks ago we saw a stage-managed tour for journalists. The result? A sanitised, all-is-well-in-paradise image relayed to the general public. By contrast, we have a small but growing group--some islanders, some from the Save the Fraser Island Dingo organisation, Indigenous people and long-term visitors--all dedicated to the island who are systematically ignored, harassed and belittled. In one case there was a legalised home invasion, the circumstances around which, if it happened when we were in government, we would see protesters in the street. It is strange how silent those protectors of our democracy have become.

The Queensland government ignores its responsibilities. That is why I have taken steps to ensure that UNESCO, the organisation charged with overseeing World Heritage listed areas, has been advised of the island’s plight. It is now a matter of whatever it takes. Ted Sorensen and I, and those who want to save Fraser Island, will battle on until we change the government. I table the report.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Document titled ‘Report: Fraser Island Discussion Paper, Glen Elmes MP, August 2010’ [ 2860 ].
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr RYAN (Morayfield--ALP)
(12.18 pm): I rise to inform the House about a new website that will help Queenslanders access the rebates and concessions on offer from both the Queensland government and the federal government. The new Every Dollar Counts website is a one-stop shop for state and federal government concessions and makes it even easier for people to access the cost-of-living subsidies that they are eligible for. The Every Dollar Counts website is an initiative of the Queensland Labor government and is just another way that this Labor government is helping Queenslanders. Along with its nation-leading $1.3 billion concession program, this Labor government is providing real assistance to Queenslanders who need a helping hand.

The Every Dollar Counts website hosts a comprehensive guide to concessions, retail discounts, rebates and assistance packages that are available to families, pensioners and Queenslanders. As you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, Queensland has one of the broadest concession, rebates and discount programs in Australia and, accordingly, this website will help Queenslanders know which concessions and rebates are available to them. For instance, people buying their first home, saving for a rental bond, wanting to save money on their electricity bill, investing in solar panels or visiting some of our great museums, galleries or parks, should visit the Every Dollar Counts website. I encourage all Queenslanders to visit www.qld.gov.au/everydollarcounts or phone 131304 to find out what concessions and assistance are available to them from the Queensland Labor government.

The effects of the global financial crisis are still rippling through our community and this Labor government knows that people are still doing it tough. That is why this government is committed to one of the broadest concession programs in the nation and is also committed to keeping pressure down on cost-of-living issues. People in this House have heard me talk about my passion and commitment to the concept of a safety net, that principle of looking after people who are vulnerable, marginalised and disadvantaged in our community. Governments cannot be all things to all people, but we can certainly provide a helping hand where we can. This is one way that this Queensland Labor government is delivering that helping hand for Queenslanders.

Queenslanders will be interested to hear that there is a broad range of concessions and rebates available to eligible people. In fact, the range of concessions and rebates available to eligible Queenslanders is so extensive that many people will be surprised by the amount of information contained on the Every Dollar Counts website. I would like to run through some of those wonderful rebates and concessions which are available to Queenslanders and are listed on the Every Dollar Counts website. Some of those rebates and concessions were increased in the recent state budget and I would like to touch on them as well.

For instance, the increase to the electricity rebate of up to $216 each year for eligible pensioners and seniors is one way that this Queensland Labor government is helping those people with cost-of-living issues. The water rebate has been increased up to $100 each year for eligible pensioners. The council rates rebate has been increased up to $180 each year for eligible pensioners and discounts on car registration fees and public transport fares remain available to those who are eligible for those concessions. The Queensland Labor government also funds the ClimateSmart Home Service, which assists families and all Queenslanders with their electricity bills not only in terms of saving on their power bills but also in terms of making a contribution to saving our environment. There is also the Solar Hot Water Rebate Scheme, which provides up to $1,000 to eligible households to install solar hot-water systems at their premises.

There are also some home and property rebates available to eligible people. There are bond loans and there is the RentConnect service, which is an outstanding service. I must acknowledge the wonderful contribution made by the RentConnect staff in the Morayfield state electorate. They provide a wonderful service and are providing real assistance to vulnerable people in the Morayfield community. There are also deposit assistance grants and other grants available to those people.

This government is committed to providing support for Queenslanders who need a helping hand, unlike the opposition, which is committed to cuts--cuts to programs, cuts to support services, cuts to infrastructure. They are about making it tougher for people who need a helping hand.

Mr FOLEY (Maryborough--Ind) (12.23 pm): I rise to bring to the attention of the House the tragic disease cystic fibrosis and its impact on everyday Queenslanders. Many years ago, the teenage daughter of some good friends of mine, David and Eileen with whom I worked, passed away from this terrible disease. In more recent times some friends with whom we have been lifelong friends, Dean and Katrina, have a little boy who has cystic fibrosis. Their children, Asher, Samson and Noah, are just fantastic kids and Samson is a ‘life of the party’ little fellow.

Anyone who has journeyed with a family who has been touched by cystic fibrosis knows full well the terrible impact that it has on that family. Yet Cystic Fibrosis Queensland is proactively delivering preventative health information, support and services, medical equipment, oxygen, counselling for families, respite services and metropolitan and regional health professional education. The work that Cystic Fibrosis Queensland does in this regard saves the Queensland taxpayer and Queensland Health a heck of a lot of money.

Cystic fibrosis presents a very serious health issue in the community that has a significant impact on Queensland hospitals. This government really needs to pitch in and give urgent attention and support to Cystic Fibrosis Queensland even if for no reason other than the money saved in its own Health budget. Cystic fibrosis, or CF, affects only a small percentage of Queenslanders. However, its impact on the lives of those individuals with the disease, those nearest to them and the health system is very substantial. It is an insidious, debilitating disease and is the most common life-threatening, recessive genetic condition affecting Australian children. There is no cure and the average life expectancy is only 38 years. As I have said, I have seen parents who have lost teenagers and attended their funeral. That has left a lasting impact on my life.

Every four days a child is born with cystic fibrosis. It is an extremely serious illness that mainly affects the lungs and digestive system. Breathing and digesting food causes significant problems, with young patients requiring constant medication and treatment. Babies, children and young adults who live with cystic fibrosis have to take up to 40 tablets every day just to break down food and every day they can have up to two hours of physiotherapy to help them breathe. For people living with cystic fibrosis, a small cold can develop into a life-threatening chest infection and three weeks of treatment in hospital. Repeated chest infections can permanently damage their lungs, making it harder for them to breathe. At some point in their life, people with cystic fibrosis may need a lung transplant, which is often their only chance of survival. Of course, this places a huge stress on the entire family physically, emotionally and financially.

Of 4,422,820 Queenslanders, there are currently 740 people living with cystic fibrosis, representing one-quarter of all Australians living with cystic fibrosis. While this only represents 1.6 per cent of the Queensland population, their lifetime care comes at a cost of millions of dollars per person. Frankly, the Queensland government could do a lot more towards funding this organisation. So much of the effort that these parents put in, such as the grind of doing physiotherapy with their children, is a task that they take on gladly to see their children survive but, obviously, it puts a great deal of pressure on those particular families. The best practice treatment and management of cystic fibrosis on a daily basis is crucial to the person’s quality of life and their longevity. I can do nothing other than urge the government to get behind funding this great organisation which, in the end, saves the Health budget millions of dollars and also saves the lives of some of our most vulnerable Queenslanders.

Mrs ATTWOOD (Mount Ommaney--ALP) (12.28 pm): This year I have been delighted to be able to represent the Bligh government at a number of multicultural festivals and consultation policy forums. This wide array of festivals has been an exciting time for the diverse cultures we have in Queensland. Just this weekend I travelled to Bundaberg to attend its annual festival. This is the second time I have visited this festival since becoming the Parliamentary Secretary for Multicultural Affairs 18 months ago. The theme of the festival, peace and harmony, reflected the feelings of thousands of people who attended that day. There was a lot of goodwill and support for the citizenship ceremony conducted that morning. I congratulate the local member, Jack Dempsey, and the Rotary Club of Bundaberg Sunrise on their support for and coordination of this great event.

Queensland is now well known and respected for its rich multicultural history. Indeed, it is something that we are proud of and celebrate. Queensland is home to people from more than 200 different cultures, all of whom have come here seeking a better life for themselves, their families and their children. Australia’s humble beginnings lay the very foundations that led to the multicultural society that we now live in. From the Chinese who settled in the goldfields in the 1870s to those from European nations who were displaced by war in the early 20th century and the Vietnamese in the 1970s, people from many countries have come for many reasons and created their new homes here. Communities across the state continue to embrace the notion of a fair go for everyone, regardless of where they come from, what language they speak or what religion they follow. The Queensland government welcomes this diversity and is committed to building a fair and equitable society.

Our multicultural festivals provide an opportunity to build bridges between cultures and increase appreciation of and respect for diversity. I enjoyed the opportunity to attend a number of festivals in South-East Queensland, including the Iraqi festival. This culture has a deep and rich history that dates back to ancient times as Iraq was home to some of the world’s earliest civilisations such as Sumer, Babylon and Assyria. The Vishu festival originates from the state of Kerala in South India and marks the first day of the Malayalam year. The Ipswich Global Fiesta, organised by the Ipswich City Council, celebrates Ipswich’s cultural diversity and increases community engagement in the region. The ethnic youth ministry multicultural fiesta gathered young people from various ethnic communities in the Catholic Archdiocese of Brisbane to share in and celebrate the richness of their cultural heritage through food, fellowship and entertainment. The Sinhala and Tamil new year celebrations recognise the contribution of Australia’s oldest migrant groups.

Such celebrations build bridges within cultures. For young people in particular the festive environment is ideal for connecting with and sharing their cultural heritage with the wider community. We live in a complex world and this makes it especially important that our youth develop a strong sense of belonging and pride in their identity, which of course includes their cultural identity. I congratulate the organisers for their continued efforts so that people from many different backgrounds can be sure that culture remains strong in Queensland while sharing this with the wider community. As I have said, the Queensland government has a strong vision for a fair, equitable and inclusive society.

I also briefly mention the government’s review on Queensland’s multicultural policy. In October last year, Multicultural Affairs Queensland launched extensive public consultations seeking people’s views on how the state’s multicultural policies can be improved for the benefit of all Queenslanders. This review was about planning for the future of Queensland and deciding what we would like our state to look like. The government has held many community workshops across the state, attended by cultural groups, refugees, migrants, peak community bodies and many non-government service organisations. I have attended workshops in Emerald, Gladstone, Hervey Bay, Bundaberg and the Sunshine Coast and was impressed with the numbers present and the contribution people made to the discussion topics. We held these consultations because we recognise that community input is vital to good government. We know that for policy to be effective it must truly reflect the needs of the people it is meant to support.

Some of the important issues raised included the recognition of prior qualifications, the underemployment of migrant groups, training and educational opportunities, information about services and strengthening multicultural identities to name but a few. The total number of submissions was outstanding, with 240 submissions received. This review is designed to ensure that the policy continues to be responsive and relevant to the changing needs and demographics of Queensland. I look forward to the ideas raised in the community contributing to a multicultural policy that is bigger, stronger and more inclusive than ever before.

XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training) (12.34 pm): I present a bill for an act to amend the Education (Queensland College of Teachers) Act 2005, the Industrial Relations Regulation 2000, the Public Service Act 2008, the Statutory Bodies Financial Arrangements Regulation 2007 and the Vocational Education, Training and Employment Act 2000 for particular purposes. I present the explanatory notes, and I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a first time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Education and Training Legislation (Skills Queensland) Amendment Bill [ 2849 ].
Tabled paper: Education and Training Legislation (Skills Queensland) Amendment Bill, explanatory notes [ 2850 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training) (12.34 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Today I introduce the Education and Training Legislation (Skills Queensland) Amendment Bill 2010 into parliament. This bill will establish Skills Queensland, an independent skills commission to lead the state’s skills and workforce development. The bill will also amend the Education (Queensland College of Teachers) Act 2005 to strengthen the child protection measures within the teaching environment. Skills are vital to Queensland’s economic prosperity. For workers, qualifications represent the passport to increased employment and earnings potential. For employers, a skilled workforce is flexible, innovative and productive.

Queensland’s skills system is a formidable industry sector in its own right. Education and training is now Australia’s largest services exporter and is worth $2.4 billion a year to Queensland’s economy. Queensland’s vocational education and training or VET sector has over 1,140 active training providers, which is more than any other state or territory. Queensland now trains about 45 per cent of the nation’s school based apprentices and trainees. Again, that is more than any other state or territory. A higher percentage of unemployed Queenslanders engaging in the skills system find employment after the completion of their studies than the national average. Despite the strength of Queensland’s VET sector, more can still be done.

Queensland’s strong population and economic growth over the past decade has meant that maintaining a high participation rate in the skills system has been difficult. The boom years leading up to 2007 stretched our system, with providers struggling to keep up with a growing demand for skills. The global financial crisis presented other challenges to the system as providers struggled to shift their training effort to meet a rapidly changing demand for skills. With the state budget predicting a return to strong growth in the years ahead, it is now time to ensure our system is focused on the future. That is why the Queensland government proposes to establish Skills Queensland, a statutory body to lead reform to Queensland’s skills system to create a more flexible and demand-driven system that meets the needs of industry, communities and the economy.

Skills Queensland’s key function will be to advise government on skills and workforce development and skilled migration. It will develop a skills and workforce development investment plan, a five-year plan with a 10-year whole-of-economy outlook that will be renewed annually. This will be the primary way for Skills Queensland to identify priorities, over a five-year period, for investment in skills, qualifications and workforce development. Through the plan, Skills Queensland will be able to recommend how government resources should be allocated to meet the state’s skills development needs and to respond to emerging industry opportunities and regional and global economic factors.

Non-government investment in vocational education and training in Queensland is relatively low compared to other Australian jurisdictions. The government is looking forward to employers taking further responsibility for skilling their workforce. Queensland is on the front foot in meeting this challenge with the recently announced CSG/LNG investment fund. This fund leverages resources dollar for dollar from industry to meet the skills needs of this new and emerging industry.

In its first six months, Skills Queensland will focus on developing and implementing industry engagement mechanisms to establish an identity amongst industry stakeholders and support its advisory functions and the development of the inaugural skills and workforce development investment plan. It will also start to look at opportunities to leverage greater contribution from industry. Skills Queensland will have access to strategic purchasing funding held by the government. The funding will be allocated towards the skills and workforce priorities identified by Skills Queensland and will be used to leverage funding from industry through co-investment. Access to the fund will be subject to government approval, taking account of the impact on providers, in particular TAFE institutes, to ensure viability and sustainability into the future.

In the future, when the body has established its credentials with industry and government, the funding arrangements may evolve whereby Skills Queensland could be provided its own funding to support its strategic investments and brokerage arrangements with industry. Skills Queensland will be a genuine partnership whereby industry and government can share the challenge of meeting Queensland’s future skill needs.

Skills Queensland will be led by seven industry representatives with direct experience in industry, training or employment sectors, one of whom will be the chair. It will also comprise the directors-general from the employment and training portfolios. Industry representatives bring commercial acumen, an understanding of emerging industries and technologies, supply and demand priorities for skilled labour and economic drivers for business.

The establishment of Skills Queensland will strengthen industry leadership of and investment in skills and workforce development in Queensland. It will also increase industry confidence in and ownership of our skills system. Government will continue to play a key role in funding, implementing and administering skills and workforce development strategies. However, these activities will be informed, and well informed I believe, by Skills Queensland.

I turn now to the College of Teachers legislation. The bill amends provisions relating to teachers who are convicted of disqualifying offences. Currently, the college must cancel the registration of an approved teacher convicted of a disqualifying offence after 1 January 2006 who is sentenced to imprisonment. That teacher then becomes an excluded person and cannot apply for teacher registration. The teacher cannot appeal the decision to cancel registration.

However, where in a limited number of cases a teacher surrenders their registration before they were convicted of a disqualifying offence and sentenced to an imprisonment order, the person is currently able to reapply to the Queensland College of Teachers for registration. The bill will address this by amending the definition of excluded person to include persons who previously held teacher registration or permission to teach who are convicted of a disqualifying offence after 1 January 2006 and sentenced to an imprisonment order. This means that, even if the person surrendered their registration prior to their conviction for a disqualifying offence, they will be excluded from ever again applying for teacher registration.

The bill will also ensure that the college is notified of the outcome of all investigations started by employing authorities involving an allegation of harm caused or likely to be caused to a child because of the conduct of a teacher. Currently, the employing authority is required to notify the college when it commences this type of investigation and then notify the college if the teacher is dismissed after the investigation or resigns during or after the investigation.

However, the employing authority is not strictly required to notify the college of the outcome of every commenced investigation--for example, if the investigation does not result in the teacher’s dismissal or resignation. This bill amends the act to clarify that, if an employing authority is required to notify the college that an investigation has commenced, it must also then notify the college of the outcome of that investigation. This will ensure that the college is kept well informed about all investigations and can instigate its own investigation or take disciplinary action against the teacher if appropriate.

The bill also amends the act to make minor and technical consequential amendments arising out of the amendments to the act in the Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Act 2010. The amendments are supported by the three education sectors. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate, on motion of Mr Nicholls, adjourned.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Fair Trading (Australian Consumer Law) Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. PJ LAWLOR (Southport--ALP) (Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading) (12.42 pm): I present a bill for an act to amend the Fair Trading Act 1989 to apply the Australian Consumer Law of the Commonwealth as a law of Queensland and for other particular purposes, to make consequential amendments to the acts stated in the schedule, and to amend the Security Providers Act 1993 for particular purposes. I present the explanatory notes, and I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a first time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Fair Trading (Australian Consumer Law) Amendment Bill [ 2851 ].
Tabled paper: Fair Trading (Australian Consumer Law) Amendment Bill, explanatory notes [ 2852 ] .
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. PJ LAWLOR (Southport--ALP) (Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading) (12.43 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: In 2008, the Productivity Commission published a comprehensive review of Australia’s consumer policy framework. This review found that Australia had a sound consumer policy and product safety system but highlighted areas in which regulation could be substantially improved.

The shape of the current consumer policy reforms was agreed in broad terms by COAG in October 2008, and further defined through a national cooperative process engaging the Ministerial Council on Consumer Affairs and officials groups from all jurisdictions. The resulting Australian Consumer Law, or ACL, represents the most significant overhaul of Australia’s consumer laws in 25 years.

The ACL is founded on a well-established core of consumer provisions from the Trade Practices Act 1974. In addition, the ACL captures best-practice approaches to consumer protection by drawing on some of the beneficial consumer provisions that have been independently developed by the states and territories. The ACL will provide to all Australians, consumers and businesses alike the benefits of a national product safety system. Finally, the ACL adopts some aspects of consumer protection entirely new to Australian consumer law, such as the consumer guarantees system.

In a practical sense, the bill applies the ACL as Queensland law through amendments to the Fair Trading Act 1989 and consequential amendments to related acts. The Commonwealth Trade Practices Act will be renamed the Competition and Consumer Act--a name which is much more accessible and reflects the focus of Australia’s main law which regulates markets.

The implementation of the ACL is a key element of COAG’s seamless national economy reform agenda. Under the terms of the National Partnership Agreement to Deliver a Seamless National Economy, the Commonwealth and all states and territories have agreed to apply the ACL by 1 January 2011. From 1 January, Queensland and Australian consumers will enjoy the benefits of consistent rights wherever they live, and Queensland businesses will obtain greater efficiencies through a single, simplified national law. The ACL will cover a greater range of consumer transactions and provide a broader range of protections than currently provided through the existing Fair Trading Act.

Key features of the ACL include new unfair contract terms provisions, which will allow consumers to challenge potentially unfair terms in contracts and allow the courts to declare unfair terms of contracts to be void. The new consumer guarantees will replace the system of statutory implied conditions and warranties, which is generally not well understood by either consumers or businesses. The consumer guarantees provisions will provide consumers with clearer guidance about their rights to redress when problems occur. They will also make business obligations clearer.

The ACL’s unsolicited consumer agreement provisions are largely based upon the Bligh government’s family-friendly trading hours as a best-practice provision. The law contains express supplier obligations about the way in which consumers are approached and about the making of agreements, including permitted visiting hours, disclosing the purpose and identity of the supplier, and duties imposed on suppliers to leave premises on request and inform a consumer of their rights to terminate the agreement.

The law prohibits misleading or deceptive conduct and includes provisions prohibiting people who are operating in trade or commerce from engaging in unconscionable conduct towards consumers or businesses. These prohibitions will operate on the same basis as those currently in the Trade Practices Act.

The law will also deliver an improved product safety regime for Queenslanders for consumer goods and product related services. While the Commonwealth government will assume responsibility for implementing permanent bans and safety standards on consumer goods and product related services nationally, states and territories will retain their power to issue interim bans for consumer goods and product related services.

States and territories will also be able to propose permanent bans and new standards if they encounter problems with particular consumer goods and product related services. This new approach will bring more certainty for business and consumers about product safety laws in Australia.

The law also provides for a slightly broader definition of a consumer to that currently in Queensland’s Fair Trading Act. It will provide better cover for consumers purchasing goods not typically used for domestic or household purposes and for some business purchases. The ACL also provides regulators with a broader range of enforcement tools, with potentially higher financial penalties compared to those provided by the Fair Trading Act, enabling a range of proportionate responses to breaches of the law.

The Australian Consumer Law will strengthen and broaden consumer protection for all Queenslanders. It introduces reforms that will significantly reduce regulatory complexity for businesses and takes Australia further towards a seamless national economy across an increasingly national marketplace.

The bill will also implement a July 2008 COAG agreement to adopt a nationally consistent approach to the regulation of the private security industry. As part of these reforms, Queensland agreed to introduce mandatory fingerprinting of security providers to improve identity and probity checking. The security industry can be infiltrated by criminal elements, as evidenced through investigations and reports recently completed by the Australian Crime Commission and the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption.

Fingerprinting improves the initial identification of licensees and has an important role to play in improving probity checks because a more thorough criminal history check can be obtained on licence applicants. Ongoing probity, for the duration of a licence, is also improved as fingerprints can be checked against ‘latent’ prints left at crime scenes.

The amendments will require applicants for a security provider licence to consent to having their fingerprints taken prior to the chief executive issuing a licence. The legislation will also provide for the chief executive to require all current licence holders to be fingerprinted before renewal of their licence.

The amendments aim to minimise the impact on the privacy of security providers while recognising that security providers occupy positions of trust and are responsible for public safety and the protection of property. The act will also be amended to include terrorism offences in the list of disqualifying offences regardless of where such offences are committed.
The introduction of more stringent identity and probity checks will help build a safer community and better harmonise Australia’s security provider laws. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate, on motion of Mr Nicholls, adjourned.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Motor Accident Insurance and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from 5 August (see p. 2519), on motion of Mr Fraser--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr NICHOLLS (Clayfield--LNP) (12.50 pm): The Motor Accident Insurance and Other Legislation Amendment Bill principally amends three acts. For some of my colleagues, and I am not sure about the Treasurer’s side, this piece of legislation takes the eye-glazing award of the year. I will certainly try to make it not quite as bad as it would otherwise seem. I want to deal with three major parts of the legislation in turn. The first relates to the Motor Accident Insurance Act.

Mr Fraser:
You want this job.
Mr NICHOLLS: But it would be more exciting if I were doing it.
Mr Fraser: Do your best.
Mr NICHOLLS: I am going to. Just hang on; you are getting a bit ‘previous’. The Motor Accident Insurance Act--
Mr Wilson interjected.

Mr SPEAKER: Order!
The member for the Clayfield has the call.
Mr NICHOLLS: I will get the Minister for Education’s note. I did not want to forget that. I have got him.

The changes to the Motor Accident Insurance Act are designed to implement the announcement made by the Treasurer at budget time to ban commissions and inducements paid to third parties. This, we are told, will save motorists in Queensland the grand total of between $20 and $24.
Mr Wettenhall: Every dollar counts.

Mr NICHOLLS:
As the member for Barron River says, every dollar counts. That is certainly the case with this government as it scrimps and scrounges for every dollar and increases taxes mercilessly as it tries to find every dollar in order to get some control of its budget which, I can remind the member for Barron River, is going to be in deficit to the tune of $1.4 billion this year and will be in deficit each and every year over the forward estimates of the budget totalling something like $6.4 billion. As they tax the people of Queensland more and more, the scrimping and scrounging goes on on the Labor side of this House.

The Treasurer dressed up this change as some sort of miraculous announcement stemming from a deep-seated desire on the part of the parliamentary members of the Australian Labor Party to make motoring more affordable for Queensland motorists. What is more, he dressed it up in all the finery of a budget announcement as if it were some sort of magnanimous gesture that comes at the cost of government revenue--almost as though it were a tax cut. The Treasurer and the Labor Party expect that Queensland motorists will thank them and this government for their generosity.

We know that, despite the Treasurer’s efforts to dress it up otherwise, this concession does not come at any cost to the revenue base of Queensland. It is not some form of tax relief able to be met from the abundance and good management of the Queensland exchequer by the Treasurer. We know, Queensland motorists, more importantly, know and Queensland businesses also know that it is another dodge by an increasingly dodgy government. We also know that this Bligh Labor government has not simply abandoned the Queensland motorists; it has actively pursued a policy to drive them into penury and to make motoring almost unaffordable for the average Queenslander.

Motor vehicle charges and costs affect nearly all Queenslanders. In our decentralised state with its vast distances, motor vehicle costs and charges take on an added importance. They are not a luxury. Quite simply, Queenslanders have to travel further to work, to play, to get to school, to get to the doctor, to see friends and relatives, and the list goes on. In recognition of this, Queensland for many years had no fuel tax and had low rates of registration and transfer duty. But under Labor this has all changed.

It was the Borbidge-Sheldon coalition government that took decisive action to protect Queensland’s tax-free-fuel status after the High Court ruling on franchise and licence fees found them to be unconstitutional. It was the then coalition that took action to ensure motorists were not slugged an extra 8.2c a litre at the petrol pump. I might mention that, at the same time, it was Joan Sheldon as Treasurer who removed the tolls from the Sunshine Motorway in order to make motoring more affordable in that part of South-East Queensland.
