She was truly a reforming Treasurer. She was someone who had the interests of Queenslanders at heart and actually did something to protect Queensland motorists and not penalise them.

I come back to the costs of motoring. It was Labor, with its undying hatred of the internal combustion engine, that was always on the lookout for a way to scrap the Fuel Subsidy Scheme. The Minister for Main Roads hates motor vehicles. He wants to build roads that no-one can drive on. Why else would he stand up and support--
Mr WALLACE: I rise to a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I find the member’s comments offensive and ask them to be withdrawn.

Mr NICHOLLS: I withdraw. The Minister for Main Roads comes into this place each and every day and extols the virtues of his road-building program but then goes out and taxes the very motorists who would use the roads that he is building. He increases the fees and charges. One has to wonder what his motivation is in doing so. He stands up in here and supports a budget that increases the costs and charges for motorists across Queensland. At the same time, he cuts $250 million from the Main Roads budget this year.

I go back to the history of the fuel tax in Queensland. It was Peter Beattie who wanted to do away with it. He instead changed the registration fees payable. He tried it on a number of occasions but the Queensland public and the Queensland motoring public woke up to the pea-and-thimble trick that he was trying to perpetrate on them and forced him to back down.

There were various other attempts to modify the scheme in subsequent years, culminating in the current Treasurer’s stillborn attempts to introduce a scheme that relied on motorists producing a licence with details either electronically embedded in it or stuck to the back of it with a sticker to claim the discounted amount. This crazy scheme also relied on the retailer having signs with about three different prices on them outside their fuel stations to show the true cost of the fuel so consumers could see whether they were getting the full benefit of the rebate.

If ever we wondered where Ken Henry got the idea for a simple super mining tax from, we do not have to go any further. He rang up the Queensland Treasurer and spoke to him and said, ‘Can you design a super mining tax for me?’ That is where he got the information from. That plan of the Treasurer’s was abandoned after several million dollars had been spent on it. It was cast onto the trash heap of abandoned ideas which is gradually getting more and more full as this Labor government ages.

Eventually, all pretence at trying to keep the fuel subsidy in place was dropped. After telling the people of Queensland that she would not kick them while they were down and after promising that the government would continue to deliver a fuel subsidy scheme, the Premier and her Treasurer did just the opposite. They did kick Queenslanders while they were down. They effectively introduced a 9.2c a litre fuel tax for all Queensland motorists.

Three years ago the government increased the transfer duty on motor vehicles across the range. Four cylinders, six cylinders, eight cylinders--it does not matter. Transfer duties increased by between 50 and 100 per cent. The transfer duty on an average six-cylinder car--an ordinary Falcon or Commodore--goes up from $300 to $575. Annual registration fees jumped by between 17 and 23 per cent depending on the engine size. For an average six-cylinder car the cost of registration is now over $800 a year. This year alone the car registration fees will increase by another three per cent--by the rate of inflation. To top it all off, there has been an increase in tolls from 1 July of up to 33 per cent as the government tries to max out the return on the rushed sale of Queensland Motorways.

Queensland has become the most expensive state in Australia in which to own and operate a family car. It is all down to Anna Bligh and her Labor administration. That is why we have announced a vehicle registration freeze when elected. Queenslanders deserve a tangible sign that their government cares about their everyday costs. A registration freeze is one way of showing that.
What do people say about the proposals in this bill? Let us see what the MTAQ said about these proposals.
Sitting suspended from 1.00 pm to 2.30 pm.

Mr NICHOLLS: Before the lunch adjournment I was reflecting on the great motoring rip-off that was being perpetrated on motorists in Queensland by the Labor Party and in particular the increases in charges and costs, whether it be fuel, registration fees or transfer duty. I also want to reflect on some of the comments that have been made about the Treasurer’s proposal to prohibit the payment of inducements in relation to the compulsory third-party insurance scheme by the Motor Trades Association of Queensland, which represents motor dealers--motor dealers who in the main are small businesses, motor dealers who in the main are struggling, motor dealers who in the main employ many thousands of people and motor dealers whom both the Treasurer and I have some sort of knowledge, understanding, background and history with. In its letter to the Treasurer the Motor Trades Association of Queensland said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The announcement by you to reduce the CTP ceiling by $24 at the expense of dealers and legislate to ban the payment of commissions and other inducements is nothing more than a smokescreen for the government hikes in other statutory charges over the past two years.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The organisation goes on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Over the past two years this office has received numerous complaints about the costs of car registrations but has never received a complaint about the cost of CTP, so the cost of collecting statutory charges, including the delivery of CTP on behalf of the government, was never the issue.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: So that was never the issue in terms of the costs of registering and running a motor vehicle.
XML.Hansard-Body: One of the great acts of a scoundrel is to get someone else to pay the freight and then take credit for it, and that is the act of this government with this amendment. The motor industry is not the milch cow which the government thinks it is. Latest figures show that, while record high monthly new vehicle sales results were achieved nationally, Queensland achieved record low monthly results. So nationally there were high figures but Queensland had low figures--in fact, the lowest according to the MTAQ since 2004, with used car sales travelling not much better, with the 2010 average monthly sales at the lowest levels since 2002. So while delivering a small saving to the motorist, small business is being asked in the main to pay the cost. It is no wonder that businesses in Queensland are doing it so hard and no wonder that small and medium enterprises in Queensland have lost faith in this Labor government and its management of the economy.
I also have here a response from an average motorist who has written to me, and I am sure many other members have received the same sort of correspondence. He states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Dear Tim Nicholls
Is Andrew Fraser joking? They have found a $20 saving in CTP but they have increased car rego and fuel beyond people’s reach.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He goes on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Tell him on behalf of me and fellow taxpayers to go join a circus, because his work is an embarrassment to this state.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He goes on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This saving is the price of one meal for me and my family.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: That is how the change to the CTP scheme manufactured by the Treasurer is measured by a variety of people.
XML.Hansard-Body: What were the alternatives to what has been put forward and what is being considered by the legislation today? We do not know because the report by the Motor Accident Insurance Commission into fees and charges commissioned by the Treasurer was taken to cabinet and is now covered by the shroud of cabinet secrecy. So any alternatives cannot be canvassed or considered and the strength or weakness of the case in relation to the CTP prohibition on inducements and on commissions cannot be measured.

The CTP scheme relies on CTP insurers offering the insurance at a price within a range set by the commission. It is not something that a true free market sets but is in fact regulated, and that is because of the element of compulsion. Madam Deputy Speaker, neither you nor I, or in fact any motorist obeying the law in Queensland, has a choice with regard to CTP. We have to register a vehicle if we want to drive on a public road. So as a government mandated service it requires a degree of regulation--that takes it out of the free market--and the government via the MAIC sets a ceiling above which an insurer cannot charge and also sets a floor, and it is primarily the ceiling that we are concerned about here.

In setting that ceiling the MAIC takes into account all of the costs of the CTP scheme, and over time that has come to include the commissions that have been paid to third parties, who predominantly are motor dealers. So in setting the total amount of the insurance levy, the commission gets information and works out what the cost of delivering that service will be. There are also some other provisions in section 12 of the legislation that deal with what the costs and charges are. It is a compulsory scheme--we do not have a chance to opt out of it--and the prices for the insurance and the provision of the service are set by regulation. Therefore, it would seem appropriate that any change, such as that which we are considering here today, that comes about as a result of an inquiry being carried out by a government body should be supported by the inquiry document being released to the public. Indeed, at the briefing on the bill yesterday I asked about that report and I was informed that it had been sent to cabinet as it contains commercial-in-confidence information from the insurers.

So what do we have? All we have here are the statements in the explanatory notes, and I will read them. The explanatory notes state that a review of the scheme recently conducted by the commission ‘identified high policy and acquisition costs associated with the scheme’. But there is no explanation of what that actually means--that is, high policy and acquisition costs associated with the scheme. There is no further information provided. The explanatory notes go on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It has also contributed to the tendency of insurers over several years to file their premiums ...
XML.Hansard-Body: It does not say it actually was the cause of it. It says that it has contributed to the tendency, so it does not even mean that it is occurring all of the time. It is a very weak statement out of a report that we cannot see, test and assess. We do not know what the real options and costs will be because they are hidden in cabinet-in-confidence documents.

The question we have to ask is: what else did the report say? Previous reports have been made public, and so should this one. We should know what else that report contained, other than the very scant detail that we have been provided with in the explanatory notes. So my question to the Treasurer in this respect is: will the Treasurer table the report, with any commercially sensitive information deleted, so that Queenslanders can see what the report says? Until that happens, we have to take the government on trust. Unfortunately, that is not a commodity that this government has a lot of.

When we look at some of the other aspects of what could go into the cost of a compulsory third-party insurance premium, we need to look at section 12 of the act. It includes the insurer’s premium--that is, the cost from the insurance company--and we have discussed that. That is where we are told that there is a tendency for the insurer to file their premiums at the ceiling. However, there is also the statutory insurance scheme levy--that is, the cost of the government actually running the scheme. That is a component of it as well. Then there is the hospital and emergency services levy which funds some component of the running of our public hospitals, because when people are injured in an accident they rely on the public services primarily in those hospitals to treat them immediately after an accident.

The nominal defendant levy covers people who are injured but who cannot identify the vehicle that caused the injury or where that vehicle is driven in an uninsured or unregistered state. So that provides a safety net for those circumstances. There is also the ubiquitous administration fee. It is interesting to note in the annual report for 2008-09--and I am indebted to the Parliamentary Library’s research note which came out at lunchtime--that the commissioner filed a statement in his report in which he said that he believed that the main factors pushing up premium prices were a downward change in interest rate markets and an increase in claim costs, especially claims for economic loss. The commissioner also stated that it has also been reported that industry sources believe that the current pricing reflected tight margins in CTP.

So there we have the commissioner in the report, according to the Parliamentary Library research note, identifying the main factors pushing up the premium prices as being a downward charge in the interest rate markets--so as insurers invest the premiums they receive an income from it; as the interest rates goes down, they receive less money so they have to earn a profit and so they push up the price--and an increase in claim costs. So as there are more motorists on the road, there are more accidents and perhaps, because of a tendency to give greater payouts to people who are injured, there has been an increase in the cost of the scheme and an increase in the premiums in order to cover those costs as set. Those premiums are usually calculated by actuaries.

When we look at some of the functions that are carried out under that scheme, we look at the cost of the Motor Accident Insurance Commission itself. The Motor Accident Insurance Commission was set up to administer this compulsory third-party scheme and it does such things as supervises insurers, establishes and reviews prudential standards, monitors the management of claims and fixes the insurance. It also does a number of other worthwhile things, such as provide funds for rehabilitation, research and education, promotion and, if funds are available, financially contributing towards regular safety and roadworthiness inspections. So there are a whole range of components that go into the Motor Accident Insurance Commission’s cost base that have to be covered by part of the CTP insurance claim under section 12 of the act.

But we do not know if any of those components have any impact on the increase in the cost of the compulsory third-party scheme and the calculation by the Motor Accident Insurance Commission of the ceiling and the floor for the scheme. We do not know, because the report that the MAIC did into the scheme, on the Treasurer’s instruction, has been shuffled off to cabinet and is now held to be cabinet-in-confidence. I think that is a great pity because, where we have someone saying that these are savings that can be driven out of the private sector, we should also look to see if there are any savings that can be driven out of the public sector. That is, can the public sector do more with less or are they doing everything that they need to do with the right amount of money? We do not know. Maybe it is, maybe it is not, but we have not seen the report so we cannot see whether that is the case or not. We do not know if savings are available to motorists other than this saving that is being proposed in the legislation here today.

This process is shrouded in secrecy and, I have to say, it smacks of government opportunism. One has to wonder why the report has not been made public. I do not believe that the excuse of cabinet-in-confidence because of sensitive information is sufficiently adequate or could not be dealt with in such a way as to provide the details and the information that would be required in order to enable a fair and full assessment of all the costs to be made available.

I want to turn now to the amendments proposed to the Queensland Competition Authority Act. Let me make it clear to those opposite and anyone else who might try to make mischief out of the debate on this legislation: the LNP has consistently and constantly opposed the rushed and poorly thought through privatisation program promoted and promulgated by Labor in Queensland. We opposed it when the legislation was brought into this place last year. We fought it in last year’s budget debate until four o’clock in the morning, when the government guillotined debate and pushed through the legislation. We oppose it despite the government’s attempts to cloud the issue this morning and we will continue to oppose it.

I will tell members why we oppose it. The privatisation program represents a fundamental failure of the operation of democracy in this state. The ALP did not tell the people before the March 2009 election that privatisation was on its agenda. The LNP categorically supports the right of voters to be informed about these types of decisions at the ballot box before they make their decision. The integrity of and faith in the electoral system requires it. There is the rushed nature of the privatisation, the lack of a consideration of alternatives and the discussion of those alternatives in the public domain. The Premier claims that the alternative to her program is massive service delivery cuts, but that is simply more deceit and so spurious that it is simply unbecoming of a Premier of this state who knows better.

I heard those claims this morning in relation to a discussion about the duplication of the Gateway Bridge. The duplication of the Gateway Bridge was, in fact, funded entirely out of the operations of the business case for the duplication of the Gateway Bridge. It was funded before the privatisation was coming on and the business case was in place before the privatisation was coming on. So let us not get confused about projects that are going ahead and projects that are not going ahead because of privatisation. Projects like the duplication of the Gateway Bridge were underway before privatisation was coming along. The duplication of the Gateway Bridge was being carried out based on the fact that there was a case that was put forward by QTC and by Treasury that would enable the state to afford to build and deliver it within the confines of the Gateway Motorway company. All the debt that was taken on in relation to that project is securely locked away in the Gateway Motorway company. It is not the debt of the state of Queensland in the sense that it is in a position that it would change if the debt was taken off it.
Mr Fraser: Therefore you can never talk about $83 billion anymore.
Mr NICHOLLS: Yes, I can.
Mr Fraser: No, you just took out three--
Mr NICHOLLS: No, the $83.5 billion debt includes GOCs but it also includes the capacity for those GOCs to pay for it. If you start selling it off--
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms Farmer): Order! I ask members to direct their comments through the chair.

Mr NICHOLLS: Let us not go down that path, because that is not the correct path to go down. There are alternatives to this rushed privatisation. They exist and this government has refused to consider them.

We also oppose privatisation because of the state of the market and the chance that the assets will be sold for less than their full value. We have already seen with the sale of Forestry Plantations Queensland a sale price that was substantially less than that which was achieved by the Victorian government almost exactly a decade ago for a very similar class of assets. We are convinced that this is a fire sale and that this will continue to be the case in the foreseeable future.

The other issue that causes us to oppose this privatisation is that the asset sale is not a long-term solution to the structural problems in Queensland’s budget. The Labor government continues to fail to address the issue of debt and deficit. It fails to control its own expenses growth. As I have indicated earlier, deficits continue over the out years in the budget forecasts. That means quite simply that the Queensland government is spending more than it is earning. Once these assets are sold in an effort to bring the budget back into some form of shape, unless that fundamental flaw is fixed up--unless that structural deficit is addressed--we will find ourselves in exactly the same position in two or three years time, except that the assets will have been sold. So the capital value will not be there and the income from those assets, whether that be by dividends or by way of direct revenue, will not be there. So we have opposed a flawed privatisation agenda and only the election of an LNP government can stop it.

This bill, insofar as it deals with the Queensland Competition Authority, is not about the sale of parts of Queensland Rail; it is about the third-party access regime that applies in Queensland to monopoly assets that impact on productivity in Queensland. It applies not just to railways but to ports and other monopoly services. It applies whether that asset is publicly or privately owned. At the moment in Queensland, there are two services that are currently declared services under the Queensland Competition Authority Act. They are the entire rail transport services provided by Queensland’s intrastate rail network and the coal-handling services at the Dalrymple Bay Coal Terminal.

Most people who do not live in the rarefied air of competition policy theory--and I think that is most people--are entitled to be somewhat confused by these amendments and what they mean. In essence, we have here an attempt to resolve a turf war in Queensland’s favour. There has been a review of the competition principles that apply in Queensland to monopoly service providers whether they are publicly or privately owned. Those services can be things such as port facilities, electricity transmission services, railways, water and waste water pipeline services and treatment services. That is one aspect of where we are today. There has also been an application from Asciano, the operator of Pacific National rail services, to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission for the Central Queensland coal network--and that is the four networks that make up that Central Queensland coal network--to be declared under the national access regime.

There are two competing regimes in relation to competition and provision of access to monopoly services. Although not specifically related to the sale of Queensland Rail and Queensland Rail assets, it is the case that the changes proposed in this bill have been spurred on by the government’s decision to sell off the QR coal freight business and the Central Queensland coal network. They are not the specific reasons for it, but the sale has brought the problem to a head. There is the review process, which is agreed under COAG, and then the application by Asciano under the national competition principles to have the Queensland service declared.

If we are going to go into that, it is appropriate to set out what exactly is happening with the sale. QR Ltd is the current owner and operator of all the passenger and freight rail businesses in Queensland. It also owns and maintains the intrastate rail tracks--the internal rail tracks. These separate components of QR’s business are each identified, and the terminology is fairly widely used, as the above-rail and below-rail components of the QR Ltd business. The above-rail is the actual business of carrying passengers and freight and entering into contracts and running, owning and operating rolling stock. Below-rail is the sleepers and rails and all the work that goes into the network services. As I said earlier, those above- and below-rail services are currently declared under the Queensland access regime and that allows third-party access. We have examples of that third-party access with the operation of Pacific National at the moment.

As from 1 July this year a new organisation called QR National has been formed, although, as I understand it, that organisation is not a company but, in fact, a trading name. It is QR Ltd trading as QR National who will own the coal freight and general freight business--that is, the above-rail business of QR Ltd. A wholly owned subsidiary, called QR Network, and that is presumably a proprietary limited company, will effectively own, via a long-term lease, the Central Queensland coal network comprising the Newlands, Goonyella, Blackwater and Moura rail network infrastructure--that is, the below-rail component of the QR Network. We will have QR National running the business of coal and general freight and we will have QR Network, a subsidiary, owning the tracks underneath--a vertically integrated monopoly. What is left is the passenger rail business--that is, the above-rail business of carrying passengers and the passenger and general freight rail network infrastructure, the sleepers and tracks and the network remnants that are not part of the Central Queensland network. Those remnants will be owned by a government owned corporation to be called Queensland Rail.

So we have those two bodies currently being considered in terms of the proposed asset sales. Once we have our head around that structure we need to deal with the issues of economic rent and monopoly rents. That is where the competition policy and the Queensland Competition Authority Act comes in. Clearly, there is a monopoly provider of services that has the power to act unconscionably in relation to the provision of those services and so must be subject to an access regime under legislation. It would be, I think, entirely natural and understandable if there is only one person who has complete control of something like the freight rail network and owns that network and also owns the business on it to try to favour their own business to maximise their returns and to provide the largest profit possible. It suits them, and it is in their business interests in a lot of ways, to exclude competitors from access to that line. In order to deal with that natural monopoly that applies and the impact that has on the economic development of the state, we have to have an access regime and that access regime is either the Queensland Competition Authority Act access regime or the regime that is set up under part III of the Trade Practices Act.

The proposed amendments to the Queensland Competition Authority Act relate to the Queensland access regime and, in particular, how Queensland Rail will be regulated by the Queensland Competition Authority. I think it is fair to say that the proposed amendments and the impact of them is significant and they are complex. From a reading of the legislation and the explanatory notes, the government hopes that these amendments will allow the QCA to continue to regulate Queensland Rail rather than the ACCC taking over the state based access regime as a result of any perceived ineffectiveness of the Queensland access regime. This goes back to the comment I made at the beginning of the discussion about this part of the legislation that this is a turf war. This is a turf war over who controls the access regime to the Queensland rail network. That turf war is being fought out between Queensland on the one hand through its legislation and, potentially, the national access regime set under part III of the Trade Practices Act with control ultimately resting with the Australian Consumer and Competition Commission, the ACCC, in Canberra as to who regulates it.

The background to this comes about as a result of the Competition Principles Agreement of 1995. Back in 1995 all Australian state and territory governments signed the Competition Principles Agreement. That agreement required the Commonwealth to establish a national third-party access regime. It established a set of principles to guide the development of third-party access regimes by state and territory governments. Third-party access regimes create a regulatory framework to enable fair and reasonable access by third parties to significant natural monopoly infrastructure facilities such as electricity grids, gas pipelines, rail tracks and port channels. I have mentioned those previously. Access regulation is intended to apply where owners or operators of natural monopoly infrastructure have the potential to exercise undue market power by denying access to their facilities or charging excessive prices to someone who wants to access their facilities thereby hindering or preventing competition within a dependent market. The classic example of that recently has been Telstra. Telstra owns the copper wires and there have been innumerable reports about battles that third-party access seekers--the likes of Optus or any of the other providers of telephony services--have fought in order to gain entry into the market and, in doing so, provide telephone services to consumers at a more competitive price. It is not about the use of the service per se, it is about what it offers at the end of the line. What does it offer at the end of a line? A more competitive service for the consumer or the user of that service.

Establishing a legal right to seek access to services provided by monopoly facilities under reasonable terms and conditions is the objective of an economic regulator such as the QCA or the ACCC charged with enforcing that access regime. They are there to make sure that access can be granted on reasonable terms and conditions; that people are not held out or made uncompetitive by the charges. In Queensland, regulated assets are covered by the act, which is the Queensland Competition Authority Act 1997, which provides a mechanism for governing access and competition. The jurisdiction covers rail services on Queensland’s intrastate rail network, as I have said, and the coal loading facility at Dalrymple Bay Coal Terminal. Part 5 of the act is modelled on section 3A of the federal Trade Practices Act 1974. The Queensland government has stated that the proposed amendments that we are discussing today will clarify the existing regulatory processes and safeguards in the regime by providing explicit guidance for ministerial decision making and ensuring that the QCA, as Queensland’s independent economic regulator, is the primary administrator of the Queensland access regime.

However, the underlying intent of the changes seems to me to be in response to an application by Asciano to the National Competition Council to have the Queensland intrastate rail network dealt with under the federal competition regime. Asciano is concerned that the Queensland access regime does not operate to provide it with as much access to the network as it would like. In order to address that issue it is seeking to have the services that are provided in Queensland under our access regime transferred to the jurisdiction of the national regime. That application by Asciano, which was made in May, was made following the government’s decision to privatise the below rail track assets, on which Asciano operates its Pacific National business, in conjunction with the above rail assets. The issue of a vertical monopoly was something very much to the forefront of Asciano’s mind when it came to these sorts of dealings.

There are some differences between the national access regime and the Queensland access regime. I think we need to have a quick look at those to understand some of these changes. Part IIIA of the Trade Practices Act establishes the national access regime, as I have indicated, and that provides the third-party access. The national access regime provides three avenues for access to a monopoly provided service. One of those avenues is a declaration by the ACCC that establishes a right for any party to negotiate terms and conditions of access with the declared service provider. In the event that either party is unable or unwilling to come to a commercially acceptable agreement, it provides for arbitration by the ACCC. It is left to the two parties themselves to negotiate the access arrangements. The party providing the access cannot refuse to deal. It opens the door for negotiations. If the negotiations do not work out, then they go to the ACCC and it arbitrates.

There is a provision in the national access regime so that the provider of a declared service or even an undeclared service--that is, one that has not been declared by the ACCC--can submit a voluntary access undertaking. If that is approved by the ACCC, negotiations for access to the service are guided by the undertaking. So the undertaking sets out the rules under which you can access the service. That is the second way that it can be dealt with under the national access regime.

The third way is a recognition by the national access regime of a state based regime. The ACCC can actually recognise an effective state based regime, and that effective state based regime then operates as the access regime. The effectiveness of a state or territory access regime can be predetermined by making an application to the National Competition Council. That is the basis of the process for access to these third-party services.

There are also amendments to the Trade Practices Act which are currently before the Commonwealth parliament, and those amendments will change the system again to provide that only a certified access regime will be considered effective in the future. So that just adds another layer of complexity to what is already quite a complex set of arrangements in relation to access. In other words, if the National Competition Council regards the Queensland access regime--that is, our current regime under our current legislation--to be ineffective in regulating access to the QR network, the NCC will not certify the regime. If it does not certify our regime, the NCC can declare the service itself--that is, it can take over the operation itself--and the NCC can declare any nationally significant infrastructure, even if it is totally within state borders, and hand over regulation to the ACCC, taking it away from the QCA.

The principal difference between the unamended Queensland regime and the federal regime is the trigger for intervention. The Queensland regime operates a proactive approach with the government having to identify key assets, make a declaration and provide a regulation for those assets to be considered for competition access regulation. The federal regime operates on a market failure basis so that when the parties have an unresolvable issue with access they can apply to the NCC for arbitration. So the Queensland regime sets out the principles. If you comply with those, you get access. The national regime opens the door for negotiations. If you cannot agree, you go for arbitration to the NCC. So it is quite complex but quite important to get that right and to understand that it also applies to both public and private monopolies. So the issue of ownership is not the thing that enlivens the jurisdiction; it is the issue of the monopoly service provider and whether it meets certain criteria that enlivens the jurisdiction.

There are a number of questions that the NCC asks when certifying a Queensland regime. It rests on the Queensland regime complying with what are called the clause 6 principles, which are incredibly long. I do not intend to go through them all, much to the relief of everyone in the House.
Government members: Hear, hear!
Mr NICHOLLS: However, if I am given some encouragement by those opposite I am more than willing to go through the five pages of clause 6 principles.
Mr Shine: That’s a threat.

Mr NICHOLLS: I hear the member for Toowoomba North, whose interest in trade practices law is well known to all those in the legal profession, and he wants to hear a little bit more about it. I can outline a few of them. They should incorporate the following principles: access to a service provided by means of a facility should be on the basis of terms and conditions agreed between the owner and the person seeking access--there is a blinding glimpse of the obvious if ever there was one; where such agreement cannot be reached, governments should establish a right for persons to negotiate access; there should be an enforcement process; it should include timing to make it certain; if the right lapses it should be clearly set out in the regime; they must use reasonable endeavours to accommodate the requirements of those seeking access; and it need not be on exactly the same terms and conditions as someone else who already has access to the service. You have to take into account: the owner’s legitimate business interests and investment in the facility, so that the owner of the service cannot be forced to give it away; the economic value to the owner of any additional service; the economically efficient operation of a facility; and a variety of other terms and conditions. So they all have to be met and those are the criteria against which the Queensland regime, as amended by this legislation when it passes, will be assessed. There is a certification guide for those criteria, and I can table that for the interest of the House. It is entitled ‘Certification of state and territory access regimes’, which I am sure the Treasurer will find incredibly useful reading. That is the guide upon which the Queensland access regime will be tested.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: National Competition Council document, dated May 2009, titled ‘Certification of State and Territory Regimes: A guide to Certification under Part IIIA of the Trade Practices Act 1974 (Cth), version 2.1’ [ 2853 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: During the briefing on the bill we were informed that the government took the view that the current access regime already would be considered to be or deemed to be an effective regime by the National Competition Council under the national access principles. I think, however, the Treasurer--and I think he has said it publicly--is of the view that the regime is effective. The question to be asked is: why did the government not apply for certification sooner after the September 2006 COAG meeting, where the decision for each state to apply for certification was taken? Why has it taken four years to bring these amendments forward to the House and apply for certification?

There are several proposed amendments to the act under this bill for the purposes of strengthening the access regime up to the level of national access regime. We are bringing the Queensland access regime up to the level of the national access regime so that we can keep control here in Queensland. These relate to increasing transparency and reducing the minister’s arbitrary powers, particularly the powers under regulation. They include the removal of the minister’s ability to declare services by regulation for which there were not clear criteria set out in the regulation; the removal of the candidate service requirement for ministerial declaration--as some service providers could have been declared as candidate services before actually being declared; provision of more explicit guidance for matters to be considered by the ministers when making an access code--and they are set out in the legislation and I think there are four or five of those items that need to be considered by the minister; and removal of the ability to exclude by regulation particular services and facilities from the regime.

These amendments simply need to be made in order to strengthen Queensland’s hand to ensure that Queensland keeps the power to regulate Queensland Rail under the Queensland Competition Authority Act. We do not believe that the access regime should be handed over to the ACCC. We believe that the access regime should remain under the control of the Queensland Competition Authority working with a properly structured act.

However, I think there is some opportunity to also move further than has been suggested in the current bill--and this is something worthy of further debate, not of action today. That is, with the increased powers and responsibilities given to the Queensland Competition Authority, we may wish to consider and review the way in which the QCA board is appointed. There may be some opposition there to reconsider the appointment of people to the QCA board potentially on the recommendations of, say, the Economic Development Committee of the parliament or with referral to the Economic Development Committee of parliament rather than by the executive. We might be able to see some improvements in the way people are appointed to the board and the appropriate credentials given to people who sit on that board. Perhaps the Treasurer may be prepared to give some thought to that suggestion.

There are several other amendments to the act designed to streamline the regulatory process. Many of these are uncontroversial. They are supported by both the Queensland Resources Council, which has made submissions on this legislation, and Asciano, which has also made submissions on the legislation. That is in response to the consultation paper issued by Treasury in June. These amendments include the introduction of a pre-expiry review of declarations, which is about providing certainty for investors so that people know that a system is still going to be in place when they come back to invest in it; clarification in the objects clauses so that it is made clear that the regime is intended to apply to significant infrastructure, not just any infrastructure--it has to be significant, not just something that the government feels it may want to regulate; and the introduction of a process for amendment or revocation of an access determination. At the moment, once they are made you are stuck with them; you cannot change them. The amendments also include streamlining the approval process for determinations and undertakings which are given as a result of the operation of the regime; clarification of the application of provisions relating to extensions to a facility--that is, building more on to a declared facility, and not just extending it but actually making it a newer, bigger and better facility on the way through; introduction of a six-month time limit for declaration recommendations to get the QCA to actually make its recommendations to the minister about a declaration; and some other amendments that go to improving the process.

There has also been the introduction of additional provisions relating to the prevention of anticompetitive behaviour by vertically integrated access providers. That is Queensland Rail’s concern. These amendments will allow the QCA to deal with any attempts by access providers to ‘game’ the process and to stall a decision being made by the QCA. Those tactics can lead to a considerable economic loss to the state, where markets can change dramatically in a very short period. For example, if the price for coal suddenly goes through the roof and we do not have economically efficient access to a rail network, the state of Queensland misses out. It is not just the company that misses out. We all miss out, because there is not a competitive network to get the coal from the mines to the ports and, in the case of Dalrymple Bay, to get the coal loaded on to the ships and out of the place. That can apply equally to agricultural products. If the price of a particular agricultural product goes through the roof and we need to move it quickly, we do not want to be stalled for two years waiting for an access undertaking to be developed.

In fact, that is one of the issues that has arisen with Queensland Rail. Work on its access undertaking has been underway for over two years. We still do not have a revised and final access undertaking, which is making life difficult for the authority and probably for the minister, and is not an ideal state of affairs that should be allowed to continue. As I said earlier, effectively through these amendments we are trying to resolve a turf war in favour of access of the Queensland Competition Authority access regime. That is where the amendments ultimately are directed. We can see that because of the Queensland government’s own submission to the National Competition Council, that the regime we have in place, together with the amendments contained in this bill, are sufficient to be declared an effective regime.

I turn to the third part of the legislation, which is the amendment of the transport infrastructure component of the bill. It provides changes to the structure of the QR Network Board. It is about providing that members of the QR Network Board, which establishes the ability to access the rail network and particularly the Central Queensland coal rail network, do not act solely in the interests of their own business, QR National, which also runs a coal freight business on top. This legislation excludes from the position of director of QR Network anyone who is involved in the executive management of QR National. While that is understandable in terms of the policy position, a question that has not been answered in respect of this is why are only members of the executive management of QR National excluded from the board of QR Network? Surely there ought to be some provision in place that ensures that board members of QR National are also not on the board of QR Network, because presumably their obligation is the same, which is to ensure that QR National makes the best return it can if it is a private operation. That is the duty of directors. Other provisions in the legislation relate to arms-length transactions, but we could certainly look at this aspect of the legislation to see if we can strengthen the provisions to prevent any anticompetitive behaviour being entered into in terms of the allocation of space on the network to competitors or to QR National.

In a vertical monopoly, actions of the board could exclude a competitor. In fact, that is one of the great fears of the federal government, as reflected in the comments made by Minister Albanese and Minister Ferguson in correspondence with the Treasurer and in their public statements, that is, the control by a vertically integrated monopoly and actions taken by a vertically integrated monopoly that would stop proper access to third parties to the network. The Treasurer may be able to address that issue.

The bill also affects Queensland Motorways Ltd and entrenches the last round of massive toll rises for the Gateway and Logan motorways. The shadow minister for main roads and transport will discuss these in greater detail. However, I would like to make these comments: firstly, in Queensland only one side of politics has ever removed a toll and that is the conservative side of politics. The Borbidge-Sheldon government removed the toll on the Sunshine Motorway, as I said at the beginning of the debate. The Bjelke-Petersen government duplicated the bridge to Redcliffe and removed the toll on the Hornibrook Bridge. Sir John Chandler, a member of a party that was a forerunner to the Liberal Party in Brisbane, removed the toll on the Story Bridge and the Nicklin government removed the toll on the Walter Taylor Bridge at Indooroopilly.

There is no doubt that tolls and increasing tolls is in Labor’s DNA. With the changes in the bill before the House today, we will see an entrenchment of the tolls and the toll increases on the Gateway and Logan motorways for the foreseeable future. With that, this government cements its reputation as being the party that hits up motorists the most with increased costs and charges. Whether it is increasing fuel prices, increasing rego costs or increasing transfer duty, one thing is unarguable, that is, this government hates the internal combustion engine and anyone who seeks to use it to get around this state.

In summary, this bill potentially provides a saving for motorists of up to $24 on the cost of CTP. However, again it demonstrates Labor’s unfriendly attitude to the business sector, particularly motor dealers, and it highlights the hypocrisy of taking more with one hand, as CPI increases in registration fees are grabbed by the government, and giving away someone else’s money with the other. It shows the access regime in Queensland is flawed and needs to be changed if Queensland is to retain its supervisory powers over monopoly infrastructure, whether that infrastructure is privately or publicly owned, and it hypocritically pretends to protect motorists from increased tolls while, at the same time, entrenching the last round of increases of up to 33 per cent in some instances. Because of the savings it potentially offers motorists, because of the need to preserve Queensland’s control of access to the regime and because of the limit, however belated, on future toll increases, we will not be opposing the bill.

Ms SIMPSON (Maroochydore--LNP) (3.16 pm): The Motor Accident Insurance and Other Legislation Amendment Bill makes three primary changes and a number of miscellaneous changes. The first change is to the competition legislation to improve third-party access arrangements, particularly with rail, port and other monopoly services, attempting to keep control in Queensland under the Queensland Competition Authority. The second change is to amend compulsory third-party arrangements to ban commissions and the third change proposes to stop increases of more than the CPI on tolls after the asset sale.

Queensland motorists are now the heaviest taxed in Australia, thanks to the waste and mismanagement of this state Labor government. We have seen this state Labor government mislead the people of Queensland and get rid of the petrol tax rebate, resulting in Queenslanders paying about $500 million a year. This came on top of huge hikes in registration charges of about 34 per cent over two years and toll hikes of more than 30 per cent, although that increase is even higher for commercial class vehicles. Over the next few years the cost of a new five-year driver’s licence will double to more than $150, again thanks to the waste and mismanagement of a project that this government said would save people money.

It is pretty rich for a Labor government to tell the private sector to be competitive and pass on savings when it does not know how to do that itself. Essentially, the government wants the insurance sector to be more competitive, cut its costs and pass those savings on to motorists, but we see the complete opposite happening when it comes to how the government runs its own business. It is wantonly abusing the public purse. It does not know how to manage taxpayer money with respect. That has resulted in huge cost hikes. As I said, Queenslanders are now the heaviest taxed motorists in Australia. This bill proposes to cut commissions for compulsory third-party insurance, for a grand total saving of up to $27 for motorists. As I mentioned, Queenslanders now pay hundreds of dollars extra thanks to the government, so it seems like a very small reprieve from the costs that they are paying as a result of this government’s mismanagement.

I will now address the issue of tolls. This legislation seeks to entrench the current costs to be capped at CPI into the future, after the motorway is sold. However, we should not let the public forget what has happened with increases in charges. Unfortunately, an increase in a toll will not come back before the parliament as a regulation that can be potentially disallowed. The government released a gazettal notice on 18 June 2010 that resulted in a significant increase in costs.

The reason the government whacked up the tolls was not so that motorists would get better services and outcomes. If they believed that it was delivering better services and outcomes by collecting more money, wouldn’t they have done some cost-benefit analysis? Wouldn’t they have looked at what the impact would be of people avoiding the tolls in order to protect their hip pocket because people are really struggling? No, there was no cost-benefit analysis done in regard to the impact of people who were going to rat run around the tolls. I asked the question of the main roads minister and he had to admit that the government had done no studies into what the impact would be of people avoiding the tolls.
I want to tell the story of one owner-driver who is typical of so many others who have contacted me following the huge increase in tolls under this government. The letter states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I am a owner driver in Brisbane. I have only 1 truck but as I sub contract to a company that deals with freight out of the Port Of Brisbane. Myself as well as 3-400 other drivers are hurting very badly because of the rising of the toll costs. Most of us have gone from paying $2.95 per each way on the gateway to $10.20 each way. The feeling out there with these increase of costs are crippling us. We have gone from making a living down to just surviving.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The increase in the tolls has been about 350 per cent for this particular driver. The letter goes on--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Bligh has just made a decision and that’s it, not thinking about how it is going to hurt the transport industry. I also have approached small and medium sized businesses and they have told me about trying to cover these costs as some customers are dealing with other companies as they are not prepared to pay the tolls to get their freight over the bridge or down thru the logan motorway as they also have gone for most of us from $2.00 to $6-6.40 per pass thru the beacons.

There are many drivers out there that will be selling their vehicles as they have told me that they won’t be able to go on ... as we have just had enough, as I said with Ms Bligh putting these increases as well as registration and any other cost she can throw at as most of us will fold very soon.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is just one letter. It disturbs me that this government that claims to be about looking after the workers has completely forgotten those who are least able to carry those costs. Some of these trucks will be paying smaller trucks that are still caught in the class 4 category and will be paying exactly the same as the very biggest trucks, the B-doubles, but there is no consideration of that.

This government in all that it does is about gouging motorists and gouging the business community but not about cutting its own cloth. These increases are having an impact on people, but the money is not even flowing back into our roads. I heard this morning the main roads minister get up and talk about road programs and warning of potential cuts. He did not mention once that under his watch in this last budget, despite the biggest increase in registration and despite the gouging of motorists with petrol costs, this government has actually cut the roads budget by a quarter of a billion dollars--$250 million has been taken out of the Main Roads budget. So it does not wash when this government says that these increases in charges are about helping the motorists. I think people have had enough of this kind of help, because they are really hurting.

I am going to table an explanation for the increases in the toll classes. For class 1, there has been a 41 per cent increase in fees; for class 2, it is a 31 per cent increase in tolls; for class 3, 96 per cent; and for class 4, 39 per cent. But accumulatively, as I said, some operators have borne a far greater increase. That is why they have said that they will be avoiding the tolls if they can, but some businesses find that very difficult to do and they will find it very difficult to pay those costs. I table that document.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Document detailing the toll charges for various classes of vehicles on toll roads [ 2854 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: As has been said, this legislation before the parliament is not about assets sales. We have made it very clear that we do not support this Labor government’s proposed sale of Queensland’s assets. We stand against the sale of Queensland Rail, the motorways and the forestry. It is a fire sale and one that is not being done in the best interests of Queensland. This government is in fact selling off the house to pay the grocery bill. It does not have a plan in place to reduce the debt. It is interesting that the government has threatened its own backbenchers that if the privatisation of these assets does not go ahead then they will not get some particular project in their electorate. Every which way you turn, the government has another excuse for which project it says will not go ahead. The government has even blamed current projects and that recurrent costs are dependent upon the assets sales. There has been an inconsistency in the argument of this government about asset sales.

The legislation before the House has raised issues of competition and these are the matters that we are addressing today, and they would occur regardless of assets sales in Queensland. I want to firstly refer to the warnings of the federal Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Anthony Albanese, and his office about the way this government has gone about the assets sales. Documents obtained under right to information have revealed that the Queensland government has been warned that the sale of QR will be detrimental to the Queensland resources sector. Minister Albanese’s office warned the Bligh government that the sale of QR will ‘result in higher costs for the resources sector and consequently less revenue for government’.

The minister’s office advised the Queensland government that its plan would ‘remove competition for above rail services’--that is, the freight haulage operations. The briefing note from Minister Albanese also warned that ‘while the basis for the sale of an integrated entity would potentially provide the highest upfront payment for a seller and facilitate a quick sale, it would be at the expense of a sound public policy outcome for competition and efficiency of the coal network in Queensland and is likely to reduce Queensland government income from the resources sector over time’. With advice from the federal minister that condemns the sale of Queensland Rail, the question to be asked is: why is Premier Anna Bligh not listening to this advice and going ahead with a sale that is not in Queensland’s best interests?

The provisions of this legislation do deal with issues of third-party access. I think they have been covered excellently by the shadow Treasurer. These are issues that were on the table prior to assets sales and in fact have been subject to COAG agreements up to four and five years ago in relation to improving the regime even for existing operators in the Queensland network. They are complex provisions. As we understand from the briefing and with regard to recent applications from operators, the intention here is to try to keep control of the access regime within the Queensland jurisdiction under the Queensland Competition Authority, as opposed to seeing that moved into the federal jurisdiction under the ACCC.

I want to address some of the other provisions in this legislation, particularly in regard to the Transport Infrastructure Act, and to note some of the other measures that are being amended. This legislation is supposed to enhance the governance of the QR Network Board from the QR National Group by requiring the majority of directors of the QR Network Board to be independent of the executive management of the QR National Group. As the shadow Treasurer has outlined, I think there are still some questions to be asked as to whether that is sufficient.

While the majority of directors of the QR Network Board have to be independent of the executive management, that does not mean that they all have to be. There is in fact still the potential for conflict and there are still issues as to how that is going to be managed practically. I seek the minister’s explanation in that regard. I think there has been some recent case history about subsidiary boards and some of the issues they face with regard to decision making which can have ramifications not only for the customers and the dealings of that entity but also practically for those directors in how they perform their duties. It is not enough just to have this requirement noted in legislation. I think the minister needs to give us an explanation as to how this is going to work practically.

There are also provisions in this legislation to preserve existing train paths for regularly scheduled passenger and non-coal freight train paths. The legislation also introduces a process by which the chief executive’s consent is required for the reallocation of a preserved train path. I seek an explanation from the minister as to the circumstances that are envisaged that require the reallocation of a train path. Obviously it is envisaged that not all preserved train paths will be set in concrete, so to speak, into the future and that there are circumstances in which they can be changed.

There has been a great deal of concern among existing industry that their difficulties in negotiating access to train paths are currently not being addressed. When we hear that consent to reallocate a train path is required of the chief executive it certainly flags that other changes will be flowing through.

One of the complaints we constantly hear from the livestock industry is that, while a service is promised, a service is not delivered. They are feeling very much disempowered as to how they effectively address that. When they turn up with their stock and are ready to load and they find that the train is not available, that is completely impractical. They cannot just load them back onto the trucks and send them back to where they came from. That lack of certainty with regard to service delivery and the ongoing changes--sometimes quite arbitrary changes--have made some of these services less and less viable for those who are seeking to access them.

That is a tragedy in this day and age when we want to see rail as an efficient operation that is available for more than just the biggest operators. If all the freight is dumped on our roads the public will realise pretty quickly that that is not to the broader community’s advantage. It is questionable whether there would be enough trucks to carry all of the livestock that are currently carried on trains.

There is great pressure on this industry to use trucks. The reality is that unless we see certainty of pathways that is more than just lip-service but is practical, has a high standard of service delivery and does not leave people in the lurch the way it has over the last six to 12 months--that is absolutely disgraceful--then this legislation does not mean anything. There has to be a genuine effort to provide a high standard of service delivery to those who are seeking to access rail rather than what we have seen happen to date where people have been left severely disadvantaged when services do not arrive and there seems to be a reallocation of those services to other parts of the network or certainly a lack of concern for investment in the network to ensure that customers have certainty about the way it is delivered.

As has been mentioned, this legislation has some extremely complex issues with regard to competition access. We are not opposing the parts of the legislation pertaining to insurance and tolls. However, we continue to raise our concerns about the policies of this government leading up to this legislation which cannot be addressed through this legislation but still ultimately leave Queenslanders really hurting in their hip pocket.

Mr EMERSON (Indooroopilly--LNP) (3.32 pm): What we see here today is another example of the Bligh government’s appalling management of the state’s finances and the endless rises in the cost of living for Queenslanders that Labor has caused. We will hear Labor MP after Labor MP say how they are helping struggling households by cutting CTP insurance by $24 a year. What they will not be so keen to talk about is the extra $220 a year that they are taking from Queensland motorists in increased taxes, fees and charges. On the one hand they are giving back 45c a day and, on the other hand, they are ripping out of the back pocket of Queensland motorists $220 a year.

This is what Premier Anna Bligh insists is good news for motorists. That is what she told the media--good news for motorists. Let us have a look at some of that good news for motorists from Premier Anna Bligh. The first of Labor’s good news for motorists is that Queensland has now become the most expensive state in Australia in which to own and run a car. Last year, motor vehicle registration rose by 17 per cent. This year it goes up by another three per cent. According to Labor, that is good news for motorists.

In the past two years alone, revenue collected from motor vehicle registration has risen by 30 per cent from $1.014 billion to an estimated $1.311 billion in 2010-11. Since 1 July it has cost $627 to register a large car in Queensland compared to $178 in Victoria and $246 in Tasmania. Vehicle registration fees now account for 13 per cent of the government’s total tax take and are one of the largest single source tax revenues.

One of the clearest examples of how much Queensland motorists are hurting is how many are late paying their registration fees. Hundreds of thousands of Queenslanders were hit with more than $27 million in late fees for failing to pay their annual vehicle registration bills on time. Motorists paid about 600,000 late payment fees of up to $48 each in the last financial year, funnelling in excess of $73,000 into state government coffers every day. That was a record number of defaults. This controversial fee, initially $40, was introduced by the state government in 2003 and rises with inflation annually. From 1 July it increased to $49 for vehicles and $12 for trailers and recreational ships.

But Labor’s good news for motorists does not stop at the rise in rego fees. While motorists are paying more, the government is allocating less of its resources to the road network. Spending on roads this year will fall by 6.6 per cent--down more than $232 million--while motorists will pay an extra $50 million in registration fees.

Let us have a look at some of Labor’s good news for motorists at the petrol bowsers. It is not just registration fees that are increasing the cost of living for Queenslanders. Queensland motorists have gone from paying the lowest petrol prices in Australia to paying the highest in the year since the Bligh government’s fuel tax was introduced. Monitoring by price watchdog FUELtrac and MotorMouth showed Brisbane had the highest average unleaded petrol price of all mainland capitals at $1.27 a litre in July. Let us not forget that this is a fuel tax the Bligh government ruled out.

The goods news Premier said, ‘I will not kick Queensland households when they are down and I will not abolish the petrol subsidy.’ The good news Treasurer said, ‘Make no mistake about it, we will be delivering a fuel subsidy scheme. It will stay in place.’ After the state election the good news team scrapped the fuel subsidy in the 2009-10 budget, costing Queensland motorists an extra 9.1c a litre in fuel.

So that is Labor’s good news for motorists--paying more for petrol. What about Labor’s good news for motorists crossing the Gateway Bridge? The government has lifted tolls across the Queensland Motorways network--up 30 per cent from $2.95 to $3.85 for a single Gateway Bridge crossing. There might be more Labor goods news ahead because the Bligh government has also developed detailed proposals to charge distance tolls to use major South-East Queensland roads, including charging motorists 12c a kilometre. The government has ruled it out, but can it be believed? It ruled out scrapping the petrol subsidy.

Finally, let us look at Labor’s good news for motorists when they are renewing their driver’s licence. A five-year licence will jump from the current $73.30 to $96 next year and to $152.50 by 2014-15--that is, equal highest cost in Australia. So this is Labor’s good news for motorists: increased registration fees; increased petrol prices; higher road tolls; and more expensive drivers’ licences. For Queenslanders the only good news for motorists will be when we get rid of this incompetent Labor government.

Mrs KIERNAN (Mount Isa--ALP) (3.38 pm): I rise to speak briefly to the Motor Accident Insurance and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. I say at the outset that I support this bill, which delivers premium savings to motorists. While banning the payment of commissions and other inducements to third parties is necessary to reduce CTP premiums and deliver real competition, the bill makes provision for policyholders to be able to pass on any incentives they receive to registered charities. Some CTP insurers have developed relationships with particular charities, offering donations to these registered charities in exchange for policyholders selecting that particular CTP insurer for the next registration renewal period. This bill allows that relationship to continue. Charities are able to receive vital funds which, in turn, are used to provide worthwhile community services. Importantly, though, these incentives can only be passed on at the request of the policyholder and cannot be charged back to the CTP business or taken into account in determining premiums.

One registered charity which I am aware of is Scripture Union Queensland. I am aware that this charity relies on inducements from CTP insurers as a valuable funding source for its school chaplaincy program. Scripture Union Queensland is a not-for-profit youth and children’s organisation and the largest employer of school chaplains in Australia, providing spiritual and emotional support to our school communities and a caring and valuable presence for our children. I want to take this opportunity to commend the wonderful work of the school chaplaincy program in schools in my electorate. The Cloncurry chaplaincy service, with new chaplain Jenny Pearce, has now been operating for some six years and I have seen firsthand the support and strong connection the chaplains have with the students and also with the community. The Cloncurry chaplaincy service has also gone from strength to strength because of the strong commitment of its community committee, led by Karen McGee. The annual fundraising dinner is supported strongly by businesses across the community and the community has embraced the chaplaincy service as a valuable service for young people in the town.

Three schools in Mount Isa benefit from the fantastic work of Mischa Grummitt, who, again, is strongly supported by the school communities of Spinifex Junior, Spinifex Senior and the Barkly Highway State School. Mischa is a great support person for the students. I know that Mischa relates well with the kids and helps them in all manner of ways. He is someone other than staff who can be turned to and is seen as a friend and mentor to many young people. Mischa holds a healthy breakfast morning at both schools throughout the year. Queensland core skills tests are happening for senior students at Spinifex Senior today and tomorrow. Mischa cooked bacon and eggs for brekkie at 7.30 this morning for Spinifex Senior students and will do the same tomorrow. He provides invaluable work, service and friendship to the young people in our community. I commend the government for acknowledging the financial pressures impacting on registered charities and taking action in allowing this small exemption to ensure that these organisations like Scripture Union and our chaplaincy service are not worse off. The reforms are a win for motorists and a win for our registered charities. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr WATT (Everton--ALP) (3.43 pm): After talking to residents of the electorate of Everton at mobile offices and around the electorate generally, there is no doubt that one of the main issues people have raised with me as the year has progressed is the cost-of-living pressure they are experiencing. Rates of unemployment are still relatively low in Queensland, and the government has been doing an excellent job of creating jobs--that is, for about 12 months in a row the government has actually created jobs in Queensland. That is an excellent record and is very largely attributable to the continuation of the government’s building program. Despite this good news in terms of unemployment, there are still undoubtedly many Queenslanders experiencing financial pressure, and that is certainly the case in the electorate of Everton.

In the last few days the Premier has again recognised this fact and has recommitted the government to taking action to help Queenslanders overcome the financial pressure that many of them are currently experiencing. This bill is one example of the government helping Queenslanders to make ends meet. Among other things, the bill bans commissions on compulsory third-party insurance premiums, and that is expected to equate to a reduction of about $24 per year in those premiums. I have heard a number of opposition members deride this commitment from the government and the action that is taken through this bill. They seem to regard this decrease as a paltry commitment from the government. I do not know about their electorates, but I can assure the House that people in the electorate of Everton welcome any savings they can make, whether they be $24 or $200. This is a good move on behalf of the government. There is no doubt that more can be done in this regard and, as I say, the Premier has said that this is an issue that the government is looking at. There is no doubt, though, that the reduction in compulsory third-party premiums that this bill ushers in is a very good start.

There are a number of other initiatives that the government currently has underway to assist Queenslanders who are experiencing financial pressure. Probably the one that is becoming best known is the Every Dollar Counts forums that have been held in a number of electorates around Queensland, and I am certainly intending to stage them in the electorate of Everton in the not-too-distant future. The government has done a good job of trying to pool together the various savings and rebates that are available to pensioners, seniors and other groups within our community. Again, this is an example that we are listening to the community and demonstrating that we do understand that people are experiencing financial pain at the moment and the government does have a role to play in helping them overcome that financial pressure.

There is no doubt that the cost-of-living issue is a big one in my electorate, and it is something that I continue to represent to the government on behalf of the residents of Everton. I am very pleased to speak in support of this bill because it is a good example of the government listening to that financial pressure and taking action to alleviate that pressure on Queenslanders. I commend the bill to the House.

Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP) (3.46 pm): When a government seeks to get a little mileage from a very broad area, it will try to secure guaranteed income from an area with good continued growth in its returns for very little input. Whatever happens, a government such as the Bligh government will try to maximise its own take and shed a few limited crumbs our way. Such are the lessons! This bill gives a pretty good template for what is going to be delivered by this government.

This bill is more than just a method of removing the commission payable on compulsory third-party insurance; it is really a series of four major steps that flow on from the flawed financial plan put forward by the Treasurer on behalf of this dying Labor government. As has been described by other speakers, those steps are (1) removing the $25 payment of commission and the trailing commission paid by customers for CTP; (2) updating third-party access in that it attempts to align the Queensland Competition Authority Act with national regimes; (3) resetting the rules allowing for price rises for tolls on the Logan and Gateway motorways to be limited to CPI after the government increased the tolls earlier this year so as to make the asset more saleable in this market; and (4) changes to the Transport Infrastructure Act 1994 specific to QR National’s corporate governance framework.

A few issues have been raised today about the $25 commission which, when removed, will make compulsory third-party premiums cheaper. This really does need to be cheaper because motor vehicle registration has been progressively ratcheted up as the government has become so desperate for cash and is now at the point where our motor vehicle registration is the most expensive in Australia. Our boats, motorcycles and trucks also have that dubious distinction. There is now also this ridiculous situation where a B-double actually costs more to register than a B-quad, when there is a 40-tonne difference. I wonder whether someone in the department is looking at the maths. However, saving $25 is critical to many households at any time--not just at this time--so this is welcome news to my constituents in Gaven particularly, and I am sure most members will express the same sentiments.

Sadly, many groups that receive income from trailing commissions include school chaplaincies, scripture services in schools and all manner of voluntary community support groups that will now miss out on this trailing income. There is also a further tragedy in that some motor dealers who have staff who exist on these incomes will lose their positions, and for some businesses there will be multiples thereof. I am very sorry to see those individuals lose their jobs at the stroke of a pen to justify a perception that this Labor government may have community interests as its major concern, but I wonder whether it does have a heart for these people. If this is the case, does one wrong deserve another?

I also note that the minister has stated in his second reading speech that the bill will permit policyholders to direct the payment of an inducement by an insurer to a registered charity, but will prohibit the practice of any type of trailing payments. By ticking the box annually, these charities or research entities may get an ongoing direct donation by the consumer at the time of the compulsory third-party payment. Trailing commissions have been a menace in the mobile phone business area. They have enriched some operators often at the expense of many small or unknowing consumers. So this amendment is to be supported.

The bill also amends the Queensland Competition Authority Act 1997 and in doing so allows the Queensland government to circumvent the federal competition policy. The bill will--and I quote from the minister’s second reading speech specifically--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... remove the ability for services to be declared or excluded from coverage by government regulation without the processes contemplated by the broader QCA regime.
XML.Hansard-Body: Furthermore, the minister stated that the bill--
