XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... will ensure there is a single and structured process for determining whether a service should fall within the scope of the third-party access regime.
XML.Hansard-Body: Therefore, because the National Competition Council--the NCC--will not consider an application where an effective state regime is already in place, broadly, this change exempts the state from NCC policy and only where nationally significant infrastructure is not included in those items, not state declared, then and only then can the NCC rules apply. The NCC is not removed by the process but is effectively excluded by those changes.

This is not trivial stuff here. We must all remember that pipelines, railway lines, shipping channels and electricity grids are relevant to all of us throughout the nation. We need a regulator and fairness needs to apply to all. There are plenty of examples overseas that are salient. Whilst it is an extreme case, Russia turned off the gas to the Ukraine primarily because it did not like the democratically elected government there. There was also extreme doubt about the validity that both the claim over an outstanding account and the reasonableness of a massive price rise over and above agreed prices was indeed fair. These things occur and sometimes common sense goes out the door. Ask Rio Tinto and BHP about the issue of below-rail assets in Western Australia. The NCC needs to be supported. The state should not need to exempt itself in any situation.

I have previously made the point about what happens to markets and exports where there is a denial of third-party access in practical terms. The best example is in the Elk Valley in Canada, where the Teck mining company has been restricted in increasing its volumes and other miners also have been excluded from shipping on the same line after the takeover of Canadian rail by a private consortium. Growth in that market for coal exports has been restricted to two per cent per annum for the last eight years when the global market demanded greater access to coal exports, particularly in the Canadian model. Canadian exports stalled and Australia made up the difference. Clearly, we must not constrain our own ability to build growth in this competitive market. In coal, we have significant global competition from South Africa, South America, Indonesia and central Africa increasingly. We must not underestimate the ability of these markets to overtake us. At present, coal and iron ore have enabled Australia to maintain three per cent annual growth.

Clearly, the bill is focusing on the intrastate rail network of QR, rail transport for specific coal deposits in the Central Queensland coal network and coal handling at the Dalrymple Bay Coal Terminal. I suspect there are a few others included and also excluded, but the Bligh government thinks that they are not needed because of the lack of linkage to their flawed assets sales program. Asciano’s application to have its access to the Queensland intrastate rail network handled under the federal competition regime is obviously the major reason for this change. The details of the issue relating to the Trade Practices Act 1974 under the federal law have been explained earlier by the shadow minister.

As has been stated, this act and its amendments are currently before the Commonwealth parliament. In short, these changes will ensure that only a certified access regime will be considered effective in the future and if the National Competition Council regards the Queensland access regime to be ineffective in regulating access to the QR network, then the NCC will not certify that regime. In effect, it then hands over the regulation to the ACCC, removing it from the QCA. The amendments in this bill have an intention of raising the existing regime to the level of the national access regime. In doing so, these changes primarily relate to increasing transparency and reducing the minister’s arbitrary powers.
I relate this change back to the minister’s second reading speech in which he states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: New provisions will reinforce existing obligations on access providers to not unfairly differentiate between access seekers both during negotiations and in the provision of access.
XML.Hansard-Body: This problem has come about only because of the Bligh Labor government’s desperation to save itself after blowing all the money on, basically, a nothingness. The minister is now going to enormous lengths to say that he, Treasurer, is going to vigilantly ensure--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... that monopoly infrastructure providers do not misuse their market power or engage in anticompetitive cost shifting.
XML.Hansard-Body: Yet at the same time, after a boost in the offered price for the below-rail coal assets of Queensland Rail, the Bligh Labor government is negotiating with a monopoly of coal companies to purchase this critical asset. It is the filthy lucre that is driving this Treasurer and Labor. Labor is petrified that the national regulator might not agree. It saw what happened in Western Australia when Rio and BHP sought to exclude Fortescue Metals from access to their rail. Labor thinks that this could seriously torpedo its sale and any potential blue sky price for the below-rail asset.

Currently, fear is ruling Labor’s decisions. All Labor’s decisions are made in an environment of fear because it alone created the crisis that led to this sense of fear. Does Labor really think that having a captive board of QCA Labor stooges will pass the acid test of probity in this matter? Honourable members, fear is a dreadful motive to activate a plan. Good decisions are made in an environment of confidence and prudence, not in a panic. The QCA board will work only if it is truly impartial and fearless.

Is Labor ready for this? I do not think it is. There is no evidence anywhere else where there are contentious issues. I highlight the dying CMC as it muddles along on its present confused path. Do members know anything of the features of a dying organisation? They are the same as a dying government: resignations, unhappiness, leaks, cost overruns, inability to complete even simple tasks and open disputes of leadership. The changes to the QCA Act are reasonable. Even Asciano supports them. We support these amendments as well, since efficiency and access will improve.

The third major changes are the changes that prepare QR National for sale, but they are an each-way bet since they make changes that separate the corporate structure into a form that will allow the separation of above-rail and below-rail assets. I say that this is an each-way bet, because the certainty that the Premier and Treasurer talked of when selling QR originally has now changed, because QR National is not only minus the passenger network but also the issue of the above-rail asset appears to have evaporated as well. Why? Because Labor’s core constituency will not support that and Labor thinks that it can get away with selling below rail as it is so different from selling a monopoly toll road that can earn hundreds of dollars every second. The only difference is that road users are private--car owners or truck owners--and in this case the government remains potentially the above-rail owner. Honourable members, these critical state assets--the QR network--are unlocked and these changes are at a once-only price of $5 billion and they are gone. I struggle to believe that, by excluding the freight and above-rail assets of QR National, the consortium will take on the rumoured $1.7 billion of debt. I doubt that it will. Asciano has a legitimate concern about this being an outcome, because it will restrict its overall growth. That is why it has proceeded on its current path. It is considered that the members of this purchasing consortium have form in this market.

Let us look at the international comparisons of the sale of vertically integrated rail monopolies. The most recent one is the sale of the Burlington Northern Santa Fe, which was purchased for US$25 billion, which is $30 billion Australian in a critical market. It has competitors in 70 per cent of its market and it is roughly comparable in terms of transport. It was purchased by the world’s most successful 20th century--now 21st century--investor, Warren Buffett. Why is QR selling its below-rail assets at 15 per cent of the price of equivalent first-tier railway global assets in a global economy?

I will give members a clue--because Labor has no idea what it is doing. It understands nothing of business, it understands nothing of what assets should be sold and how to evaluate them. Here today the Premier confused the issues of governing and a government’s right to dispose of a major state asset without the agreement of the public. She failed to understand the difference between second-tier assets and first-tier assets. But critically she failed to understand what must be done with the money received from such a massive decision. She used the example of Suncorp Metway as a non-monopoly financial provider that ended up being sold in part into private hands. Largely it occurred as a result of the collapse of building societies in a credit crunch in Queensland and the merging of the entity that was created by Premier Ryan to improve public access of homeowners to a mortgage with affordable insurance.

These assets are completely different. The sale of rail in the UK and New Zealand was nothing short of a national disaster for both and it will be so here at a critical time of coal market expansion in the global market. The three biggest coalmines at Alpha, operated by Hancock Prospecting, Waratah Coal and a currently unnamed entity will double the state’s output. They will also double the average rail tonnage carried. Honourable members need to remove their blinkers here. If one sectional group owns the critical pipes that carry these assets it will try to limit access so as to raise its own returns on investment and restrict competition.

Currently the public of the state of Queensland is the monopoly owner and we have the ability to grow the market responsibly and control somewhat that growth as it occurs and critically, like a toll road, take a small commission on every tonne mined and transported. This is not market power; this is the concept of mining the market. There is a difference. We must be smart. Just as increasing toll charges for toll roads just in time for their sale, as occurred in this bill, is wrong, it is wrong to jettison the key state national earning asset at a time of almost exponential growth in the export coal market on the network.

The mining sector in Australia, if people do not realise, earned 40 per cent of all company tax profits in the June quarter but is only 7 per cent of the economy. Overwhelmingly in Queensland that is significant. This bill is an enabler bill that has been introduced purely to address an asset sale that will collapse a government. It has led to the downfall of a first-term federal Labor government. There is no clear statement as to exactly where the money from these asset sales will go, nor is there any message other than fear and panic. The impact of the loss of the AAA credit rating has destroyed much of Labor’s will to go on. These asset sales will do nothing to ease the pain of the last few years, nor restore public confidence in the integrity of Labor governments. Critically, this bill is attached to the Treasurer and it is he to whom the public will attach much of their angst for his role in this debacle. There will be little leeway for penance nor forgiveness. The hostility is, and will be, palpable. It will ultimately destroy much of the critical Labor players’ confidence in themselves and also any legacy they wish to leave as a mark of their time in government. In 1957 the same thing happened as the knives sharpened for those who could be blamed. The bloodletting was awful. It is coming again. History constantly repeats itself.

Ms BATES (Mudgeeraba--LNP)
(4.03 pm): I rise today to contribute to the debate on the Motor Accident Insurance and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. The objective of the bill is to reduce delivery and acquisition costs and promote greater price competition within the CTP scheme so as to deliver premium savings to motor vehicle owners throughout Queensland. The bill updates the state’s third-party access regime. It also clarifies and strengthens the regime to reflect the changing nature of investment and competition in regulated infrastructure services.

The main reason for the bill came after a review of the compulsory third-party scheme recently conducted by the Motor Accident Insurance Commission which identified high policy and acquisition costs associated with the scheme. Payment of commissions and other inducements by insurers to motor dealers and insurance brokers has increased significantly over a number of years. This in turn has led to an increase in CTP premiums for Queensland motorists and has prevented many smaller insurance companies from being able to compete with the larger providers. Stopping these types of payments will improve efficiencies in the CTP scheme and deliver much needed savings to motor vehicle owners.

The $24 saving will be well received by Queensland motorists. However, Queenslanders are sick and tired of the Bligh Labor government giving with one hand and taking away with the other. I have outlined on many occasions previously in this House the ever-increasing costs of operating a motor vehicle here in Queensland. There was a time when Queensland held the great monicker of being the cheapest state in which to own and operate a motor vehicle. Sadly, this title is long gone and forgotten as we take on the unwanted title of now being the most expensive state in which to own, operate and register a motor vehicle.
As reported on the Brisbane Times website in May 2009, motorists would bear the full impact of this government’s mismanagement of our economy. The website reports--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The peak motoring body also accuses the state government of being coy about the true impact of rises in vehicle registration already announced by the Bligh government and due to become effective on July 1.

Car owners will be paying between $45 and $113 more for registration from July 1 ... The increases will net the government $194 million towards a $14 billion shortfall blown in the state budget ... After July 1 it will cost $627 to register a large car in Queensland, compared to $178 in Victoria and $246 in Tasmania. We’re currently the most expensive state or territory in which to register a motor vehicle.
XML.Hansard-Body: It is ironic that the Treasurer can stand in this House to espouse the benefits of delivering this saving on CTP insurance, but it is the same Treasurer who has presided over increased fuel costs, licence renewals and overall registration costs. In the past two years under this Bligh Labor government car registration has gone up by a massive 27 per cent. This increase has put further pressure on struggling families, but is only the tip of the iceberg when it comes to increased fees and charges that the average family now has to deal with.

Conversely, one would expect to see an increase in funding to Main Roads. Unfortunately, this is not the case. In this year’s budget, Main Roads’ funding was cut by $250 million. Our car registrations have increased but our road funding has gone down. These moneys should have been reinvested in our roads. How will the extra $24 help families at the fuel bowsers after this government put a 10c per litre fuel tax on all Queenslanders? The Bligh Labor government went to the last election misleading voters that they would not apply a fuel tax and, as we all know, as soon as the election was over fuel went up by 10c a litre. Using that $24 for fuel at an average rate of $1.20 would only buy 20 litres of fuel. That is not much for the average family in my area who has to travel to the opposite side of the M1 daily to drop their children to the state high schools east of the M1 because there is no high school west of the M1. It is not a lot either for motorists who queue on the M1 for up to an hour in peak traffic times just to get to work. Many of them sit in their cars wondering where the increase in fees is being invested. They have been promised for years eight lanes all the way to the New South Wales border, but as the price of registration, fuel and licences goes up, they still sit in traffic on the M1.
Further to the increased cost in registration and fuel, the hits to the family budget just keep coming. As reported in the Brisbane Times on 12 May 2010--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The price of a new five-year licence will initially rise from $73.30 to $96.05, before escalating again to $152.50 in 2014.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: That is an overall increase of a massive 108 per cent. The article continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The cost will be even greater for truck drivers who will need a separate heavy vehicle licence under the new system. The price increase is the latest hit for the state’s drivers, after hefty registration cost increases came into effect last year, while the government scrapped the fuel subsidy.
XML.Hansard-Body: Increase after increase has been putting further pressure on struggling families and senior citizens. In addition, Queenslanders have had to cope with the increases in water and electricity charges and additional red tape, making life very difficult for many families to make ends meet. What other surprises and increases does this government have in store for us for the remainder of its term in government? This is a government that has a proven track record of backroom deals and continual spin. How can we trust it not to put prices up next month to try to fill the ever-increasing black hole which is the current Queensland Treasury coffers? This government went bust in a boom. It misled voters at the last election and cannot be trusted not to add further to the burdens it has already placed on working families.

The LNP has made public our policy to freeze registrations for our entire first term in government. Unlike those opposite, we understand the pressure that these and other increases have put on working families. Labor has lost touch with its core values to support working families. This can clearly be seen by the backlash from voters Labor copped at the polls in the recent federal election. The Premier said today that she is listening to the voters of Queensland and has heard their message. Labor and the Premier are not listening to their calls not to sell off our assets; they are not listening to Queenslanders’ cries for some relief to rising bills. The Premier does not even listen to her own unions, let alone the rest of Queensland.

If the Premier was listening she would not continue with the push to sell off Queenslanders’ assets without their permission. Labor just does not care about Queensland anymore. Its members are drunk on their own power. As an election gets closer and closer, Labor’s days of total disregard for the voting public of Queensland are numbered.

Ms JOHNSTONE (Townsville--ALP)
(4.09 pm): I am pleased to take part in the debate on the Motor Accident Insurance and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. During the budget sittings this year the Treasurer announced that the government intended to amend legislation to ensure that compulsory third-party insurance premiums offered to all Queensland motor vehicle owners is as competitive and, as a subsequence, as affordable as possible.

I am pleased to see reforms proposed to the CTP scheme that focus on the underwriting of the business. I recall that a number of years ago government had to bring in scheme reforms to keep CTP premiums affordable. At that time the entitlements of injured people were impacted. It is most appropriate that in a compulsory insurance product like CTP there is a focus on what insurers do and the costs they pass on to motor vehicle owners.

Most people would agree with me that at the time of purchasing a new vehicle the customer is not given the option to select a CTP insurer. When they pick up the vehicle, it is registered and the CTP insured, all arranged by the motor dealer. It is only when the new car owner receives the registration papers that they notice who their CTP insurer is. Those customers would also not be aware that, for the simple process undertaken by the motor dealer in nominating a CTP insurer as part of the registration process, the motor vehicle dealer is paid a commission by the CTP insurer. I understand that commission is generally five per cent of the CTP premium, although there have been reports of levels reaching seven per cent. Added to this, though, is the common practice of trailing commissions, which means that the commission continues to be paid on an annual basis to the motor dealer until such time as the owner selects a different insurer.

Equally, the consumer would not be aware that the costs of these commissions and other inducements provided by the insurer to the motor dealer are a cost to the CTP scheme and, ultimately, as a subsequence are borne by all motor vehicle owners in their CTP insurance premiums. I know that some motor dealers are of the opinion that they should receive payment for registering a vehicle for a customer. It is my view that any such payment, if required, should be determined by agreement between the dealer and their customer rather than being funded through the CTP premiums paid by all Queensland motor vehicle owners.

I understand that some motor dealers already charge the purchaser an administration fee as a separate charge for registering the vehicle. It is my opinion that this seems to be a more transparent way to show the customer what it is they are paying for and in fact receiving by way of services from motor dealers. When considering the situation in other jurisdictions we find that, other than New South Wales, no state or territory in Australia allows for the payment of commissions on CTP insurance. No state or territory government pays a fee to a motor dealer for registering a vehicle.

Having access to independent transport is of huge importance to many Queenslanders and, of course, to people in my electorate of Townsville. I am also very aware of the costs associated with owning and running a car and the impact that these have on families who do count every dollar within their family budget. I hope that the charges proposed in this bill will not only provide a reduction in costs for all motor vehicle owners but also provide easier access to information about the way CTP choices are put to new vehicle owners.

I commend the Treasurer on implementing these reforms, which will reduce delivery costs in the CTP scheme by banning the payment of these hidden fees that have been subsidised by all motor vehicle owners. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr POWELL (Glass House--LNP) (4.12 pm): I rise today to speak on the Motor Accident Insurance and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. As mentioned by previous speakers and as outlined in the explanatory notes, this bill has three significant elements and a number of other minor amendments. Importantly, the bill aims to reduce delivery and acquisition costs and promote greater price competition within the CTP scheme so as to deliver premium savings to motor vehicle owners. It also updates the state’s third-party access regime, contained in part 5 of the Queensland Competition Authority Act 1997. To complement the enhancements to the QCA Act, the bill will also make amendments to the Transport Infrastructure Act 1994 which are specific to QR National’s corporate governance framework.

As mentioned, the bill also makes further amendments to the TI Act in the following areas: it strengthens the existing provisions dealing with priority for regularly scheduled passenger services; it inserts new provisions into the TI Act to preserve existing passenger and non-coal freight train paths; and it enshrines in legislation the government’s rather belated commitment that future toll increases on the Gateway Motorway, the gateway extension motorway and the Logan Motorway of Queensland Motorways Ltd will be limited to the annual consumer price index.

Other speakers have addressed--and no doubt further speakers will also address--the elements of the bill that pertain to CTP, asset sales and increases to tolls. So I would like to focus my comments on the changes to the Queensland Competition Authority Act, the QCA Act. Competition policy in Queensland has been developed with the assistance of the 1995 competition policy agreement drawn up by COAG. The agreement required the Commonwealth government to assist states and territories in their development of third-party access regimes. As noted in the government’s June consultation paper--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Third party access regimes create a regulatory framework to enable fair and reasonable access by third parties to significant natural monopoly infrastructure facilities such as electricity grids, gas pipelines, rail tracks and port channels. Access regulation is intended to apply where owners or operators of natural monopoly infrastructure have the potential to exercise market power by denying access to their facilities or charging excessive prices, thereby hindering or preventing competition within a dependent market.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: As the consultation paper goes on to state, establishing legislation that protects the right to seek access to such services is, therefore, imperative.
XML.Hansard-Body: Queensland’s third-party access regime is modelled on part 3A of the Commonwealth Trade Practices Act 1974 and it has been in place for more than a decade. As such, it was based on an environment in which eligible infrastructure facilities were predominantly publicly owned with limited private investment. Accordingly, it was envisaged that third-party access regulation would almost exclusively be applied to publicly owned facilities. Since the nineties there has been an increasing prevalence of private investment in these significant infrastructure facilities. The bill therefore seeks to update and enhance the regime to reflect these changes and provide increased certainty for regulated businesses and their customers. As contained in the explanatory notes, the bill will achieve this by: making it more explicit that the regime only applies to services provided by significant infrastructure facilities; introducing a pre-expiry review to assess whether significant infrastructure should again be declared; being more explicit on the matters the ministers must consider when making an access code; and removing deemed decision for access declarations. The bill, it is suggested by the government, will also improve efficiency through promoting more timely regulatory processes.

In making these changes the bill must also make amendments to the TI Act, specifically around the vertically integrated operations of QR National. The original proposals as circulated in the consultation paper earlier this year included that the majority of directors of QR Network’s board must be independent of the executive management of the QR group; that access agreements between QR Network and its related entities must be approved in advance by the QR Network board; and that the directors of QR Network must not approve an access agreement with QR National unless the directors are reasonably satisfied the agreement is at arm’s length.

It is interesting to note that, unlike the pronounced and now substantiated amendments to the QCA Act, these proposals were not supported by either the Queensland Resources Council or Asciano, a transport company that includes Pacific National rail operation and Patrick ports and stevedoring businesses. In its submission the Queensland Resources Council states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: QRC considers that the proposed amendments to the TIA, in their current form, will not achieve their intended purpose of ensuring ‘the independence of the QR Network Board from the QR Group’. Consistent with past commercial and policy practice, QRC will be looking to the State Government to address specific matters relating to QR National’s vertically integrated structure and consequential perverse ownership incentives, including the extraction of monopoly profits from the supply chain by withholding investment or delaying infrastructure expansions, to be addressed within the network lease agreement between the State and QR National.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Asciano was stronger in its objection, stating--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... there are a number of areas where the amendments are not sufficient to prevent anti competitive behaviour by incumbent monopolists. In particular, the non discrimination and governance controls around QRNetwork are ineffective and the term of the declaration is inadequate.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Asciano continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The corporate governance controls are ineffective. In particular a director of a QRNational company can be a director of QRNetwork and the board of directors of QRNetwork can take into account the interests of a QRNational company in addition to its own interests in making decisions. This governance framework facilitates and encourages QRNetwork to prefer the interests of its related above rail operator over those of third party rail operators. At a minimum there needs to be a majority of independent directors on the QRNetwork board, with independent meaning independent from any QR related companies.
XML.Hansard-Body: It appears the government was listening--at least in this instance and perhaps for a change--for the final amendments we see in this legislation will enhance the governance of the QR Network board from the QR National group by requiring the majority of directors of the QR Network board to be independent of the executive management of the QR National group and prevent QR Network directors from approving an access agreement with QR National unless they are reasonably satisfied the agreement is on arm’s lengths terms.

As I said earlier, establishing legislation that protects the right to seek access to significant natural monopoly infrastructure facilities is imperative. It is also imperative that monopolies such as QR Network are transparent and seen to be independent in their decision making around such access decisions. It appears that this bill may improve our state’s legislative response to these imperatives.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM (Gladstone--Ind) (4.20 pm): I rise to speak to the Motor Accident Insurance and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. The first part of the bill is the matter about which the Treasurer made significant announcements during the budget, in relation to vehicle owners in the state of Queensland receiving $20 extra a year because of the changes to CTP insurance. Naturally, motor dealers throughout Queensland reacted to that press release. In my electorate, two representatives from a very reputable, family owned company spoke to me and I place on the record their concerns in relation to the changes to the CTP scheme. If you asked any person in Queensland whether they wanted an extra $20 in their pocket, even though that is a relatively small amount of money, they would say, ‘Of course I do’. However, it is important to place on the record the feelings of the motor dealers in relation to the impact on them and on jobs. I quote from an email that I received from those two dealers. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Please find attached the Treasurer’s Media Release regarding the changes to CTP which I would like to discuss with you.

The changes have enormous implications to Motor Dealerships state wide. I have had discussions with Suncorp Insurance over the past week and the estimate that the Insurance industry has put on these changes is 10 million dollars which will be taken out of the Qld Motor Vehicle Industry. This in turn means hundreds of jobs will disappear within Motor Dealerships in Qld over the next 3 months as the change comes into effect.
In our case alone the difference will amount to $125,000, which means 3 staff members.

The changes amount to nothing more than trying to pull the wool over Queenslander’s eyes. The Government has been increasing their fees over the last few years at astronomical rates, and now expect businesses to drop their fees to make the Government look good. The changes will save a motorist around $20... but cost Queenslander’s hundreds of jobs.
XML.Hansard-Body: Subsequent to receiving the email, I met with those dealers. They spoke of the pressures on the motor industry over the past short while. They raised the fact that since the withdrawal from the country of finance companies GMAC and GE, there has been an increase in interest rate charges for floor plan financing. They went on to explain the implications on their ability to employ staff. They said that three of their staff members were directly involved in the organisation of CTP and registration. They have a close relationship with and, indeed, act as an agent for Queensland Transport, and those staff members do that work. I asked whether there was any other benefit to the motor dealerships as a result of a close association with one or other insurance company. They acknowledged that they received ‘a good deal’ on their insurance because of that close relationship. That needs to be put on the record. Certainly in Queensland and in my electorate motor dealers are feeling the pressures because of these changes. It is very difficult to vote against the proposal, simply because in Queensland many families--indeed, most families--are struggling under the increased costs that particularly the state government has imposed on them.
In June I wrote to the Treasurer, asking a number of questions. I asked--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Could you clarify the following matters please?
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • What consultation has occurred with the Motor Traders Association or other representatives of the motor vehicle industry?
• In the formation of this policy, was there any consultation with the Insurance industry?
• What consideration has been given to the impact of the loss of the benefit to motor traders--ie payment of a commission by insurers for directing CTP cover to them by motor traders?
• Has a quantitative study been done in relation to potential job losses in the motor industry...
• Will this change impact on local Departments of Transport offices? Will constituents have to travel to Departmental offices to organise CTP thus offsetting any benefit to consumers?
• When is it proposed to introduce the bill to Parliament?
XML.Hansard-Body: The Treasurer replied, stating--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... the Queensland Government held concerns as to the cost efficiency of the CTP scheme, as these costs are ultimately borne by motor vehicle owners in the form of higher premiums. In what was envisaged as a competitive premium band model, CTP insurers have in recent times consistently priced at the ceiling set by the scheme’s regulator, the Motor Accident Insurance Commission (the Commission). Of particular concern were the costs associated with the payment of commissions to intermediaries like motor dealers by CTP insurers. Not only has this given rise to higher CTP premiums, it has caused significant barriers for new entrants to the scheme or those insurers wanting to build market share. This also hinders price competition.

I can assure you that the Government and the Commission in its statutory capacity has had ongoing consultation with CTP insurers throughout the review process and following the budget announcement. Similarly the Commission invited and received a submission from the Motor Trades Association of Queensland (MTAQ) during the review process. Since the budget announcement, there has been further consultation with MTAQ and other stakeholders.

I acknowledge the potential impact on motor vehicle dealers, however the policy rationale for trailing commissions is especially questionable. The Government considered a range of inputs and decided that there was an overall clear benefit to motor vehicle owners by undertaking these reforms.

It is worth noting that apart from New South Wales, no other state or territory in Australia allows for the payment of commissions on CTP insurance. No state or territory government pays a fee to motor dealers for registering a vehicle.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I acknowledge that point. The Treasurer continued--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It is not anticipated there will be additional cost or impact to Customer Service Centres operated by the Department of Transport and Main Roads (DTMR). Motor dealers will continue to use existing software for a DTMR interface or current arrangements through Customer Services Centres.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The Treasurer then advised that the bill would be introduced during the August sittings. I thank the Treasurer for that fulsome response. However, I need to place on the record the concerns in relation to motor dealers, particularly those of one of the three larger dealerships in my electorate.
XML.Hansard-Body: The remainder of the bill predominantly deals with privatisation, which makes it very difficult for those of us who wish to support our communities in relation to any refund on the cost of CTP to oppose the rest of the bill that relates to privatisation. The Treasurer has effectively ensured that, during the second reading, we will perhaps vote for the first part of the bill and then call a division on every clause that relates to the privatisation. Surely that is not an acceptable direction to take, but it is one that the Treasurer has left us no option but to take. Strategically, it might have been a good move on his part to put what is, from the community’s perspective, a palatable part of the legislation at the front of the bill and the privatisation matters at the back of the bill, in the hope that the bill would be passed without objection. However, the reality is that my electorate remains totally opposed to the privatisation of Queensland Rail coal freight. There has been no reduction in their concern or objection. I certainly will not be supporting those parts of the legislation that relate to that privatisation.

Mr DOWLING (Redlands--LNP) (4.29 pm): I rise to speak to the Motor Accident Insurance and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, which attempts to achieve a number of things. I will limit my comments to the compulsory third-party component of the legislation which I think most of my constituents are more concerned about with the day-to-day running of their household budget.

The amendment bill seeks to remove the current provision allowing for a commission to be paid by insurers to vendors who, more often than not, are motor dealers who process the compulsory third-party insurance at the point of sale. At the same time, the legislation removes the opportunity of a funding stream used by numerous charities to carry out their work in our community. I recall during my response to the budget on 11 June that this policy had not been thought through, and I said as much to the Treasurer at the time. I remind those opposite of the comments I made on 11 June. I said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: There is another example of the government thinking things up but failing to think them through. The Treasurer announced that there will be a review of compulsory third party insurance so that motorists do not bear the cost of commissions paid to other parties. I highlight to the Treasurer--and I am pleased he is in the House--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: and still in the House--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: that there are a number of entities who benefit and rely upon those commissions. Let me list some of those beneficiaries. They are organisations such as Rotary clubs, the Autism Association, sporting clubs across the length and breadth of Queensland, chaplaincies, school P&Cs, who actually pick up a trailer from those compulsory third party policies, and who knows how many more. It is not the first time that this government has seen fit to raid the community coffers. They raped and plundered the community gambling fund only recently, and that is so typical. I would like to know what the Treasurer thinks the community organisations will do to try to replace the revenues that they are about to lose.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is what I said on 11 June. Now we know--an amendment like so many amendments. You would think that a government with the resources that it has could manage to get a piece of legislation into the House that has been free of Labor spin and not done in undue haste--something diligently prepared by the relevant departments, free to do the work they are capable of doing and need to do without Labor’s incompetence or the ham-fisted approach so typical of this dysfunctional Labor government. This is another example of a Labor government which has no understanding of the decisions it makes and the knock-on effects. While I support any attempt to reduce the costs to Queensland motorists, it is a bit rich when Labor takes the credit for prohibiting CPT commissions but at the same time has been directly responsible for so many more increases for the motoring public.

The government has been directly responsible for removing the Fuel Subsidy Scheme, increasing fuel costs. It has increased road toll charges up and down our motorways. It has increased vehicle registration. It has increased driver’s licence costs, with more to come. We are now the most expensive state in which to own a motor car. That is in direct contrast to where we used to be--one of the most affordable states to own and operate a motor car. It has increased transfer duty. This is then added to everything else that this government has mismanaged, like power and water--the everyday essentials that most people cannot live without and are locked into a closed market.

The charitable groups that have been robbed by this new policy are many and varied and include such charities as I mentioned earlier--Rotary Clubs, Autism Queensland, sporting clubs and school chaplaincy. School chaplaincy is one of those great initiatives in our schools and I think it is so undervalued. School chaplaincy is under great threat. A small concession by the Treasurer in allowing a once-only commission to charities is half a step in the right direction. However, it does not replace the ongoing revenue loss for the charity if the purchaser of the CTP fails to deliberately nominate the charity at the time of renewal each year.

This Labor government will again get bruised shoulders from all the backslapping and self-promotion of this generous, benevolent offer by the Treasurer. But the Treasurer is not able to offer this $20 to $24 reduction in CTP insurance because of any government efficiency or any significant improvement in the state’s finances. It is, however, using someone else’s money to manipulate a false discount. It is a fool’s economy that has seen Queensland go bust in a boom. The worst Treasurer in the history of Queensland continues to run Queensland into the ground. We have lost our AAA credit rating--the only state to do that. We have gone from the cheapest to the dearest state in Australia in which to own and operate a vehicle. The people of Queensland cannot afford this continual financial impost at the hands of the Premier and the Treasurer.

This Labor government has lost its way, just the same as the Rudd-Gillard Labor government federally lost its way, just the same as Labor governments across the country have lost their way. Taking hundreds of dollars every quarter out of household budgets and replacing it with a $20 to $24 a year discount annually is a fool’s economy. Only an LNP government will deliver real action.

Mrs PRATT (Nanango--Ind) (4.35 pm): I rise to speak to the Motor Accident Insurance and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. I know that I have risen before other people who wanted to speak, but I do not know where they are. So I thank the Deputy Speaker for the opportunity to speak. I will not take up much time.

Like other members in this House, I have been approached by many motor dealers in the Kingaroy and Nanango districts with concerns about this particular bill. It is a feel good bill in some ways because everyone wants an $20 extra in their pocket at any time. Overall, I think a higher price will paid by rural communities and by young workers who want to work in the motor vehicle industry.

I also believe that motor dealers are a very easy target, but this will affect them. In one case I think the member for Gladstone said it would cost one dealer $120,000. One dealer in my area will be impacted by a $60,000 loss, which is at least 1 jobs in their business. Although the rest of the state may indeed get $20 back in their pocket every year, some people--possibly their own children--will in fact lose their jobs. In a lot of ways, this is robbing Peter to pay Paul. I would like to read a letter from one of the motor dealers who wrote to me. He wrote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Treasurer announced in the budget CTP reforms with an effective date of 1 October 2010. The reforms will lower the CTP premiums by $24 and prohibit the payment of commissions and other forms of inducements with CTP insurance. The Treasurer also stated a number of CTP insurers pay motor vehicle dealers and others commissions on what is a compulsory product. These costs are ultimately borne by motor vehicle owners in the insurer’s premium pricing. The government will legislate to ban the payment of commissions associated with CTP insurance as of the abovementioned date, and we will also look at other charges now to ensure that these costs do not emerge in other forms.
XML.Hansard-Body: I think most people would note that the vehicle costs have risen in all manner of forms. You only have to look at registration. The government reduces the costs in one area but puts them up in others. To think that people are actually going to save $20 is wrong. Somewhere along the line they are going to be penalised, and it will not just be by $20. It will be by considerably more. We have seen continual price rises over the last 12 to 18 months, and they are totally unreasonable overall. I oppose this section of the bill. I know that there will be a lot of people out there who will not like me for doing that. But I believe that any job is worth saving, and most people would not mind paying $20 if they could ensure jobs for their children.
This motor dealer who wrote to me has been a dealer for an awfully long time. He stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Some important points we would like to raise are the following. Approximately 20 to 25 years ago Queensland Transport registered all vehicles at Queensland Transport offices. This included checking vehicle ID and paperwork. An in-dealership online registration scheme was developed which involved the need for computer software and the training of staff. In agreement to accept liability dealers also sell personalised numberplates for which there is commission. At the time the pay-off to offset the cost to the dealer was to increase commission on CTP from one to five per cent. The loss of the five per cent commission on new CTP business and the one per cent on renewal CTP business will cost the motor vehicle industry millions of dollars.
XML.Hansard-Body: Like I said, there will not be many people out there who will have sympathy for motor dealers because they think they do all right anyway. The point is that there will be a greater cost to consumers than the $20 per annum they save on CTP insurance. I will be opposing the first part of the bill. I am not sure whether I am the only one who will oppose that part of the bill.

I definitely oppose the rest of the bill. It is another sneaky tactic by this government to include possible privatisation issues within bills such as this. I do not think I have left anyone in this House in any doubt about exactly how I feel on the issue of privatisation. I foreshadow here and now that any bill that comes into this House that facilitates in any way, shape or form the sale of public assets will be opposed by me.

I know this is a deliberate tactic to try to hoodwink the majority of people in the electorate. I can explain this pretty clearly, which I will be doing out there. This government is already thought to be very sneaky. I think this shows that it continues to use those practices. The House is on notice that I will oppose this bill. I definitely do not commend it to the House.

Ms JARRATT (Whitsunday--ALP)
(4.41 pm): There just are not any surprises left in this world, are there? I rise to fully support the Motor Accident Insurance and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. We have heard a lot about cost of living increases in this debate. It is true that, like countries around the world that are also grappling with pressures such as repaying funds used to fight the global financial crisis and responding to the costs of population growth, Queensland is not immune to those pressures.

These are difficult times on a number of levels. I know that it is getting harder for many families to make ends meet. As a government we provide a range of subsidies and rebates to assist the most vulnerable in our communities to ease the burden on their weekly income. We are also on the lookout for new ways to cut costs such as our ClimateSmart Home Service which equips householders to monitor daily electricity use and take control of unnecessary usage.

A review of one of the mandatory costs associated with vehicle ownership, the CTP scheme, revealed that what should be a competitive environment has become less than perfect in a number of ways. Indeed, the review identified that not all motor vehicle owners are benefiting from the price competition on CTP insurance. While we do see advertisements from time to time offering special deals that include a competitive CTP arrangement when insurance products are bundled up by the customer, new car buyers are not only not being offered a competitive price for CTP but the incentives paid to motor vehicle dealers have contributed to a situation where all of the licensed CTP insurers have filed their class 1--that is, for cars and station wagons--premiums at the regulated premium ceiling.

This means that motorists are paying top price for CTP while motor dealers and insurance companies enjoy the spoils of the arrangement. Clearly, motorists have not been getting the full benefit of competitive CTP premiums which should result from private sector involvement. As I said before, I am aware that insurers offer inducements to some motorists in the form of discounts on other insurance products and the likes of fuel vouchers, but these offers have only benefited selected motor vehicle owners while the remainder continue to pay high premiums.

It appears that the licensed CTP insurers have put more effort into competing for motor vehicle dealerships as tied agency arrangements than actually competing for customers on premium pricing. The cost of payments to intermediaries like motor dealers and brokers as well as the cost of these additional policyholder inducements has been charged against the CTP scheme and insurers have filed their premiums at the regulated premium ceiling to offset these additional costs.

The reforms contained in this bill appropriately prohibit commissions on what is a compulsory government product and will also stop the cost of inducements to policyholders being charged against the CTP scheme, giving motor vehicle owners a real opportunity to benefit from CTP price competition. I commend the Treasurer for acting and implementing these reforms to provide an environment in which not only will the vehicle owners pay lower delivery costs in their CTP premium but they will benefit from true CTP price competition. I therefore commend the bill to the House.

Mr KNUTH (Dalrymple--LNP)
(4.45 pm): I rise to speak in the debate on the Motor Accident Insurance and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. In the minister’s second reading speech he said that the amendments to the Motor Accident Insurance Act 1994 contained in the bill are the culmination of the government’s commitment in this year’s state budget to deliver a CTP scheme that provides value for money for Queensland’s motor vehicle owners. These reforms to the CTP scheme will deliver a cut to the total registration bill paid by Queenslanders from 1 October this year.

This $24 saving is welcome because $24 is a lot of money to the average battlers out there. However, the cost of drivers’ licences is set to double. Our fuel subsidy has been removed. This is supposed to be a sweetener. We have a massive debt of $85,000 million. This government is using whatever means it can to rip people off.

For example, on Friday my office was filled with angry small mining leaseholders who are incensed about new laws which have snuck into the system. They are being hit with whopping bills of $6,000 for leases that in some cases no longer exist. A letter from DERM advises miners that leases will now be paid in advance. Miners now have to make a payment to the environmental authority of $500 for each lease. It was previously $200 for each lease. This has to be paid every year whether or not the lease has been granted. In previous years it was a one-off payment that would last for the term of the lease.

It gets worse. Incredibly, some miners have been asked to pay the increase in fee backdated to before the new legislation came into effect on 1 January 2009. One miner who owns several leases is facing a fee of $10,000, with more bills rolling in by the day. Not only are they facing these exorbitant bills which are backdated but the miners have also found out that this will not be a one-off fee but a fee that will need to be paid every year.

The environmental authority is immediately activated when a mining lease application is made. The charges are applied at that time. The applications usually take years to be granted. The miners are thus required to pay for leases that they do not own and may not even be granted. These small miners are scrambling to find thousands of dollars to pay for unexpected bills. I call on the minister to investigate this issue.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ryan): Order! Member for Dalrymple, I am calling you to order. The bill relates to the motor accident insurance scheme. It is for particular purposes. I ask you to direct your comments to the purposes of the bill. I call the member.

Mr KNUTH:
I have an issue with third-party access. If a driver hits a kangaroo or a pig in our rural or regional areas there is no chance to claim that insurance. I think that needs to be investigated. If the passenger is hurt, that is different. That is something that needs to be looked at. I wanted to bring that to the attention of the House.

Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind) (4.49 pm): I rise to make a very brief contribution to the Motor Accident Insurance and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, something which I am sure all members will appreciate. I acknowledge that the policy objective of the bill is to reduce delivery and acquisition costs and promote greater price competition within the CTP scheme so as to deliver premium savings to motor vehicle owners of about, as many members have said, $20 to $24. I also acknowledge that the bill amends the Transport Infrastructure Act 1994, which is specific to QR National Ltd’s corporate governance framework.

The name of this bill is misleading. This is the Motor Accident Insurance and Other Legislation Amendment Bill because the government decided to call it that. By my calculations, 20 pages of this bill are spent on motor accident insurance provisions, 35 pages of this bill are on competition authority and 13 pages of this bill are on transport infrastructure. If that is the case, why did the government not call this bill the ‘Competition Authority and Other Acts Amendment Bill’? I would suggest that the reason that it has not correctly named this bill is that it wants the main focus of the debate to be on the savings, and member after member on the government side has risen and spoken about the $20 to $24 savings that people will get. It is just like a bad trumpet player--they wave the trumpet around to throw the focus off the dud notes. This government wants everyone to focus on the alleged $20 to $24 savings but wants us to forget the jobs that the members for Nanango and Gladstone spoke about. It wants us to forget about the jobs that will be lost in the motor dealerships, especially in rural and regional Queensland. It looks like those job cuts will be heavy and will be significant in those motor dealerships.

The government also wants us to forget about the 9c per litre extra that we are paying every time we fill up the tank. Every time I drive from the Burnett to this place I fill up the car, and the cheapest fuel is about $1.21. I keep thinking, ‘If only this government, if only this Treasurer and if only this Premier hadn’t added 9c or more a litre, everyone would be better off.’ Once again, that extra charge hits people in rural and regional areas harder than it does people in the south-east corner. Anyone north of Caboolture and those who live in rural and regional areas who have to travel further and obviously use more fuel are hit disproportionately by that tax--effectively an extra tax. The government wants us to forget about the 400 per cent increase in land rents, and we appreciate how much $20 to $24 is. The retirees in Carlyle Gardens village in the Burnett all know the value of a dollar and how much it costs to live and every cent is counted, and they understand that this government is $85 billion in debt. They know that we have to look after our own budgets.

Many speakers in the opposition have outlined this point, but we are also being asked by this government to forget that two-thirds of the bill, which effectively facilitates and helps the sale of our state’s assets, was not spoken about or addressed by many members of the government. The member for Gaven made the point in his speech that this government is fearful that the regulation in law surrounding the sale of rail and other infrastructure will undermine the sale and the sale price of Queensland Rail. They are not his exact words, but there are provisions in this bill which facilitate and assist in the sale of Queensland state assets. The member for Nanango is opposing the first part of the bill, and I agree. There will be job losses because of the passage of this bill. The sale of our state assets will be facilitated if this bill passes this place. Obviously the pertinent question to ask is: if this bill failed to pass this place, would it hamper or slow down the efforts of this government to sell off and privatise our state assets? I believe that the answer to that question is yes. If this bill failed to pass, it would hamper those sales. For that reason, I am going to oppose this bill.

Mr HORAN (Toowoomba South--LNP) (4.55 pm): This afternoon we are discussing an important bill in the Motor Accident Insurance and Other Legislation Amendment Bill which covers four major issues--the compulsory third-party insurance premium and how that is paid, keeping motorway tolls within or below CPI, and two issues with regard to the detail of competition policy particularly as it relates to government owned enterprises. First of all I want to address the matter of compulsory third-party insurance. When the budget was brought down, this was the only single item where the government gave anything to the people. Everybody then discovered that it was not a gift from the government to the people; it is actually--
Mr O’Brien: Medical rebates!

Mr HORAN: I take that interjection. However, what I am saying is that that was one of the major items that it promoted post budget in terms of giving something to the people. We then discovered that it was not coming from the government but rather from motor dealers. If anybody has had a belting from pillar to post, it has been Queensland motorists. This CTP insurance saving of approximately $20 to $24 per registration will provide a small relief to Queensland motorists who are staggering under the heaviest costs in Australia.

The previous system provided motor dealers with a commission for going through the process of CTP when somebody bought a new car. In other words, they were basically doing the work of the government because, if they did not do it, people buying a car would have to go to the motor registry offices and the queues there would have been kilometres long, because the queues there are long enough now anyway. Doing that processing provided some motor dealers with a very modest amount of income, especially for country dealers. There is a dealer in a small township near Toowoomba which got $19,000 to $20,000 per year which helped them employ the receptionist in the office of their dealership. This is not a big dealership and that was an important part of their cash flow in terms of maintaining staff. The whole gamut of dealers--small, medium and large--would receive varying amounts. However, the thing we have to remember about car dealerships is how important they are in the commercial structure of our cities and towns. No matter what the dealership, they are employing salesmen, they are employing mechanics, they are employing service people, they are employing reception staff, they are paying advertising in the local newspaper and they are providing work to many of the associated motor industry businesses in town such as panelbeaters, detailers, windscreen tinting, painting and all the rest of it. It is a huge industry and it is a very important industry in our cities. If those dealerships were taken out, there would be a major problem with unemployment.

So it is important for the economies of our towns that the motor dealerships are recognised for what they do. This amendment takes away something that had been partly a service that they provided, but it was also a payment for providing that service or a commission for providing that service. Also, other people benefited, such as Scripture Union, various sporting clubs and various service clubs. I know that this bill allows those charitable organisations to still be a part of this arrangement, but it depends upon the insurer agreeing to that commission. In other words, the insurer probably has to come up with a percentage to come out of its CTP to pass on. It has to be a system of ticking a box to allow that arrangement to continue as a trailing commission.

I think the point that should be recognised is the importance of motor dealerships. They will now be suffering a loss of income for something that became part of their normal cash flow. We would do well to remember how many of these motor dealerships relied on this arrangement as a component of paying staff, particularly front-office staff within their dealerships, who in many cases were the ones who processed these compulsory third-party insurance arrangements.

As I said, this amendment will provide a small relief to Queensland motorists, because they are facing absolutely horrendous costs. It is those costs that are hitting motorists and people who operate trucking organisations that are starting to flow on. Not only are the direct costs flowing on; the indirect costs are also flowing on to the rest of our community.

We hear so much about the increased cost of living. Every single matchstick and everything else that comes to Toowoomba comes on the back of a truck. Those trucking operators have to pay more stamp duty, more for fuel, more for registration and more for the tolls. Everything that they do is costing them more. Even the registration for the B-double trailer alone is now around $15,000 per year. So there are massive costs and those costs get passed on to the supermarket, the small business or whoever else is getting that item brought to Toowoomba to be sold. It is the same situation in the capital city, the regional cities and the country areas of Queensland. Those costs that are hitting Queensland motorists are hitting all the freight and trucking companies and are being passed on right down the chain and they are contributing to the increases in the cost of living in the state.

If I can coin a phrase from this morning’s TV reality show type stunt that the government wants to put on, let us walk in the shoes of an average Queensland motorist who goes to buy a vehicle. If he wants to buy a modest, second-hand Ford, from the stamp duty increase of a couple of years ago that vehicle will cost him a couple of hundred dollars more. But if he is a tradesman or a rural person who wants to buy a LandCruiser ute to use for his work, that is going to cost him about $2,000 more because of that increase in stamp duty. When he turns the key and finds that the vehicle is only a quarter full of fuel, he then has to go and fill up at the servo and he finds that fuel is around 10c a litre dearer because this government imposed--
Government members interjected.

Mr HORAN: No, it is 10c a litre dearer because of the fuel tax that the government whacked on--the 8.35c plus the GST. We have heard some figures today that fuel prices in Queensland are now among the dearest in Australia whereas Queensland always had the cheapest fuel in Australia. The cost of fuel in Queensland was always around 9c to 10c a litre less than it was in other states. Now, Queensland’s fuel prices are way up there. So everybody has to fork out a bit more every time they fill up their car. Whether it is a little car or a big vehicle, everyone has to pay more and it is money out of their pockets.

If we are walking in the shoes of this Queensland motorist when he goes to pay his registration, which used to be the cheapest in Australia, we will find that it is now the dearest in Australia. If he wants to get the vehicle home and he goes on the Gateway Motorway or the Logan Motorway, he finds that the tolls have gone up again with that big increase that the government put on the tolling system. So all the time it is cost, cost, cost. Not only are motoring costs going up; their electricity, their water, their gas--just about everything they touch--has also gone up. Queenslanders have less money in their pockets, so they are not going to the small businesses. They are not buying the clothes that they used to buy. They are not going to the restaurants where they used to take their family. They are hanging back on buying real estate because they have less money in their pocket. So everything that this government is doing is taking money out of the pockets of people and causing serious problems to our economy. Members should go and talk to small business and ask how things are going. The mismanagement and the waste that has occurred under this government has caused these problems.

When you have a government drowning in debt--lining up for $85 billion of debt, which will cost the state as a whole around $100 million a week in interest--it has to find ways to pay the interest, let alone the capital. That is why we have had all of these massive increases. How has that debt been accumulated? It has been through years of mismanagement, of not keeping enough money aside within the budget in the boom times to pay for the capital works that the government wants to undertake. It has been accumulated through the government mismanaging the way it manages the state’s finances. The government spent more than it should have and, as a result, it did not have the capital to undertake the capital works. So it has to go out and borrow.

We have seen the mismanagement of projects like the western corridor recycled water pipeline--a great white elephant, with only about 15 per cent or 20 per cent of its water capacity being utilised--the cost of which blew out by about $1 billion, and Traveston Dam, on which hundreds of millions of dollars were wasted. They are just individual cases of mismanagement and waste. There has also been the overall waste by the government year after year after year. It spent and spent and spent to try to buy its way out of massive problems that came as a result of weak ministers and mismanagement. Then it taxes the people and charges the people to try to handle the massive interest burden that it has built up, let alone make the capital repayments. Of course, that has led to the loss of Queensland’s AAA rating, which amounts to somewhere between $259 million and $280 million a year more in interest penalty payments on top of all the other interest. What would that buy by way of hospitals or schools for our sate? Nevertheless, that is absolutely dead money that has to be found as penalty interest and the government has to pay that.

That is what has forced the government into privatisation. It is not making proper capital payments. Even though the income the government is earning from these assets is probably more than the interest that it would save by selling them off, it is forced by its own financial mismanagement to go into this fire sale of assets, which we have so vehemently opposed and which we will continue to oppose. As we have said, the only way to stop the privatisation will be to vote into office an LNP government.

This bill also addresses competition policy with regard to monopoly service providers. This part of the bill endeavours to maintain the competition oversight of monopoly service providers within Queensland rather than that oversight being forced on the state by the federal government, because they are two regimes that oversight competition within monopoly owned facilities, be they ports, rail, or waste water treatment. As a result, this legislation brings in a system so that where there is a monopoly owned item, such as a rail track, there is a process for seeking to gain access to that facility by other organisations that want to use it.

This bill also addresses the issue of boards and sub-boards within government owned enterprise. For example, that part of Queensland Rail that is a board and which operates the Queensland rail network--the tracks and so forth--does not have the same board as the other segment of Queensland Rail that operates the freight system, QR National.

The fourth element of this bill relates to the tolls on the motorways. Recently the tolls on the motorways were massively increased by the government by gazettal. That increase was not done by regulation that went through the parliament so that it could have been challenged in the parliament and voted against; it was done by gazettal. That is an unfortunate fact of life. Because it went through that system we did not have the opportunity in this parliament to oppose it and endeavour to stop it.

This bill looks at containing any future increases to CPI or less. At least it would keep them to what might be described as a modest increase but an increase on a far bigger base than previously existed. This is quite a cynical exercise because there is no doubt that that gazettal notice and the increase in the motorway tolls was done to make those motorways more attractive to a buyer as part of the government’s fire sale, as it sold off the motorway tolling franchises, as it sold off our Brisbane Port, as it sold off Queensland forestry and as it sold off the very productive and financially viable coal lines within Queensland Rail. This section of the bill has a sour taste about it, but strictly speaking all this bill is doing is containing the future increases to within CPI.

We would certainly hope that increases are not always at the level of the CPI. We would like to think that they could be kept a bit below the CPI. People on low and fixed incomes in particular cannot afford the increases that are occurring. This government admitted this morning that its members have not walked in the shoes of ordinary people or talked to ordinary people for the past 10 years, that it has members who have been here since 1998 and even members who have been here for 18 months or six years who do not know how the people are feeling. I can tell those members how people feel because we talk to pensioners and low-income workers. If those opposite were to ask them how they would find the extra 14 per cent to cover the electricity price rise, they would tell them they could not find it. One old pensioner told me the other day that they used to be able to scrimp and scrounge and maybe at the end of the pension period of two weeks they might have $6 left over and be able to buy a Magnum ice-cream or something like that as a bit of a treat. But no more, not since these increases have come in.
Mr O’Brien interjected.

Mr HORAN: I hear the member for Cook squarking over there. I would like to see him on a pension trying to pay a 14 per cent rise this year in electricity, with a massive increase the year before and the year before that, totalling 54 per cent over a period of three years. That is for the basic need of electricity. When it comes to water, the government took over Seqwater and owns the wholesaling rights and the pipeline distribution rights. It takes the profit from that to try to pay off its debt and the interest. That is not to mention the selling off of the gas arm in Toowoomba which saw about a 300 per cent increase in the price of gas. People on pensions and low incomes cannot afford these massive increases.

The fact that this increase will be CPI or less at least softens the blow in the future for those people who have been slugged with massive increases on the tollways in a cynical exercise by this government to jack up the potential value of the motorway tolling franchise so it could sell it off as part of a disgraceful and shameful fire sale of our public assets. That fire sale has been forced upon this state by 10 years of mismanagement, of waste, of spending more than was coming in. It has left Queensland with multimillion dollar deficits for the next four or five years and continued payments for generations to come of interest and capital on this massive debt--a debt which is bigger than the debt of New South Wales, with its much larger population.

This bill addresses these immediate issues of the CPI limit on the tolls and some matters that have to be attended to within the gamut of providing competition so there is proper economic development within the operation of government owned assets that are monopolies, whether or not those particular assets are public or private. I reiterate our total opposition to the privatisation and I say again, in discussing this bill and looking at the issue of the money that goes to people under compulsory third-party premiums, let us not forget the contribution that is made to our economy and to jobs by motor dealerships throughout the length and breadth of Queensland.

Mr HOOLIHAN (Keppel--ALP)
(5.14 pm): In speaking to this Motor Accident Insurance and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, I challenge any member of this parliament to honestly say that they do not understand what components make up their registration.
A government member: We are not all dills like him.

Mr HOOLIHAN: We know about dills; we just heard from one. The people who have spoken the loudest seem to know the least. We heard about the rising cost of fuel. If one goes to Gin Gin, fuel is 3c a litre cheaper now than before the rebate was taken away because the rebate was being eaten up by fuel companies.
Mr Dempsey interjected.

Mr HOOLIHAN: You go back to your seat! There are a couple of aspects to this bill that everyone seems to have overlooked. My understanding comes from having had a couple of careers, one of them working for an insurance company. In those days motorists used to pay only a $2 third-party commission. Then it went to five per cent. Now it is not only paid when one registers a vehicle at the first point of call; it is paid every year, and it is paid every year while people are too lazy to shop around for their third-party insurance. Everyone gets a notice with their registration which says ‘If you want to change your third-party insurer, shop around.’ You have to change it before you pay your registration. That way you can get the cheapest premium.

The Motor Accident Insurance Commission sets an upper and a lower limit for the cost of third-party insurance. Third-party insurance in Queensland is actually underwritten by private insurers. Does anyone know how many? I am willing to bet no-one does. There are six. While continuing to freeze out other insurance companies by paying trailing insurances they are maintaining their own profit base. Who are the costs ultimately borne by? They are borne by consumers. Bearing in mind that everyone pays their insurance through the Department of Transport and Main Roads, they are the ones who have to enforce any changes. As I said, most people do not shop around to compare their insurance. Does anyone know what the lowest insurance is? I am willing to bet that very few do.
Mr Finn: How much is it?

Mr HOOLIHAN: I will take that interjection. It is $337. That in itself will effect a saving. One of the things that will come out of this legislation will be that the CTP insurance scheme will be protected in that if an insurance company is not able to continue to offer that insurance and meet the licensing requirements--and it did happen during the 1970s and 1980s when all insurance companies pulled out and the SGIO at that stage, now Suncorp, were the only third-party insurer--the state will provide that insurance. That will allow underwriting of the policies.

One of the things that this does is allow competition between the insurance companies and, hopefully, new insurance companies can enter into the market. It does not limit car buyers’ choice in relation to the company that provides the CTP insurance when they buy a vehicle. As I said, hopefully, they will be able to shop around and find out what companies offer the cheapest deal when they go to renew their policy.

The other thing we heard much about was in relation to the access regime regarding particularly rail. Queensland has had an open and fair access regime for over a decade. This provides a legislative framework that governs the economic regulation of significant monopoly infrastructure. That is imposed on Queensland and every state in Australia by the national competition authority. An open access regime will guarantee non-discriminatory access. What a lot of people here may also not know is that Asciano through Pacific National now has about 20 per cent of the rail market in Queensland. It is intended that this change will ensure that they have unfettered access and that it is clear and transparent.

We heard from the member for Gaven about what has happened in Western Australia. I understand that, in that instance, Fortescue Metals has had its access to one particular line blocked, although the Federal Court did allow them to have access to a second line. The bill increases the transparency of the regulatory processes provided for in the regime.
