Regulatory decisions will now be guided by clear provisions to ensure that the Queensland Competition Authority administers and enforces compliance with the regime including giving the QCA the powers to collect information to monitor compliance with an access undertaking, as the state’s independent economic regulator is best placed to apply the provisions in the regime.

The ability for governments to make unilateral regulations regarding which services may be included or excluded from the regime will be removed. While the government has only made regulations where it has clearly been appropriate to do so, the changes increase certainty for players in the regulatory regime by legislating that coverage will be guided by clear access criteria and extensive involvement of the Queensland Competition Authority.

In terms of the national competition authority and the Queensland Competition Authority, the national competition authority and the federal government will punish any state that does not offer clear and open competition between monopoly interests including monopoly infrastructure. This act will allow for the reduction in third-party insurance premiums by preventing the payment of trailing commissions. It will also look after the regulatory regime in Queensland. I commend the bill to the House.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (5.22 pm), in reply: I thank all members for their contribution to the debate this afternoon. I acknowledge that the bill has the support of both sides of the chamber--not unanimous support around the chamber, but both sides across the chamber. I think it is important to acknowledge that and to place that on the record. At times during the debate one had to wade through the blizzard of bile coming from some of those opposite in order to detect that they were, in fact, supporting the bill.

This is a bill that delivers on a central commitment of the government. That central commitment is to provide cost of living support to every Queenslander registering a motor vehicle through the policy changes on which we did the hard yards in order to provide a better system that delivers a cut--a real cut--in the costs of registering a motor vehicle in Queensland from 1 October this year. It is a $24 cut, as I announced at budget time. This was a process that I announced in the parliament in March. It is a process that occurred in consultation with industry. Then at budget time, at the conclusion of that review, the decision was to provide for a $24 cut.

I want to address the point attempting to be made, which is false and which is untrue, by those opposite that this in no way relates to the government. In the first instance, the $20 reduction that arises through the policy changes in the banning of commissions is a result of the policy review that the government undertook. The policy work that the government undertook delivered this result to the people of Queensland--to the motorists of Queensland. We also--but none of them wanted to mention it today because it did not support the falsehood being advanced--have removed the $4 levy surcharge that was the fee to support the funding of the nominal defendant after the HIH levy. For the benefit of the record, let the falsehood not stand that was put forward by those opposite that this in no way related to the government’s efforts or, indeed, to an impact on the government’s finances--quite the opposite.

As to the notion, however, that the $24 cut that the government has put in place is something that should be decried, as many of those opposite did--unlike the member for Dalrymple, who obviously for once forgot to pick up the script from the Leader of the Opposition’s office when he acknowledged that it was an important contribution--imagine if the government had proposed a $24 increase to CTP in the budget. Imagine if I had, in handing down the budget, proposed a $24 increase. They all would have stood up and, to a man and woman, argued the fact that $24 would break the bank of every single Queenslander. However, on this occasion when we are delivering it back, they seek to decry it. Therefore, they are revealed for practising the most dismal form of politics which is without ideals, without a clue, without any policy appreciation.

Let us also say this. In fact, if any of them had looked up the scheme, they would have noticed something else--that $24 is not where it ends. In anticipation of the reforms we have put in place in the abolition of commissions to promote competition--real price competition so that consumers, Queensland motorists, are the beneficiaries--one of the companies has moved off the ceiling and is, in fact, taking a further $5 off. For all those who thought that $24 was not enough, the good news today is that if people shop around they can get $29 off. The good news about abolishing commissions is that insurance companies who underwrite the scheme now have the wood on them to promote price competition.

I want to address the complete falsehood being advanced by those people who are singing the eulogy of the motor dealers of Queensland and the people who work for them as somehow being of higher virtue than the interests of Queensland consumers. Let me say this: I am the son of a car dealer. In fact, if honourable members drive to Proserpine and they drive down Main Street they will see Fraser Ford proudly still standing there. Yes, my broader family still has a stake in it. I am a Ford man and proud of it. I have always been a Ford man and I have always been a Labor man. The two go together and I also bank with the Commonwealth. All of those members opposite would actually do a lot better if they got on board with the ‘holy trinity’: bank with the Commonwealth, vote Labor and make sure they back the Fords at Bathurst. They can take the tip.

Let me say this about the commissions: those people who are seeking to say that the right of motor vehicle dealers in this state should continue as is are saying that those motor vehicle dealers--and we heard them quoted--were getting hundreds of thousands of dollars each and every year. That is not a fee for service. That is not because the motor vehicle dealer is getting paid to register a vehicle. That fee is being paid by each and every Queenslander each and every year they renew their CTP, not when they buy a new car but when they register a vehicle. So if people have not bought a car at any time in the last 20 years but in each of the last 20 years they have renewed their registration and paid the CTP, as they should, they are paying the piper. They are paying the motor vehicle dealer who had signed up a commission arrangement with an insurance company. Why would that be the case? Guess what the best business in the CTP scheme is? It is the brand-new customer. That is why the commissions existed.

This is a compulsory product. It is compulsory in this state to have a CTP policy; it is compulsory to have CTP if people register their vehicle. That fundamentally challenges the notion that trailing commissions should be payable by each and every motorist--not those registering the vehicle--not only in the year they register it, but in each and every year. Those fools on the other side who have stood up and advocated for this policy course of action have said that it should be the people of Queensland who register their vehicle each and every year--not the ones who buy new cars--who should contribute to seeing that the motor vehicle dealers across Queensland continue to get paid that fee.
Mr Rickuss: Grow up.

Mr FRASER: That is what you have supported, member for Lockyer. To a person, members opposite stood up and said that what is important are the jobs and that motor vehicle dealers rely on it. They are saying that people across Queensland who register their vehicle each and every year should pay a tax in order to subsidise other people’s employment. The problem with the argument is that it is not true. I do not believe it. As someone who grew up closely associated with motor vehicle dealers and who has a great respect for motor vehicle dealers across the state, not for a minute would I begin to pretend that that total rort should be defended.

Of course, it falls to those opposite to defend what is unquestionably a rort. I make no bones about the fact that this government decided to take it on to benefit Queensland motorists and consumers. Of course, along the way some cosy arrangements with insurance companies have had to take a haircut, but the end result will benefit Queensland motorists. Let us be clear: this bill introduces a key commitment that is the result of hard policy yards done by this government. Those opposite bristle at it because the concept of doing the policy hard yards, of getting in there, rolling up their sleeves and making sure that they can deliver an outcome that is to the benefit of the public, is anathema to them.

I will remark on other parts of the bill, particularly the reforms to the Queensland Competition Authority Act arrangements. For the benefit of the record, I will be clear. These are reforms to the competition arrangements in Queensland that were due by 31 December this year, regardless of any other reason that some people opposite want to advance. The reality is that in February 2006, under the stewardship of then Prime Minister Howard, COAG agreed to a timetable that required reforms to be undertaken in these terms by 31 December 2010.

For the benefit of the Independent members who sought to come into the chamber today and say once again that this debate on the decisions that this government has taken is about privatisation or asset sales, I say that the fact of the matter is this: if they somewhat miraculously gathered support from across the chamber and defeated this bill today, it would have no impact whatsoever on our ability as a government to carry out what we have said we would do, which is to undertake some divestments in order to support jobs and build the future of Queensland. One Independent member took the prize when she said that she was interested in the jobs of motor vehicle dealers but wants to vote against the whole bill of this government when it is this government that is advancing the very cause of jobs, which is the reason for the decisions we have taken.

Once again, I will be really clear: the reforms to the competition arrangements were due by 31 December 2010. For the benefit of the House, I will table the extensive documentation from COAG from 2006, from the tories’ favourite Prime Minister, John Howard, which states that that was the timetable.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Bundle of documents, titled ‘Council of Australian Governments’ Meeting 10 February 2006, Communique’ [ 2855 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: It is there for the benefit of all members of the House. I am sure that those Independents who like to say that they come in here and judge things on their merits will walk back in here and withdraw their comments, judge the bill on its merits and support the bill. In reality, their reasons for opposing it are not born out by the facts.

The last point in the debate is this: we are undertaking reforms as a state. The reforms that are contained in this bill are about making sure that we have a competition regime that is the best in Australia. Some members of the House were very keen to advance the cause of Asciano, which has been able to gain 20 per cent of the market. It could not do that unless the competition regime in the state was effective. Ipso facto, it is. Ipso facto, that is why, when it released its results the other week, Asciano said it was interested in increasing more of its market share in Queensland. It is why QR is increasing its market share in the Hunter Valley. Let us be clear: the competition regime in Queensland is effective.

In summing up, the only part of the bill that I want to draw to the attention of the Independent members in particular is that which outlines the arrangements that seek to ensure that any future regular toll increases across the Queensland Motorways network are, in fact, limited to CPI. I place it on the record for the benefit of those Independent members who have said that they are committed to voting against this bill that it will not in any way facilitate any privatisation. However, they will vote against the commitment of this government to ensuring that future regular toll increases under the franchise agreement will be limited to CPI. Again, I place on the record for the benefit of those members of parliament who want to vote against this bill, based on the notion that somehow it will do something that it will not--I remind them and I intone them--that all they will do is support the idea that toll increases should go above CPI. Having dealt with those facts, I am sure that all members of the parliament will support the bill. I commend the bill to the House.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Division: Question put--That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: AYES, 79--Attwood, Bates, Bleijie, Bligh, Choi, Crandon, Cripps, Croft, Davis, Dempsey, Dick, Dickson, Douglas, Dowling, Elmes, Emerson, Farmer, Finn, Flegg, Fraser, Gibson, Grace, Hinchliffe, Hoolihan, Hopper, Horan, Jarratt, Johnson, Johnstone, Jones, Kiernan, Kilburn, Knuth, Langbroek, Lawlor, Lucas, Male, McArdle, Menkens, Miller, Moorhead, Mulherin, Nelson-Carr, Nicholls, Nolan, O’Brien, O’Neill, Palaszczuk, Pitt, Reeves, Rickuss, Roberts, Robertson, Robinson, Ryan, Schwarten, Scott, Seeney, Shine, Simpson, Smith, Sorensen, Spence, Springborg, Stevens, Stone, Struthers, Stuckey, Sullivan, van Litsenburg, Wallace, Watt, Wellington, Wells, Wendt, Wettenhall, Wilson. Tellers: Darling, Keech
NOES, 5--Cunningham, McLindon, Pratt. Tellers: Foley, Messenger
XML.Hansard-Body: Bill read a second time.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Powell): Order! Before I call the Clerk, I remind members that, under standing order 103, only a member who has voted against the majority as declared by the Speaker may demand a division.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 1 to 11, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 12--

Mr NICHOLLS (5.47 pm): Clause 12 deals with the provisions of inducement for CTP insurance business. We have heard that this legislation effectively ensures that motorists in Queensland receive approximately a $24 saving and that to not pass this legislation would in fact result in an increase in the insurance component of the annual registration of ordinary Queensland motorists, who we have said on a number of occasions in the debate are already being hit by more and more fees and charges. In that sense, this prohibition on the inducement in proposed new section 96 of the legislation is the effective provision that stops the insurance companies from offering an inducement to third parties in order to get them to sign up for their CTP insurance. So this is, in effect, the part that saves motorists at least $24.

I wish to thank--and I failed to do so when I first addressed the bill--the officers who provided the briefing on Monday. It was relatively late in the piece. Nonetheless, I thank them for their willingness to answer a number of questions. I also record my position that on this one I am with the Treasurer--I am a Ford man. I am also the son of a Ford dealer. There are more things bizarre in this life than you would consider. I suspect that I have been watching the Blue Oval go around Bathurst a few more years than he has.
A government member interjected.

Mr NICHOLLS: Someone said, ‘A lot.’ I have more hair than you, mate. In any event, I want to re-emphasise the point I made during the debate in relation to the report that was prepared by the commission and taken to cabinet. I want to reflect that there may be other savings on top of the $24 that may have been identified in that report. I raised this in the second reading debate on the bill and the Treasurer did not respond as to whether there were other identified savings in that report.

Mr FRASER: I thank the shadow Treasurer for the question and for his admission that he, too, is part of the great Ford faith that is a key part of the nation’s history. In relation to the report, I am happy to table for the benefit of the members of the House a copy of the review report that was included in the submission that I took to cabinet in order to deliver the savings to Queensland motorists. This does not contain the vast series of commercial information, as I think the shadow Treasurer indicated. It does canvass the other options that were there for the government to consider. I table it for the benefit of the members of the House.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Document, titled ‘Review of Queensland’s Compulsory Third Party Insurance Scheme’s Underwriting Model’ [ 2856 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: In the end, as this report indicates, we went with a model that included staying with the status quo with reforms to the delivery costs that were involved through the insurance companies not being able to include commission charges across the broader premium that they set. In that regard, I am happy for all members of the chamber, and indeed the people of Queensland, to look through the report.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 13 and 14, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 15--

Mr NICHOLLS (5.51 pm): Clause 15 is the provision that amends the Queensland Competition Authority Act. We have had a fair bit of debate about that. I want to make it clear for the record that the amendments to the Queensland Competition Authority Act have nothing to do with the sale of any of the assets that are owned by the Queensland government. It is our understanding and our knowledge--and as has been made clear by the Treasurer--that they are as a result of a review of the principles of the national access regime as agreed by governments through the COAG process.

The review and amendments in relation to the Queensland Competition Authority Act are those that are determined and required as a result of interstate agreements. The amendments and the changes that apply and the application of the Queensland Competition Authority Act would apply to either publicly or privately owned significant monopoly infrastructure--that is, they would apply irrespective of ownership. The amendments are designed to facilitate good economic outcomes for the state of Queensland--that is, to benefit the economy as a whole and lead to greater jobs and greater productivity in Queensland.

Mr FRASER: I thank the shadow Treasurer for the contribution. I do want to make a particular point of emphasising this. As I said in the debate, the reforms of the Queensland Competition Authority legislation are undertaken under a COAG requirement that was signed up under the CIRA agreement in 2006. For the benefit of the House, I have tabled the 2006 documentation signed off by COAG, under Prime Minister Howard, that includes the timetable to undertake these reforms by 2010.

I make the point that these reforms apply equally to infrastructure in public ownership and in private ownership. It relates to infrastructure such as the Dalrymple Bay Coal Terminal which has long been in private ownership. It also relates to the Central Queensland coal network as is declared in regulation that exists presently. That is important to emphasise.

I also want to make the point that one argument advanced by those opposite during the course of the debate was that this was being undertaken in accordance with a timetable because of Asciano putting views into the public arena. I want to make the point that I announced that the Queensland government would be seeking certification in accordance with this timetable by public statement on 22 April this year. Asciano did not advance its lodgement for declaration as it said that it would until May 2010. The government’s intention was on the public record in April. When did Asciano actually put in an application? That was in May 2010.

I have every confidence that the regime that we are strengthening here today is, before today and certainly after today, the best, most open, facilitating competition regime in the country. The facts prove it. The competition in the marketplace proves it. The market share that Pacific National has gained proves it. If we look across the way to Western Australia and see the way that infrastructure has worked under federal regulation then I think we see a stark contrast.

Mr NICHOLLS: I thank the Treasurer for his response. I raise for comment by the Treasurer that it is the case that in the event that our competition regime is not strengthened and is found to not be an effective regime under the provisions of the national access regime then the prospect could be that control of the monopoly service providers in Queensland--whether that be the ports, whether that be the electricity providers, whether that be the railway providers--could potentially be considered to fall under the control of the ACCC or the National Competition Council. These changes strengthen the case for the Queensland access regime to be found to be an effective regime.
Mr FRASER: The answer is yes.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 16 to 61, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 62--

Mrs CUNNINGHAM
(5.56 pm): I will make a point of clarification and a comment. This clause inserts part 12 relating to transitional and savings provisions for motor accident insurance and other legislation. I am interested that it flows from that to issues in relation to coal freight rail transport infrastructure. It appears to flow seamlessly. I appreciated the Treasurer’s comments to me during the division. I valued that advice and clarification. I want to say thank you for that.

I reaffirm that the people in my electorate would not want me to support--hence my support for the division on the second reading--the part of the legislation that facilities in any way the privatisation of Queensland Rail, particularly coal freight. There are concerns about the impact on jobs, job security and longevity of employment. It is on that basis that I oppose the legislation.

Mr FRASER:
I thank the member for her comments. The clause that she has brought to the attention of the House relates to a situation--and the reason that it is in this part of the bill--which persists at the moment. That is that it has long been the case that the Dalrymple Bay Coal Terminal and the rail infrastructure has been declared for a third-party access regime in Queensland.

What this part of the bill seeks to do is preserve that arrangement beyond the end point that was put in place--that being the end of this year. It seeks to preserve it in those terms. The changes to the regime overall will allow the National Competition Council to draw the conclusion that the regime is effective--and ‘effective’ is a term of law, not a term of art. In declaring it effective, the undertakings and the regimes that exist under that regime are ones which will continue beyond 31 December this year. The alternative here, as the shadow Treasurer pointed out, is that without a regime that is considered to be best practice by the NCC regulation of that infrastructure would in fact pass to the federal regime.

Certainly, at this point in time Asciano has put forward a proposal to seek to have the coal network in Queensland declared under the national regime. The government’s view and my very strong view is that our regime is in fact the best in Australia, and the fact that Asciano has been able to gain market share is the best evidence of that. Asciano’s views about third-party access and competition are particularly circumscribed to the time and place and the market it is talking about. Far be it from me to raise the views that Asciano has put where it does not particularly like the concept of third operators coming into some of the ports where it is incumbent; nevertheless, I make the point that its views are somewhat connected to its own commercial interests. That is perfectly legitimate. I accept that.

My point here for the people of Queensland and for the Queensland economy is that our regime is in fact the best regime in Australia. It is the one that has delivered competition into the network and the amendments here today preserve the arrangements that have long existed for the coal network that have allowed Asciano on to the tracks and preserve once again the arrangements that exist for Dalrymple Bay. Indeed, they also provide the regime into the future in that if another operator wanted to come along to other infrastructure in Queensland and seek to have a third-party access regime put in place they would go through this channel under Queensland’s regime in order to achieve it.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 63 to 69, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 71--

Mr NICHOLLS (6.01 pm): Clause 71 applies to the QML network and it is the clause that effectively reverses a power of the minister to make a declaration notification of tolls under section 93 of the legislation. This is the clause that effectively says that the last declaration made by the minister on 16 June 2010 that increased the toll levels and then capped them for future years is the final declaration notice that can be given. So to support this part of the legislation and to support this component of the legislation is to support putting a cap on the future increases on tolls on the Gateway and Logan motorways. I seek confirmation from the Treasurer that that is the way that is meant to operate.

Mr FRASER: This is the clause that delivers on the government’s commitment to ensure that into the future the tolling regime that is in place for Queensland Motorways Ltd in terms of annual increases will be limited to the CPI. I can confirm that this is the clause that delivers that result.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 72 to 76, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 77--

Mr NICHOLLS (6.03 pm): This is the clause that deals with the arrangements in relation to what will be known as QR Network and is part of the suite of arrangements that ensures that access is maintained at arm’s length from any control that might be able to be exercised by QR National. It was stated by an honourable member earlier that if these changes were not passed it would stand in the way of the proposed sale. My understanding is that--I think the Treasurer has made this point; I just want to confirm it again--irrespective of this legislation passing it would not stand in the way of the proposed sale, irrespective of what one’s views are--and our views are to oppose that sale--in relation to that sale.

Mr FRASER: Voting against this clause will not stop the course of action that this government and indeed this parliament have embarked upon. This clause seeks to provide for future arrangements where QR is a vertically integrated entity into the future. I make the point for the benefit of the House that today as we speak, and indeed through its history, QR has been a vertically integrated entity. That is, throughout its history it has owned the tracks and the trains. Indeed, like many other railways around the world, it has owned the tracks and the trains. In the past it has been vertically integrated. Today it is vertically integrated and it is proposed under the government’s policy position, adopted in December last year, that it will be vertically integrated into the future.

This ensures that the composition of the network board does not have a majority of QR executives on it. It also ensures more particularly under proposed section 438H that the directors of the network company do have to ensure that they cannot approve an access agreement--that is, an arrangement with someone seeking to get on the tracks who is not part of the QR group--unless, as the clause says, that board is reasonably satisfied that the agreement is on arm’s length terms. Therefore, it makes explicit and a legal obligation on those directors serving on the network board that they have to be satisfied that recommending and adopting an access arrangement needs to be done at arm’s length. That applies to not only those people seeking to gain access but also QR National--the business itself--in that the arrangements need to be commensurate, allowing obviously for normal commercial arrangements, between those seeking to access the rail network, and that is what this clause makes absolutely clear.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 78 and 79, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (6.07 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a third time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a third time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a third time.
Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (6.07 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the long title of the bill be agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the long title of the bill be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Child Protection and Other Acts Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from 10 June (see p. 2036), on motion of Mr Reeves--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr DEMPSEY (Bundaberg--LNP) (6.07 pm): Today we are asked to support Labor’s proposed amendments to the Child Protection Act 1999. We are being asked to trust a Labor government with the protection and care of Queensland’s most vulnerable and abused children--a responsibility it has had for the best part of the last 20 years. As I begin my speech on the second reading debate I am reminded of a statement made 12 years ago. The then families minister and now Premier said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: For so long child abuse has been a hidden, painful secret in so many people’s lives. It’s time to have the debate.
XML.Hansard-Body: As we debate this bill today, everyone should know that, thanks to the Labor government, child abuse is still a painful secret that not even the minister will discuss because of the secretive way in which this government operates around child matters, more concerned with protecting itself from bad press than with protecting children.

It was the same families minister and now Premier who also said in October 1998 that by enshrining the child placement principles in law there can be no return to the policies of the stolen generation. But we know that this government has been responsible for the removal of more Indigenous children from their families than ever before. We know that this Labor government has presided over more deaths of Indigenous children known to Child Safety Services than were examined in the 20-year review of deaths in custody. Most distressing is that we know that this government has no plan to stop this trend. Yet it stands here today to ask us to trust it with proposed legislative changes once again.

The people of Queensland cannot trust Labor to protect children and to provide families with the support and interventions that they need to get back on track anymore. The people of Queensland cannot trust this minister and this Labor Premier, because they have failed at every turning point when it comes to child safety. I am sadly certain from their failings to date that things will only get worse and that more children will suffer under this Labor government.

I wanted to be able to support the Helping Out Families initiative that has been put forward by Child Safety Services, but this government has given no detail on how it will work or how the money will be spent. We only have to go to the failed One Chance at Childhood policy to show how wrong this Labor government can get it. More concerning is the lack of commitment to early intervention. An amount of $12.5 million a year over four years for this program is a small amount when we remember that the Child Safety Services’ budget has now reached more than $695 million a year. This is a tokenistic investment at best and one that would set the program up for failure because, like dysfunctional families, child safety agencies need stability and they need support. Furthermore, we have been given no detail on how families will be selected or referred.

Whilst I fully support early intervention strategies, I cannot support this bill. There are too many other factors that make it impossible to support this bill in its current form. I will be moving several amendments in the consideration in detail stage to provide some balance and clear legislative guidance to some of the amendments being proposed in this bill, but I cannot support this bill, which seeks to give substantial unchecked powers to Child Safety Services at the same time as winding back other requirements on child safety officers. This bill is a hollow product of a review that was conducted more than 2 years ago. It is filled with a mass of amendments that have nothing to do with child safety but contaminate the bill even further.

Before I begin my assessment of the issues raised in this bill, I want to place on record some facts. According to the Child Protection Clearinghouse report, child maltreatment refers to any non-accidental behaviour by parents, caregivers, other adults or older adolescents that is outside the norms of conduct and entails a substantial risk of causing physical or emotional harm to a child or young person. Such behaviours may be intentional or unintentional and can include acts of omission, that is, neglect and commission--that is, abuse. Child maltreatment is commonly divided into five main subtypes: physical abuse, emotional maltreatment, neglect, sexual abuse and the witnessing of family violence. The clearinghouse report of 2009 states that, although there is a broad consensus regarding the different subtypes of maltreatment, disagreement exists about exactly how to define these subtypes. In the absence of universal definitions of child abuse and neglect, different professional fields have developed their own definitions. There are medical and clinical definitions, social service definitions, legal and judicial definitions, and research definitions of child maltreatment.

It was reported by a clearinghouse report in 2006 that the economic cost of child abuse is significant. According to the Productivity Commissioner’s 2008 report on government agencies, in 2006-07 approximately $1.7 billion was spent across Australia on child protection and supported placement services. Further, over the period from 2002-03 to 2006-07, real recurrent expenditure on child protection and out-of-home care services increased in all jurisdictions.

The research also shows that the personal cost of child abuse is pronounced. Child abuse has been associated with a variety of short and long-term negative outcomes, including mental illness, drug and alcohol abuse, physical ailments and criminalities. In fact, the latest child protection partnership report that was tabled here in parliament recently confirms a strong link between youth offending and child abuse, with 65 per cent of child offenders in the youth justice system known to Child Safety Services. It has been documented that a review of relevant literature by Nick Richardson in 2005 reported that approximately 30 per cent of maltreated children go on to maltreat children in some way when they are adults. It is also clear that a failure to properly manage and respond to child abuse and neglect can have significant and devastating implications not only on the victim but also on broader society.

At this point it is important that I examine child protection services pre 2004 and the CMC inquiry and then post the CMC review from 2004 to 2009 and weigh those services against the track record of this Labor government since the last election in March 2009. This examination will show promise after promise, mistake after mistake and more children being removed and more children known to the department passing away. In 2004 the Crime and Misconduct Commission report stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: During 2003 information came to light, from a number of sources, indicating that the foster care and child protection systems in Queensland, as administered by the Department of Families, had failed many children. The evidence about such failures pointed, in some cases, to systemic failures over many years to prevent children placed in foster care being further abused or neglected.
XML.Hansard-Body: It was also reported during the public hearings of the CMC’s inquiry that a Ms Gwenn Murray, an independent consultant appointed by the department of families in June 2003 to audit abuse notifications made against current Queensland foster carers, stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Department of Families, I think, is dangerously becoming like one of the children for whom it has a statutory obligation ... that is, it is like a neglected child. Major reforms need to be planned and implemented to ensure the safety and well-being of children and young people.
XML.Hansard-Body: In 1997-98 in Queensland there were 17,233 notifications of suspected child abuse or neglect. Of those, 6,323 cases were substantiated. When the Premier and then families minister took over, between July 1999 and June 2000 more than 18,500 notifications of suspected child abuse were made to the families department. Those notifications included 7,935 notifications of neglect, 5,375 notifications of physical abuse, 3,163 cases of emotional abuse and 1,818 notifications of sexual abuse.

The CMC in its 2003 report found that in 2002-03 in Queensland there were 31,068 notifications of child abuse and neglect. Of the 3,966 children under child protection orders, 3,642 were granted custody or guardianship to the director-general of the department of families.

Since 1992-93, as at 30 June each year the overall number of Indigenous children in care has remained relatively stable at just under 100,000 children per year while during the same period the number of non-Indigenous children has increased by 67 per cent. Around 45 per cent of children ceasing care each year have also spent between one and six months in continuous out-of-home care. A smaller proportion--between 10 per cent and 15 per cent--have spent five years or more in care.

Between 2001 and 2003 there had been a significantly higher proportion of children leaving the system after only one month in continuous out-of-home care. For example, in 2000-01, fewer than 500 children spent less than a month in care, but that number rose to more than 1,300 in 2001-2002, which is an increase of 170 per cent. Between 1992-93 and 2002-03, the number of notifications of children in care increased considerably--from 61 to 605 respectively. In 2002-03, about 75 per cent of the notifications investigated were substantiated and 24 per cent of those substantiated notifications were against carers.

Let us now look at this government’s record since the CMC inquiry and the state of child protection. Under this Labor government, children the subject of ongoing intervention through Child Safety Services went from 8,263 in 2008-09 to 10,647. The number of children in out-of-home care has soared from 5,657 in 2005 to 7,093 in 2009. In 2010-11 Child Safety is expected to receive over 101,000 notifications of suspected abuse. This is an almost 10 per cent increase on the previous year that will have a massive impact on the ability of Child Safety Services to deliver services across Queensland.

When we do hear from the government and this minister about child safety all we hear is how large the Child Safety budget is. It is a record $695,894,000. That is all we will hear. Like the record budget, these changes being put forward today will do nothing to change the entrenched closed-shop culture allowed to exist in Child Safety by the secretive Labor government.

Let me now turn to Indigenous children and child protection under Labor. Let me make it very clear that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children make up more than 35 per cent of children in care. This is the shameful record of a Labor government that 10 years ago in this House said sorry to Indigenous people. It has since presided over a record increase in taking their children. Elders and family members still state that there are many of these children who have been ripped from their families, denied access to their traditional culture and denied family and cultural sensitivities. Whilst rates of abuse across Queensland have allegedly fallen according to figures produced by this Labor government, the number and rate of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children being abused, being removed and being reabused continues to increase.

Since 1998 we have heard nothing but talk, spin and hollow promises that have delivered nothing but more children in care, more children known to the department dying and more children placed at risk. All this is despite record amounts of money being thrown at Child Safety Services. This year we have seen yet another so-called record budget for Child Safety Services. Yet only a small percentage of this funding goes towards child and family support services. The majority of funds continue to be spent on the ever-growing Child Safety bureaucracy that is a legacy of a long-term Labor government.

This government has nothing to be proud of in its record of closing the gap when it comes to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander child abuse. In fact, in the five years since the CMC inquiry the number of Indigenous children on protection orders has increased by 100 per cent to more than 2,600. Since 2004, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children subjected to a resubstantiation within 12 months almost doubled. The most concerning aspect is that this government has taken record numbers of Indigenous children from families in the belief that they are in need of protection, yet we have seen an almost doubling of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children being abused whilst in the care of this state. In 2007-08 alone, more than 100 Indigenous children were abused whilst in the care of this government.

One thing is clear: Bligh and Labor have failed to protect Indigenous children, failed children in care, and failed children and their families upon exiting care. Now all it can offer is more talk, more plans and more empty promises. We cannot keep pretending that the only way forward is to throw more money and more cute catchphrases at child protection. It is time to start empowering and building capacity within Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. It is time we embraced the capacity of the non-government community sector in the delivery of child protection services beyond foster care services. We cannot allow 83 per cent of investigations requiring action within 10 days to go unseen. We cannot allow 77 per cent of investigations requiring action within five days to go unanswered. We certainly cannot allow 24 per cent of critical investigations requiring a 24-hour response to go unanswered.

The National Association for the Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect said the focus must be on early intervention with a whole-of-family approach. Abuse and neglect is very much linked to parental drug and alcohol abuse, domestic violence, mental illness and homelessness. NAPCAN CEO Maree Faulkner said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It is critically important that governments address child abuse through these areas.
Focus needs to be on primary prevention that supports families and children before abuse happens.
XML.Hansard-Body: Professor Dorothy Scott, speaking in the Australian on 11 September 2008, said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Australia’s most vulnerable children, those whose parents use health and welfare services for drug, alcohol or mental health problems, are being put at further risk of neglect and abuse because the agencies pay scant attention to how they effect children’s lives.
XML.Hansard-Body: Professor Scott also warned that many agencies choose to ignore the fact that their client is a parent because the needs of children are not considered part of their mission and do not count when it comes to assessing performance. She has said that many agencies see their responsibility to children as beginning and ending with reporting concerns about possible abuse or neglect to the statutory child protection services. When it comes to improving child safety training and staffing, this cannot be done through legislation. It was the University of Queensland’s School of Social Work and Applied Human Services Associate Professor Karen Healy who said that the turnover of front-line protection staff had grown since the 2003 CMC inquiry and compromised service delivery. One of the main reasons for the high turnover and therefore the relative inexperience of the child safety workforce was the narrow focus and high stress of the role. Healy went on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Queensland is the only state in Australia, and one of the only places in the world, to have narrowed the child protection worker’s role to investigation and risk assessment.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Healy concluded--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Most people who work in child protection services are attracted to this work to make a positive difference to families’ lives.
XML.Hansard-Body: Currently in the department of child safety trainee child safety officers are forced out onto the front line within the first few months with no training. Many younger officers enter this role directly from university. The burnout rate of staff is approximately 30 per cent.

I want to now make comment on some of the specific issues raised through the amendments being proposed here today. The proposed amendments being put forward that change the nature of the principles of child protection seek to divide these principles into paramount principles and then other general principles. In responding to this change, I want to read into the record comments made by PeakCare in its submission to the 2008 review. It was the view of PeakCare that the ‘best interests of the child framework’ reads as a document of principles and does not explicitly evidence mechanisms towards implementation. PeakCare expressed concern about where this framework is to be positioned within the amended Child Protection Act and whether it properly belongs in policy or would be better developed as a practice document.

PeakCare have submitted, and I agree, that it is not in the best interests of the child to enter the child protection system at all and note that the ‘best interests of the child framework’ neglects to highlight the need for preventative services, diversionary services and family and community support services which ultimately do provide for the best interests of a child. Everyone would agree that the ‘best interests of the child framework’ is heavily dependent upon the ability of the department of child safety here in Queensland to resource services for children and their families. Concern has been expressed by many in the field about Child Safety Queensland’s ability to resource the services that would be necessary in order to move this framework from principles to reality.

What this Labor government is offering in these amendments to the principles is nothing new. In fact, it will have the opposite effect and continue to exclude families from this process. No amount of changes to the law will stop the growth in the number of children being removed and taken into care under this Labor government. The only way to change the culture of child protection services in Queensland is indeed to change the government of the day.

This bill also seeks to make changes to the definition of harm. The amendments being proposed are more about catching up with every other state and territory that has already recognised cumulative harm. The National Child Protection Clearinghouse’s Leah Bromfield writes--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Cumulative harm may be caused by an accumulation of a single adverse circumstance or event, or by multiple different circumstances and events. The unremitting daily impact of these experiences on the child can be profound and exponential, and diminish a child’s sense of safety, stability and wellbeing.
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms Bromfield notes that families who experience cumulative harm have multiple interlinked problems, for example risk factors such as domestic violence, alcohol and drug and mental health issues; an absence of protective factors; social isolation or exclusion; and enduring parental problems impacting on their capacity to provide adequate care. When it comes to recovery, Ms Bromfield points out that cumulative harm can overwhelm even the most resilient child and particular attention needs to be given to understanding the complexity of the child’s experience.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 pm to 7.30 pm.
Mr DEMPSEY: When it comes to dealing with cumulative harm, research from the Clearinghouse shows--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We need to remain curious about our effectiveness, and constantly review our assessments and planning, in the light of emerging information and the outcomes of our actions. All families are different and there is not a single solution. Good practice may involve trying several strategies or interventions before coming up with an approach that works.
XML.Hansard-Body: No changes here today will address the rigid and inflexible approach that this government takes and no changes here today will change the practices of child safety where one size fits all and anything else will not be tolerated. This Labor government has failed today and its ‘remove first, ask questions later’ policy will fail within the cumulative harm changes. Temporary custody orders outlined in this bill are, as I have said, more about protecting Labor’s ‘remove first, ask questions later’ policy. These orders will allow the department to remove a child for three days without making a decision. Surely if a child is removed the department must believe there is evidence that supports abuse allegations and the child is at risk of further abuse and a temporary protection order or protection order is needed. If this Labor government needs three days to decide on an abuse allegation, we have to question the initial removal of the child. This is akin to charging someone with a crime, putting them before the court and then telling the court to hold them in custody for three days while the police gather evidence to prove the person committed the crime.

The changes proposed to case planning will limit case plan reviews to 12 months for long-term guardianship cases and stop further reviews unless requested by the child or guardian. This is a dangerous and unacceptable move that is further evidence of a department that is stretched to the limit and cannot meet its existing obligations. Case plan reviews form an ongoing, regular contact between a child safety officer, the child, the family and guardians. To limit or to stop this practice will place children at risk of further harm and limit any hope of the child exiting the child protection system.

In response to the 2008 review, the CREATE Foundation wrote on proposed changes to case planning that by changing case plan reviews for those aged five years or older from every six to every 12 months the department of child safety is going against an objective of the participation strategy 2006-2009 which is to ‘expand opportunities for children and young people to have a say about the nature and delivery of services to themselves and their peers’. Conducting case plan reviews every 12 months is not expanding opportunities; rather, it is limiting them.

CREATE is continually concerned about low levels of participation that children and young people are reporting. This is reflected in the Commission for Children and Young People and Child Guardian’s most recent review of young people in foster care report, which highlighted that children and young people do not have confidence that if the department of child safety promises them something it will happen, do not think they are listened to and do not have a say in decisions that affect them. It was further submitted that, of the 1,942 children, young people and carers who responded to the commission’s survey, only approximately 40 per cent reported having a case plan. In that same report, when asked if the respondents knew what was in their case plan only 26.9 per cent responded yes. Again, this figure has increased from 18.2 per cent in 2006, but this still means that 73.1 per cent, or 1,419 children and young people, do not know what is in their case plan. Non-government submissions pointed out Child Safety’s website and state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Case planning is about mapping a way forward for a child or young person. Case plans are goal directed and clearly identify outcomes, key actions and how the progress of the plan will be measured.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: If children and young people do not know what is in their case plan then they may not know the way forward.
XML.Hansard-Body: PeakCare and others wrote of their strenuous disagreement with the principles outlined in this section. If the overriding principle of the legislation is the wellbeing of children, then time frames which are ‘child-centric’ need to be developed and adhered to. The needs of very young children change constantly, as do the circumstances of their families and their carers. Above all, children in care should not drift without some intentional interventions and planning based on thorough, holistic assessment. Thus the legislation needs to enshrine regular and thorough case planning which is based on the age, the development and the needs of the child. There is strong evidence that these plans should be reviewed and updated regularly and should engage all parties who know the child well. Inclusive case planning is essential to prevent drift in the system, itself a form of institutional abuse, and to ensure that children and young people receive the intervention they need to develop normally.

Many in the non-government sector have urged that plans are reviewed every three months at a minimum. Review at intervals of six months or more is not adequate and enables lengthy periods without children being seen by responsible officers. This is not accountable practice. Linking the timing of review to children’s ages encourages a lack of attention to individual circumstances and the notion that older children are not as vulnerable, which is not the case. As parents and adults, we all know that children have different maturity levels and environmental factors affecting them. That is why I will not be supporting the government’s plans for case planning and will be moving amendments at the committee stage to ensure that case plans are reviewed every three months.

I turn now to transition orders and transitioning from care. The government would want us to support changes to transition-from-care plans by limiting the need to conduct plans to only when a court orders such a plan. Under existing law this should be happening already, yet we know for a fact that transition plans are rarely completed and this lack of preparation often contributes to resubstantiations. These changes are further evidence that the existing Child Safety Services cannot cope with expected workloads. Despite record budgets, it should have allowed for the meeting of service obligations.

In relation to licensee obligations, we have only to look at Labor’s track record and licensing of providers to see a litany of abuse of children in the care of unlicensed providers. Previous evidence produced through questions on notice has shown that children in the care of this Labor government are still being placed in unlicensed out-of-home care centres despite reports of an array of problems. It has been revealed that 72 incidents were recorded in out-of-home care services last financial year, with 51 providers unlicensed at the time of the complaint. These are children who have been removed from their parents or family because of abuse or neglect before being subjected to further problems in the unlicensed homes in which the Bligh Labor government has placed them.

It is disturbing that the number of matters of concern that are recorded continue to rise, despite a tripling in the Child Safety budget. I am even more distressed at the fact that so many service providers without a licence still have children in their care. It is not good enough that 51 service providers failed to meet the 11 standards of care that are set out for service providers. We have heard nothing about what this government is doing to stop the placement of vulnerable children who are at risk of further harm. Surely ensuring that all out-of-home-care service providers meet the grade is non-negotiable. Children in care should be safe from further harm. Whilst masked as some reform to child safety, the bill is really designed to hide past errors in bills that were brought into this House by another minister who is not willing to stand up and correct these changes. This minister is in an unacceptable position as he is amending legislation for the overseeing body responsible for the checks and balances of his own department. It is beyond belief that this minister can talk of amendments when they have nothing to do with his portfolio but make up almost half of the entire bill brought before the House. I will touch briefly on those provisions that are not the responsibility of this minister but are included in the bill.

In the past 12 months, the Commission for Children and Young People and Child Guardian decreased its staff by 30. At the estimates committee hearing this was attributed to the fact that some temporary and contract staff who had been involved in the drafting of the criminal history bill were no longer employed. However, in the same period the budget for employee expenses increased by $3 million, despite the staff cuts. Following the passage of the criminal history legislation, the revenue from blue cards has been forecast to increase dramatically from $4.678 million to $7.78 million in 12 months. In February this year the government introduced the Criminal History Screening Legislation Amendment Bill, four months after the member for Hinchinbrook introduced the LNP’s Disability Services (Criminal History) Amendment Bill. The government’s bill was aimed at streamlining criminal history screening processes but increased the costs and failed to sufficiently cover particular sectors, such as carers for people with disabilities. The government’s haste to introduce the act left some areas unclear.

The following are the amendments made in relation to the Commission for Children and Young People and Child Guardian Act. A blue or yellow card-holding volunteer will have to pay a fee when they move from volunteering to paid employment. That is another reporting condition. An amendment will reinstate the screening powers to the CCYPCG to assess the suitability of people to be engaged at the commission itself. One would have thought that this would have been part of the risk management procedures already in place. Members should take into account that a number of commercial interests have never had to have blue cards in the past. When the Premier of the day was asked about this, he stated that the government would have its own risk procedures in place affecting workers at shopping centres, taxidrivers et cetera. However, the commission had not thought to have those people suitably screened. It beggars belief. An amendment will ensure that the commission provides updated advice to the Queensland College of Teachers when a blue card status changes, or police information in relation to people who had blue cards recognised in teacher registration processes.

In conclusion, I put on the record my sincere admiration and support for every child safety officer in Queensland who, every day, is expected to do more and more with little or no leadership from this government. This bill is more about protecting Labor’s shocking record on child safety than actually protecting children or helping families. At no time has this government shown any evidence based strategies to support this new initiative. This government has not set tasks or provided any person or organisation with an evaluation process to help create stability in the child care and child safety sectors. By not providing that process, we will return to the time when some great programs fell by the wayside because of this government’s lack of commitment and failure to properly identify the difference between on-ground legislative changes and bureaucratic legislation. The LNP has no faith in the government and no faith in this minister. We cannot support this government or any legislation produced by it regarding child protection, because it says one thing but we know all too well that, in practice, it does not deliver, even though children continue to suffer and the number of children taken from families and placed in dangerous and detrimental situations continues to grow.

Mrs STUCKEY (Currumbin--LNP) (7.44 pm): I rise to contribute to the debate on the Child Protection and Other Acts Amendment Bill, which was introduced to the House on 10 June by the Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport, the honourable member for Mansfield. This bill purports to enhance the administration of Queensland’s Child Protection Act 1999, in order to respond more effectively to the individual needs of children at risk and in care, and to supply the legislative foundation for the Helping Out Families initiative. The stated aim of this bill is to enhance the capacity of non-government services to intervene in early intervention strategies by making amendments to statutory services--child abuse investigation and response, and out-of-home care--and non-statutory secondary services--intervention with families with identified problems to prevent child abuse and neglect. Therefore, the amendments contained within this legislation will result in some changes to both statutory and non-statutory secondary services.

The bill also amends the Commission for Children and Young People and Child Guardian Act 2000 in relation to blue cards. The bill makes amendments to a number of other acts: the Disability Services Act 2006, the Family Services Act 1987, the Public Service Act 2008 and consequential amendments to the Juvenile Justice and Other Acts Amendment Act 2009. According to the explanatory notes, proposed changes to the Child Protection Act 1999 will implement the Helping Out Families initiative, improve the operation of court orders, provide a new temporary custody order, recognise the role of suitable person long-term guardians, and extend and clarify the definition of harm. As honourable members have heard from the shadow minister, the honourable member for Bundaberg, the LNP does not support this bill

The Minister for Child Safety has proclaimed that since 2004 his government has doubled the workforce and tripled the budget. He seems proud of the fact that his government, the Beattie government, neglected children under its care so disgracefully that it took a CMC inquiry to shame them into action. He wants a pat on the back for finally doing what governments are supposed to--that is, invest in child protection and support families. Despite three reviews of the Child Protection Act under three ministers in the six years since the 2004 CMC Butler inquiry, Protecting children: An inquiry into abuse of children in foster care , I am sorry to say this legislation is the first real attempt to make any significant changes to the act.

On 14 May 2008, the then minister, Margaret Keech, released a policy paper highlighting a series of proposed amendments to the Child Protection Act 1999. At that time she stated the amendments would ‘improve services, reduce red tape and boost protection for Queensland children’. Members should note the order of the above amendments: improving services and reducing red tape are ahead of boosting children’s protection. It seems that this is the approach adopted by the Labor government in its policy to address child protection. It puts the process first and the children and their families a poor second or third, as is the case here. As honourable members have heard from the shadow minister, in May PeakCare contributed to the 2008 policy paper, which was the same month that the minister launched it, and made this opening statement--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Overall, PeakCare contends that this policy paper intends to give more power to the Department of Child Safety without the benefit of any increased external scrutiny on its activities or services offered to children and their families in Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: PeakCare continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The paramount intention of this policy document appears to be an attempt to make life easier for departmental staff and subject their actions to even more restrictive scrutiny. This appears to be an abuse of power which has not been tolerated in other jurisdictions and should not be tolerated here.
XML.Hansard-Body: So be the comments from PeakCare, a very respected organisation. I note the phrase ‘best interest of the child’, which was described by some professionals as being used narrowly in a bureaucratic sense and used extensively to push the government’s One Chance at Childhood and adoption agendas. This has been replaced. This new legislation includes a ‘framework of principles to improve decision making to promote children’s safety, wellbeing and best interests’. All too frequently in recent years the phrase ‘best interest of the child’ was tossed about nonchalantly and activated by a bureaucratic decision made by well-intended but inexperienced departmental workers. I am not convinced, and neither are my LNP colleagues, that this latest change in language will in fact advance an at-risk child’s situation.

The minister says that this bill will enable the government’s tertiary child protection system to work hand in hand with the non-government sector in order to better support families before they require statutory intervention. This is another admission of this government’s failing, and not before time. There is much work to be done here as, for way too long, the NGOs and their calls for early intervention programs and support services have gone unanswered. The department of child safety was viewed by many as an investigative bureau, a conveyor belt that processed children suspected of being abused or neglected, ignoring the importance of involving their families wherever possible. Their highly researched recommendations were mostly disregarded and even howled down by members opposite in previous speeches.

In his second reading speech, the minister listed the key bodies that were consulted in the drafting of this bill. There were a number of these and they include PeakCare Queensland, Foster Care Queensland, CREATE Foundation, QCOSS and the Queensland Aboriginal and Islander Health Council. I wonder how many of the recommendations made by these key organisations were adopted by the government in these proposed amendments. Perhaps the minister would enlighten the House in his reply.
Again, in August 2008 PeakCare Queensland provided feedback on the discussion draft. They said--and I believe the shadow minister may have already quoted this--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It is not ‘in the best interests’ of children to enter the Child Protection system at all and note that the best interests of the child framework neglects to highlight the need for preventative services, diversionary services and family and community support services which ultimately do provide for the best interests of a child.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: They continue--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It is the view of our membership that whilst families may bear the primary responsibility for the upbringing, protection and development of their children, they cannot do so in isolation, without the support of the larger community.
XML.Hansard-Body: As honourable members have heard from the shadow minister, the honourable member for Bundaberg, it is way more likely that this legislation has been introduced by the government in an attempt to conceal its dismal failings in the area of child safety. Unsurprisingly, it falls short of expectations and does not wholly embrace the principles and philosophies recommended by experienced professionals in this specialised industry. The shadow minister has indicated that he will be moving several amendments that will provide a series of checks and balances to matters brought before the court regarding temporary custody orders and to ensure that transition from care plans are prepared for all children who are exiting care.

I would like to mention the Helping Out Families initiative enshrined within this legislation that is targeted primarily at the nought to four year age group. Whilst this is genuinely welcomed--and I repeat that for the minister: it is genuinely welcomed--as an early intervention protection strategy and one that the LNP has been pushing towards for a number of years, the model before us falls well short when one considers the scale of need in our communities. The overall amount of money being allocated to deliver this program is minuscule in comparison to the money spent on tertiary services. Child and family support services represent only about 10 per cent of the budget--$55 million has been allocated over four years to pilot this new early intervention and prevention initiative in Logan, on the Gold Coast and in Beenleigh-Eagleby.

Queensland is facing a record number of children in care, increasing from 4,950 in 2004 to 7,942 in 2010. Reducing the number of children in care through early intervention and education has been a key policy direction of the LNP and certainly was during my time as shadow minister. Undeniably there is more reporting of suspected and real child abuse, but it is this government’s failed policies and attitude that have stymied the reduction of child abuse in our society. The government’s mantra of ‘child safety is everyone’s business’, stated twice in the minister’s second reading speech, is somehow not cutting through. I do not doubt for a moment that every member in this House abhors child abuse and finds it repugnant in the extreme. I also concur that honourable members would agree that governments have an obligation to protect our most vulnerable--our young.

A study by the Australian Childhood Foundation published in April 2006 titled Out of sight--out of mind found that of the respondents to their survey a percentage viewed child abuse as less concerning than the cost of petrol and problems with public transport and roads. Alarmingly, 31 per cent said they would not believe children’s stories of being abused and 16 per cent did not know whether sex between a 14-year-old and an adult constituted sexual abuse. Attitudes like these must change if we are to make a long-lasting dent in these shocking figures of abuse.

Child abuse creates enormous personal and physical cost upon those affected, but it also places a huge financial cost on governments as they have to pay for the negative outcomes, as mentioned by the shadow minister, of mental illness, drug and alcohol abuse, depression, medical problems and in some cases criminality. The child protection partnership report confirms a strong link between youth offending and child abuse, with a startling 65 per cent of child offenders in the youth justice system known to Child Safety Services. What further proof do we need?

A 2009 report Mothers and the child protection system was conducted by H Douglas, T Walsh and K Blore and made possible by a grant from the University of Queensland. In their conclusion the authors stated the need for child safety workers to work collaboratively with parents and children, adding that there needs to be much more asking than telling. Amongst the 15 recommendations, which were focused on improving education and communication between immediate stakeholders, recommendation No. 9 was about defining the concept of ‘neglect’ more definitely in legislation and procedures. ‘Neglect’, the report said, should be clearly distinguished from situations where parents are struggling financially and/or are homeless but are otherwise able to care for the child.
The authors reported a disconnect between some services that support mothers and child protection workers. In their executive summary they say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Children should and must be protected. However it must be acknowledged that removals of children may no longer be perceived to be necessary if families are appropriately resourced and their issues properly understood. Child protection workers and parents’ advocates both have a crucial role in displacing the mistrust and uncertainty preventing more collaborative and open practices, otherwise it is the child’s interests that ultimately suffer.
XML.Hansard-Body: What has been so wrong about the Labor government’s method of achieving its goal of ‘child safety is everyone’s business’ was the omission of parents and families in the equation. Parts of this new legislation are a step in the right direction, such as the Helping Out Families initiative, but others are frightening to say the least. Correspondence I received from the Department of Communities in July stated the Helping Out Families initiative of $55 million spread over four years will provide support services to vulnerable families who have been referred to Child Safety Services but do not require ongoing tertiary intervention.

The key elements of the initiative are the South-East Regional Intake Service, which commenced on 2 August. It is expected to streamline and simplify the process of reporting concerns to the Department of Communities and to improve the consistency and quality of child protection intake making decisions. Trial sites are to be funded for three Family Support Alliance services. Services in the Beenleigh, Eagleby, Nerang and Logan areas start as of October this year and on the Gold Coast in early 2011. These will be networks of local services to support children, young people and their families. I note these sites are to be trialled. I would ask the minister to outline the criteria for these trials--for example, will services be continued for the four-year period?

Services to support at-risk families will supposedly include intensive family support, home visiting for new mothers, domestic and family violence, mental health, drug and alcohol, disability and homelessness services. An absence of detailed information leaves people wondering exactly how this will be achieved. It is such a critical part of the whole exercise in reducing the incidence of child abuse that the government must get it right. It cannot afford to fail.

The minister said in a media release on 2 July that this project would fund practical in-home support, such as assistance with parenting, home management, budgeting and meal preparation as well as visits from health workers. Mothers and their newborn babies will receive up to six visits from nurses from the centre. This all sounds very promising, but what framework is being set up to ensure maximum benefits reach the greatest number of families in need?

The Queensland Council of Social Service, QCOSS, has welcomed the expenditure but has criticised the government for falling well short of the funding and for the lack of detail included in the budget. QCOSS believes that a community based approach to early intervention and protection that involves consultation with non-government service providers is essential to best reach the people who need them. According to QCOSS, the government has failed to provide detail in the budget of if or when such consultation will occur. Again I ask: where is the detail? How many visits will be made to new mums and so on?

Amendments to the Commission for Children and Young People and Child Guardian Act 2000 relate to blue cards and yellow cards. What reasonable argument can this government offer as to why there is still no willingness to place a photo ID on these cards? A person cannot even hire a video without photo ID yet they can be entrusted to care for our precious children without it. We heard tonight from the shadow minister that revenue of some $6 million will be forthcoming from the blue card system.

The former police minister, who I note is in the House tonight, gave a very weak excuse that the cost to do this was prohibitive. Let us see exactly what it would cost. Technology today allows for the printing of student photo ID cards at a cost of well under a dollar. Is this too much to pay to increase kids’ protection? Are they not worth that much? Will the minister tell us just how much placing a photo on an ID card would cost?

This bill addresses the recognition of the importance of long-term guardians. The minister says that long-term guardians are often related family members, but in truth often they are not. Taking into account this government’s poor track record, I have grave concerns that children in foster care will be unfairly targeted for long-term guardianship and adoption when some could be reunited with family if there was more political will to do so through genuine attempts to support at-risk families.

I do recognise the importance of stability for children when it comes to arrangements. There is no question that this is critical, particularly in reducing the effects of cumulative harm. But most kids still average around four placements during an individual period of care. This legislation would see children in long-term care having their case plans reviewed at 12-month intervals instead of six. Is this because of staffing limitations or because it is best for the child? Or is there such a backlog that this is Labor’s way of reducing the waiting list? What specific steps are being taken to find out whether children are aware that these plans exist? Considering the rapid development needs of young children, 12 months is a very long period between opportunities to actively participate in decisions that affect their future and wellbeing.

The three business days temporary custody order exhibits a ‘remove child first, ask questions later’ policy which is very worrying. I recall a disturbing incident a couple of years ago where a child was flown to the other side of Australia with dad who had served time in prison for armed assault. Unbeknown to the Indigenous mother, the father was contacted by child safety staff, flew from Western Australia and collected the child without the consent of the mother. Is it acceptable to breach guidelines? Was this a really good outcome?

What effect has there been as a result of the Premier collapsing the department of child safety into one big portfolio of Communities? With the superdepartment, the Department of Communities, absorbing into one entity Child Safety, Housing, Women and, importantly, the Child Guardian, some NGOs have commented that we have lost the independent umpire. Has the Bligh government downgraded the importance of this entity?
