Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms van Litsenburg): Order! Would the member stay on the bill please.

Mr MESSENGER: Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker, and I refer to the Child Protection and Other Acts Amendment Bill. It does not matter how good the legislation that we see in this parliament today is, that is, the Child Protection and Other Acts Amendment Bill. On-the-ground, underqualified, overworked and in some cases dishonest child safety officers are a law unto themselves, causing more harm by their out of control, irresponsible and often illegal actions than the parents who are allegedly assaulting their children. It is my experience that this child safety department is in deep crisis and needs another royal commission to shake things up and kick-start some vital reform.

A number of child safety issues have been brought to my attention in the course of my duties as a member of parliament. Three stand out--nay, four stand out. I can talk about three of them as long as I do not identify the people or the children associated with those matters because they are not sub judice. The matter has just recently become sub judice only after the police indicated that they would charge a parent three hours after that person--

Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER
: Order! If it is sub judice, it should not be mentioned in the House.

Mr MESSENGER: Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. I have referred that matter on to the CMC and I believe that there is a strong possibility that the charging of that person has been politically motivated.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! You are contravening the sub judice rule. You will need to stop speaking on that issue altogether.

Mr MESSENGER: Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. I take your direction. I will speak generally about the provision of information that is generated by members of parliament in the normal course of their duty. That information, as we know, is privileged to this House. I would simply make the point that that information should not be used--
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: You are contravening the sub judice rule again.
Mr MESSENGER: I take your direction.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: If you do it again, you will be seated.

Mr MESSENGER: I have formed my opinions of the child safety department based on my conversations with my constituents, former staff and serving staff. While I applaud some individual child safety officers, the consistency in performance and bad decision making on behalf of some managers of Child Safety is breathtaking and sad. It is sad because the children and families are suffering because of, quite frankly, the behaviour of child safety officers who are completely out of their depth and out of control. The behaviour that I have witnessed and experienced disregards basic civil rights and disregards the natural justice of children and their parents.

I can give members a case that is not sub judice. I referred a matter in December two years ago through a question on notice. It was not to this minister; it was a different matter. The matter related to the circumstances of a five-year-old child and I discreetly brought that to the minister’s attention on a number of occasions during eight months. The child had been placed in the custody of her grandparents for three years after she was allegedly sexually assaulted as a two-year-old while in the care of her biological father who was allegedly under the influence of illicit drugs at the time of the assault. The minister, against the wishes of the grandparents--and the provision is in this legislation--ordered that the child be taken from a loving and safe Queensland home three days before Christmas and placed back in the care of her New South Wales based biological father who may or may not have been still using illicit drugs. I asked that the minister let the five-year-old child spend Christmas with her grandparents and review her department’s decision using information from the independent commission for young people, the teachers from the therapeutic preschool which specialised in caring for victims of assault, and the Queensland and New South Wales police force. The background was that the father had an alleged criminal history and a continuing use of illicit drugs. The child safety department failed to insist on independent and comprehensive drug testing.

There were recommendations from an independent body specialising in counselling for sexual assault that were ignored by the child safety department. The common theme throughout the history of my dealings with Child Safety in Bundaberg is this ignoring of and disregard for independent reports. The commission for young people recommendations and assessments were ignored and then it was noted that, by transferring this child from Queensland to New South Wales, we had no commission for young people or an independent community visitor in New South Wales. So the child was being taken back to a place where there was less care. Of course, the grandparents accepted the removal. That is one case where I considered that the judgement of the child safety department officers and managers was at fault and severely lacking.
I wrote to the former minister for child safety, who at the time was the Hon. Margaret Keech. I wrote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Dear minister,

Late yesterday I met with my constituent and her mother who raised serious concerns for the safety of her young children. It was explained to me that ... her former husband have shared a custody arrangement for three children through a Family Law Act agreement.

The son was also present at yesterday’s meeting and recounted the alleged abuse by his father and also the physical abuse of his younger brother and sister while in their father’s care... is now running away from his father and does not want to return to him because of the alleged violence.
XML.Hansard-Body: I wrote to the minister stating--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It concerns me greatly that nobody in authority is listening to their claims of abuse, including the Department of Child Safety, police and school teachers. I have recorded an interview with the boy where he outlined the alleged abuse at the hands of his father and also the physical abuse of his younger brother and sister.
XML.Hansard-Body: I enclosed the transcripts of that conversation and the original recordings of the investigation. In addition--

Mr O’BRIEN: I rise to a point of order. The standing orders deal very strictly with the tabling of documents under the Juvenile Justice Act and the Child Protection Act in terms of identifying the child. The standing order in particular is standing order 35. I would ask that all care is taken in the tabling of those documents to ensure that that child is not identified by the member.

Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms Farmer): Order! There is no point of order, because no person has been yet identified. I warn the member for Burnett that you will be contravening standing order 35 if you name any persons.

Mr MESSENGER: Madam Deputy Speaker, thank you for your direction. I am quite well aware of the provisions of standing order 35 and I note that I have no intention of identifying nor have I identified any member, any constituent or child during my speech.

In continuing with the letter that I wrote to the former child safety minister, I want to comment on the quality of the management at the particular time of the department of child safety. I informed the minister that I was visited by a child safety manager very quickly after that. This person seemed more concerned that I had actually gone to the minister rather than him. I was very concerned by his attitude and even more concerned by his appearance. I will describe his appearance.
Mr REEVES: I rise to a point of order. I ask you to look at the relevance of this in relation to the bill. I ask for guidance on that matter.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: There is no point of order.

Mr MESSENGER: I understand the nervousness that this government has over me speaking the truth here in the people’s place. These matters are often covered up. They are certainly not reported in the media. I will continue with my letter to the child safety minister--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: While finally I understand in a free liberal democratic society it is the right of anyone to dress or groom themselves in a manner that they see fit to express their personality and individuality, I am very concerned by the unusual grooming of your regional manager. Police, prison, ambulance officers and school teachers are just some public servants who are expected to maintain a professional appearance and I was wondering if your child safety officers were expected to uphold the same standards. The facial piercings, accompanying metal studs and corkscrew metal on both the left and right eyebrows--
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr O’BRIEN: I rise to a point of order. The standing orders are quite specific, particularly standing order 35, about the prevention of the identification of a child under a child safety order. The honourable member is providing a great deal of detail to this House so that it threatens that that child could be identified. In a small community like Bundaberg, the level of detail that the member is providing is sufficient so that the child that he is speaking about here tonight can be identified by that community. The member is contravening the standing order and endangering the safety of that child and he should be asked to sit down.
Mr MESSENGER: Can I respond to that criticism?
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! I am currently seeking advice. There is no point of order. The member for Burnett has the call.

Mr MESSENGER: I was not talking about a child in protection; I was talking about the manager of the child safety office in Bundaberg. If the member only cleaned out his ears he would hear that this is what the manager looked like. The manager had the corkscrews. The manager had the facial piercings. That was the whole point of my letter to the minister at the time. I said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The facial piercings, accompanying metal studs and corkscrew--
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr RYAN: I rise to a point of order. I rise on standing order 236, which relates to relevance. I ask for your ruling on whether or not the appearance of an employee of the department of child safety has any relevance at all to the bill before the House.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: There is no point of order.

Mr MESSENGER: I went on to make the point that I did not consider what I saw as professional attire and an appropriate form of presentation for a senior public servant in charge of an important regional government department, especially Child Safety. I wrote to the minister--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I am concerned that the manager’s chosen form of eccentric personal grooming and presentation may also be intimidating, frightening and even traumatic for the fragile and abused children he is meant to interview and protect as part of his normal work duties. I could understand his choice of appearance if you confirm for me that he was involved in a police undercover operation involving outlaw motorcycle gangs or he had part-time work as an entertainer at the circus, but given that 70 to 80 per cent of communication between adults and humans, and probably more in young people, is via the sense of sight I would respectfully ask that you insist that the same dress standards which apply to police, prison, ambulance officers and school teachers also apply to child safety officers.
XML.Hansard-Body: That obviously was not the case in Bundaberg. I can understand the shame of the people opposite who would not want me to talk about matters like that--that this government hires people with those sorts of attitudes and dress standards. The minister says in his second reading speech--
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! I ask the member for Burnett to refer me to the particular clause in the bill to which he is speaking.
Mr MESSENGER: Section 20, the officer’s obligation on taking a child into custody.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: Could you repeat that?
Mr MESSENGER: Replacement of section 20, ‘Officer’s obligation on taking child into custody’. I point out that my clock is ticking down.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: There is nothing in that clause that I think is relevant to what you are saying so please move on to your next point.
Mr MESSENGER: The child safety minister says in his second reading speech--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Child safety is everyone’s business and the Bligh government is committed to protecting Queensland’s most vulnerable children and young people. That is why since 2004 this government has doubled the workforce and tripled the Child Safety budget.
XML.Hansard-Body: There are a couple of issues that I would like to take up with the child safety minister. First of all, I agree wholeheartedly that child safety is everyone’s business, except that I do not believe the message has properly got out to his staff. In relation to the budget and staff, I have been told that the average job turnover for a child safety officer is seven months. I stand to be corrected. I invite the minister to provide the official figure. I can, however, say confidently that with the department of child safety there has been a casualisation of the workforce. Budget and staffing figures that I got from the library said that the total of full-time equivalent child safety officers in June 2005 was 1,936. Of that, approximately 1,200 were permanent, 668 were temporary and 61 were casual. The number of non-permanent staff was well over 700 officers. I think that is an unhealthy casualisation of a professional service. We need to have greater retention of personnel and look at a system that encourages more full-time employment.

I have spoken to a child safety solicitor and he has some advice for this chamber. He says that he is not the only practitioner who thinks it is a good idea and necessary to have a child protection act to protect children. He agrees that child safety officers are going beyond their powers, misusing their powers and acting outside the act. He says that a 22-year-old uni student or someone with a biblical studies degree from Oakland, California cannot possibly have the life experience necessary or any other adequate qualifications to determine what is a good or bad parent.

He says that Legal Aid does not adequately fund solicitors to respond to child protection matters and therefore, because no-one takes them to task, Child Safety is running wild and parents are being unfairly treated. Child Safety is creating a new stolen generation, he alleges. He says that if Child Safety was made liable for costs or actual consequences, the unwarranted and absurd cases would quickly disappear. He says that if they had qualified legal officers in Child Safety they would not run the absurd cases and that, because they do not have legal officers in Child Safety, they run the case until trial without referral to legal practitioners. He says that a few days before the trial they brief Crown Law who are not prepared or properly briefed to prosecute the cases, costing taxpayers thousands of dollars.

This solicitor also states that Child Safety bullies the parents. If they complain or criticise the department, the officers take it out on them by discontinuing contact or charging them with frivolous charges. They have to basically admit they are guilty before the officers will let them get their kids back. I believe that is a fact, that clinical assessments by supposedly independent parties are being passed back to Child Safety and they are using the information they get in those clinical assessments to label people as sex offenders. The solicitor went on to say that he could basically telephone Child Safety and advise them whatever he wanted about anyone he wanted and they would unleash a great and powerful act upon that person. The person would not have a great deal of hope of defending the matter without a very large and costly fight that virtually destroyed their family.

This legislation gives increased powers to child safety officers. The evidence before me and presented to me by legal professionals is that child safety officers are abusing their powers. Queensland parents and children are being harmed by the uncontrolled and irresponsible use of power. Until we have a proper independent investigation into the manner in which child safety officers are operating, I cannot in good conscience support this legislation. The existing act is okay. It will work fine if the government public servants follow the rules.

Mr O’BRIEN (Cook--ALP) (9.50 pm): One thing is for certain: the protection of children in this state will not be improved by the member for Burnett acting as judge and jury on such complicated and serious matters. For him to come in here and pretend to be judge and jury on what are complicated and serious matters--
Mr MESSENGER: I rise to a point of order. I find those comments offensive and I ask that they be withdrawn.

Mr O’BRIEN: I withdraw. Child safety is a difficult and complicated matter and it should be dealt with by people with serious and reasonable minds. Child protection is particularly difficult in my electorate of Cook and as such I take a keen and active interest in new policies and procedures that will impact on my constituents.

The changes to the Child Protection Act highlight the important role that Child Safety plays in our communities. I acknowledge the changes, particularly those that will improve service delivery to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I would firstly like to note the significant work occurring to reform Indigenous child protection in Queensland. The Department of Communities is currently introducing new reforms for at-risk Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children who come to the attention of the child protection system.

Early intervention and prevention is one of the key focuses of this government. An amount of $8.5 million has been allocated to establish family support service hubs located across the department’s seven regions. These new support services are targeted at Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander families who require extra support to keep their child safe. The family support service response will be coordinated early for vulnerable families to reduce risk factors that might lead to the child requiring statutory child protection intervention. An additional $8.5 million will continue to be provided for recognised entities’ statutory functions to ensure that they can continue to fulfil their role providing cultural advice when it is not safe for Indigenous children to stay at home.

These services are designed to actively participate in the decisions made by Child Safety regarding Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children and young people throughout each phase of the child protection system. This revised service delivery model will further address the delivery of culturally appropriate and representative child protection services for Queensland’s Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children and their families. The amendments to the Child Protection Act will enable greater partnership between government and non-government organisations to improve outcomes for Queensland’s children and young people.

The amendments also include greater provisions to work with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander mothers before their children are born. This bill includes an amendment to extend the obligation to consult with recognised entities to include decisions about unborn Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children. Consistent with the current provisions of the Child Protection Act regarding unborn children, such action can only occur with the pregnant woman’s consent.

The bill also includes an amendment to the definition of ‘relevant information’ for the purpose of information sharing. This amendment will enable government prescribed entities and service providers to share information about unborn children with each other. Currently, they can only share information with the department. The intent of the amendment is that broader information sharing may result in prescribed entities and service providers identifying that the department should be notified of the risk to an unborn child.

Keeping Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children safe and connected to their kin and culture is a priority for the Bligh government. The priorities articulated by the Indigenous Child Placement Principle detail the opportunities that should be provided for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children placed in out-of-home care in order that they are able to be raised by their own kin and within their own communities. It is a legislative responsibility for Child Safety workers in Queensland to follow this principle. Under the act, Child Safety workers must consider the hierarchy of possible placement options, involvement of recognised entities in the placement decision, retention of family and community relationships and the commitment of non-Indigenous carers. The hierarchy of possible placement requires a particular order of priority to be considered when placing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children. If it is safe, children should be able to remain within their families. The second preference is for placement within their communities. The third option is for placement with another Indigenous person compatible with the child’s community. The fourth option is placement with other Indigenous people and, finally, if none of the other options is possible, placement should be with a non-Indigenous carer committed to maintaining the child’s connection with his or her family, community and culture. In all cases, the child’s safety, welfare and best interests remain the No. 1 consideration.

A number of initiatives have been undertaken to implement the child placement principle and improve outcomes for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children. These include development of a draft state-wide policy for consultation with stakeholders which focuses on strengthening working relationships between local Indigenous services and Child Safety Services centres, cross-cultural training for Child Safety Services staff throughout the Foundation Studies in Culture--Indigenous Engagement, revisions to the Child Safety practice manual and data collection system to enable practitioners to record information necessary to evidence the implementation of the principle and development of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Child Placement Principle information sheet to inform staff of the principle and related processes. Furthermore, this government is investing more than $45 million over four years to establish safe house services in 11 remote Indigenous communities so that children remain connected with their communities.
Recently I was with the minister in Aurukun, Kowanyama and Pormpuraaw. Then the minister left me and went to Doomadgee and opened those child safety houses.
Mrs Kiernan: Hear, hear!

Mr O’BRIEN: The member for Mount Isa was on the trip as well when we opened those child safety houses in those communities. I know that funding has just been provided for the northern peninsula area child safety house to open. I was up there the other week and they were very excited about that announcement. They will deliver 66 extra placements for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children as well as vital family support services.

As I said, the department continues to take up the many challenges identified with implementing the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Child Placement Principle and is committed to ensuring Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children in out-of-home care remain connected to their families and communities. The Bligh government remains committed to ensuring better outcomes for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children and their families. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate, on motion of Ms Davis, adjourned.
Hon. PG REEVES (Mansfield--ALP) (Acting Leader of the House) (9.58 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the House do now adjourn.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr DICKSON (Buderim--LNP) (9.58 pm): I rise to speak on behalf of the poor ratepayers of Queensland. In 2007 this Labor government forced council amalgamations upon the ratepayers. At the time, Premier Peter Beattie also told this House--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: By March next year they will be part of the 72 new councils that will provide for our new system of local government--stronger local government--to deal with Queensland’s growth.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Where is the evidence to suggest the councils are now more financially viable and that they are getting stronger as a result of this amalgamation? A case in point is the Sunshine Coast Regional Council amalgamation. Noosa, Maroochy and Caloundra councils were forced to amalgamate.
XML.Hansard-Body: The current Bligh Labor government has reneged on its promise to meet all the costs of amalgamation; in this case, $13.9 million. Now the ratepayers are being belted with a raft of increased fees and charges, and an increase in their household rates, in order to make up for the Labor government shortfall. On 23 April, the media quoted Mayor Bob Abbot as saying ‘... the state government decision not to pay out the $13.9 million in amalgamation costs does not help the situation.’ Amalgamation was supposed to make local government more effective and sustainable. In June 2010, the Sunshine Coast Regional Council met and voted, although not unanimously, for the latest increase in household rates. It introduced a new levy, it reduced a discount, it increased other levies and, at the end of the day, it claimed it had kept the rates increase to 4.8 per cent. While that might be true of the general rate component of the rates notice, it is a play on words and absolute smoke and mirrors from the Sunshine Coast Regional Council. When people get their bill, what do they do? They look at the bottom line. I can tell the House that on the Sunshine Coast I personally know of bottom-line rates increases of 27 per cent.

We are also seeing the engineered debacle of the council and its offspring, Unitywater. The council does not know if it is Unitywater’s parent, guardian, uncle, aunt or distant cousin twice removed. Ratepayers are being ripped off because amalgamations have failed to give them better value from their councils. We also need to take into account increases in the price of power, rego and licence fees. Then we get down to the sale of assets, which is what has really hurt the people of Queensland and is about to come home to roost at the next rate rise in June next year. That is when ratepayers will really get stitched up, because water will go up by another 25 per cent and we can pick a number as to how much power will go up by. Can members guess who gets all of the credit for this? It is Labor. Labor keeps giving the people of Queensland rate increases and power price increases, and then it sells them out just to finish the job off. There will be nothing left. However, one thing I can guarantee is that our state election will have the same outcome as the federal election.

Ms CROFT (Broadwater--ALP) (10.01 pm): Last week I had the opportunity to visit Coombabah State School for its annual junior sports day, which I thoroughly enjoyed. It was a day of great colour with students proudly wearing their new house coloured T-shirts, a day of great support with a great turnout of parents, grandparents and carers, and a day of fun. Each time I visit Coombabah State School I am inspired by the great work of our teachers, teacher aides, school administration staff, cleaners, groundsmen and volunteers who all work so hard to ensure Coombabah primary is a great state school that achieves great results.

Tonight I would like to share with the House some of Coombabah State School’s recent achievements. At the Gold Coast Special Eisteddfod, 15 students came third in the group dance and 17 students came second in the group song. At the Gold Coast Eisteddfod, the junior choir took out third place and the senior orchestra, competing for the first time in three years, was awarded honours. The string quartet was comprised of four year 6 and 7 students who played together for the first time and received honours. The junior band, which has played together for only six months, received a highly commended award. The recorder band received a highly commended for the third year in a row. The senior band, made up of 16 students, performed an ensemble and played well for a primary school band.

Congratulations go to the following students and teams selected to compete at the forthcoming regional athletics championships: Danielle Maxwell in shot-put, Ezra Tuitapa-Isacc for shot-put, Olivia Hadley for high jump, the 10 and 11 years boys relay team and the 10 and 11 years girls relay team.

A dedicated and committed teaching staff is, indeed, one of the important elements to creating the great learning environment that is so evident at Coombabah State School. I congratulate teachers Sunilla Naidoo and Sally Bourke on their nominations for this year’s National Excellence in Teaching Awards.

The dynamic and proactive Coombabah State School P&C continues to fully support the teaching and learning of all students under the guidance of its president, Pania Crawford, and her excellent volunteers. I am advised that the P&C has recently supported some students who gained regional representation: in Australian Rules, Dane Watmuff; girls soccer, Tyla Phillips; netball, Olivia Hadley; and boys touch football, Darnell Tawhi-Amopiu.

Recently the P&C was successful in obtaining a Gambling Community Benefit Fund grant of $25,000 for a sustainable urban living project based on the principles of aquaponics. The sustainable urban living project will be managed by students in the special education program and will become an integral part of the school’s science program. This project, undertaken by the P&C and the school, supports this year’s Year of Environmental Sustainability declaration by Education Queensland and teaches students to care for the environment, science and creating sustainable living.

This has been another great year for Coombabah State School. I commend Principal Mr John Hockings and all of the school staff and wonderful volunteers for their continued efforts. I congratulate the students on being such polite and engaging students--

Dr ROBINSON (Cleveland--LNP) (10.04 pm): Thornlands State School on South Street, Thornlands, is a thriving school with approximately 600 students in the primary school and 100 students in the full-day preschool. The school is proud of its long tradition in servicing the educational needs of the district and encourages students to take a keen interest in sport, the environment and cultural activities.

Thornlands State School was officially opened on 15 October 1910. The first teacher, Miss M Fielding, was appointed on 24 October. On 1 November the first student was enrolled. By the end of that week, a total of 14 children had been enrolled and 100 years of state government education in Thornlands had begun.

On 16 and 17 October 2010, a weekend of celebrations will take place at Thornlands State School to commemorate the official opening of the school in 1910 and to showcase 100 years of education at Thornlands. In that time, the school has been well served by various principals, teachers, staff and P&Cs. Many thousands of students have been successfully educated at the school.

Mr Bradley French is the acting principal and Jan Burton and Jane Barnett are the deputy principals. P&C president, Mark Spreadborough, and the P&C Association Centenary Committee have invited all past and present students, parents, staff and members of the community to participate in the celebrations.

The school is situated in a pleasant natural environment and children are encouraged to care for the native plants and animals. The school considers itself fortunate to be in a koala zone and regularly has visits from koalas, as well as other wildlife. The abundance of native trees and shrubs ensures that the school is also home to a wide range of native birds, including lorikeets and parrots.

The school’s facilities and amenities have been expanded over the century. The school’s oval provides facilities for many healthy activities such as football, cricket, tennis and swimming, to name a few. Situated near the oval is a versatile multipurpose hall that readily accommodates all students. During lunchtimes, students are able to use the hall for various teacher-led activities, including games, discos and the famous Thornlands Idol. I have had the good luck of being able to participate in the more recent practice of Thornlands Idol. Young dancing and singing talent are displayed, with judges looking for the X factor. After-hours, the hall is utilised by various sporting and community groups. The library is open daily to all students and children are encouraged to borrow from the stock held.

I look forward to the celebrations that start earlier than the big weekend. The program starts with a launch, ‘Back to Thornlands’, then a centenary concert, open day and the finale weekend of the school reunion and showcase, gala dinner/dance and family picnic day to cap things off. My congratulations to the Thornlands State School community. May your next 100 years be even more prosperous and significant.

Mrs SMITH (Burleigh--ALP) (10.07 pm): Recently I attended a Princess Party and, by the end of the night, even I felt like a princess. The Lifehouse Project is a community project that was incorporated to assist young people at risk and the Princess Party is an event to encourage potentially at-risk young women, aged 14-18 years, to value and respect themselves, have confidence and reach their dreams. The girls at the Princess Party were from a variety of backgrounds, but had been nominated by their schools, school based youth health nurses, counsellors, family members and even self-referral. The day was an opportunity for them to be inspired by others, to help build their self-esteem and be assured that they were loved and respected.

Last week members may have seen a TV program called The Secret Millionaire. Carly Crutchfield appeared on the show. Carly was a motivational speaker for the Princess Party and she spoke with the girls from the heart. As I looked around the room I saw that they could relate to her. She may now be a millionaire, but they could see that her early teen years were not unlike their own.

Five hundred under-age girls at a function at Jupiters Hotel on the Gold Coast sounds like a recipe for disaster, but it was just the opposite. I congratulate Mr Stuart Wing, the CEO of Jupiters Hotel and Casino, for taking a leap of faith and sanctioning the Princess Party at his hotel. I think even his staff thought he had rocks in his head, but his faith in the girls and the organisers was justified. While security staff were strategically placed, they were highly visible and the safety of the girls was paramount. No-one got in without a pass and no-one got out without a parent or carer.

I acknowledge the enormous contribution of Ruth Knight to this event. Ruth has faced her own challenges but now puts all her energy into instilling in young women their self-worth. There are so many people involved in this event it is impossible to mention them all. However, I would like to acknowledge a number of those people who made the whole event possible.

Evolve Make-Up, a Gold Coast based company, provided 75 hairdressers and make-up artists during the afternoon to help girls with their hair and make-up in preparation for the formal dinner in the evening. There was a donation of 500 individually wrapped flowers--one for each girl as she entered the dining room--and a number of young men were on hand to escort each girl to her table. A beautiful two-course dinner and entertainment was provided that included a former member of the Ten Tenors, Scott Fields. Scott brought a tear to the eye of those present when he singled out a young woman with cerebral palsy and sang to her. She was delighted!

No-one knows what the future holds for these young women. But, with the support of so many mentors and sponsors, I hope they can be inspired and see that there are many people in the community who care about them. I particularly like the following verse from the book of Proverbs, ‘She is clothed with strength and dignity, and she laughs without fear of the future.’ What more could we want for our young women of the future?

Mr CRANDON (Coomera--LNP) (10.10 pm): The Gold Coast rail line is a favourite topic of mine because of the issues that we have with it. I talked about it during the last sitting week in this House. I was trying to bring a human touch to the debate and talked about a particular individual in my electorate. I gave all of the information. In the sneaky way that so often happens on the other side of the House, as I completed my three minutes the member for Keppel suggested that I had in fact written a letter on behalf of a supposed constituent. That was far from the truth. In fact, I am very happy to table the letter to me, the letter to the minister, the letter from the minister and then the letter back from the constituent today, just to put paid to that argument.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: A bundle of correspondence regarding the Gold Coast rail line [ 2857 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: It was interesting that the member for Keppel, when challenged, was not able to bring himself to turn around to look me in the eye to see whether or not that was indeed the case. Anyway, that is the sort of thing we can expect on that side of the House.

We heard today a wonderful announcement: 20 years down the track, we are going to have trains doing 320 kilometres an hour et cetera and we are going to be buying trains with toilets on them! I ask the Premier to speak to her minister to get the facts. We already have trains with toilets on them. They are already in service on the Gold Coast, and thank goodness for that because quite often when people hop on the trains and head to the Gold Coast what do they find when they get to the stations on the Gold Coast? The train station is closed and there are no toilet facilities available to them.

So we have an issue with the Gold Coast trains. The minister says to my constituent, ‘Yes, indeed, we are trying to fix the problem on the Gold Coast.’ But we all know that, no, they are not trying to fix the problem on the Gold Coast. The minister says, ‘There is no room to put any more trains on the Gold Coast line.’ We now know that that is not the case. We now know that, as we speak, it is possible to put additional trains on the Gold Coast line in peak hour. Currently in peak hour we have 19 trains on the Gold Coast line heading into Brisbane. We now know that it is possible to get up to 23 trains on the Gold Coast line per hour over the peak period. That is four additional trains in the peak period. We have been told a mistruth in this House to say that it is not possible. We now know that it is possible.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Redcliffe Electorate, Bowls Day for Cancer
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms van LITSENBURG (Redcliffe--ALP) (10.13 pm): In conjunction with Daffodil Day, the Redcliffe RSL women’s bowls club held their ‘Bowls day for cancer’ to raise money for the Redcliffe Hospital Foundation’s cancer research program. The Redcliffe Hospital Foundation is developing an education and research facility in conjunction with the GP superclinic and the University of Queensland, which is collaborating to have trainee doctors, nurses and allied health professionals trained at the Redcliffe Hospital. Around 12 teams competed in the challenge, which was followed by a lunch. They raised $1,100 for cancer research which the RSL traditionally matches, so they will be able to donate $2,200.

Boris Chern, the head of oncology services at Redcliffe Hospital, has instigated some research but is keen to expand it to improve outcomes for all cancer sufferers. The statistics are frightening. Currently one in two people, female or male, will contract cancer at some time in their life. Recent research has made important gains and, because of this, the five-year survival rate for invasive cancer is 70 per cent for women and 65 per cent for men. This has improved about 15 per cent since the 1980s.

Recent breakthroughs have delivered outcomes such as a vaccine for cervical cancer and drug combinations that have improved people’s survival rates and lessened the side effects of chemotherapy. Continued targeted research can produce incremental improvements in these results. Daffodil Day and local fundraisers such as the RSL women’s bowls day are a vital link in that chain. Without support from these areas, the Cancer Council would have great difficulty in funding research programs. Because of each community’s generosity in donating to support research, cumulative improvements in the survival rate for invasive cancer and fewer side effects from drugs are continuing around the state, the country and the world.

The Bligh government has consistently increased funding for health because we understand the importance in the community of good health care and health outcomes, especially with cancer, which devastates not only the lives of sufferers but also their whole families. Our support for cancer research is in line with the Bligh government’s Toward Q2 initiatives to have a healthier community. Healthy communities are strong communities, and healthy and strong communities are those that support each other during times of difficulty. Only the Bligh Labor government is continually pushing the boundaries to ensure that Queenslanders not only are amongst the longest living people in the world but also are the healthiest and that they have cutting-edge cancer services and other medical services.

Mr BLEIJIE (Kawana--LNP) (10.16 pm): I rise this evening to address the issue of the recent minimum waste collection charge increases that have been passed on to ratepayers in my electorate in the recent rate notifications by the Sunshine Coast Regional Council. The charge relates to those residents, many of them senior, who reside in community title schemes in the former Caloundra city council area. These residents have banded together to fight the charge because they have had enough of governments of all levels attacking their standard or living. The recent history of this charge can only be described as tumultuous at best.

For the financial year 2008-09, there was a modest levy of $25 charged to each ratepayer in the complex. There was no charge in 2009-10 and now for this financial year the charge has been increased to $151.30 per resident--an increase of some 600 per cent in just two years. Most astonishingly, that is more than the Labor state government’s charges.

Currently many unit complexes have a shared bin system, whereby council is only required to collect on average 10 bins put out from a potential 40 bins per complex, saving the council valuable time and money. I have written to council, a copy of which letter I table, to highlight the inequity in this system which charges each resident for an individual service that they actually do not receive.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Letter, dated 15 July 2010, from the member for Kawana to the CEO, Sunshine Coast Regional Council regarding minimum waste collection charges [ 2858 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: The response that I have received, which I also table, suggested that the council wanted to initiate a user-pays philosophy.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Response, dated 29 July 2010, from the Manager Waste and Resources Management to the member for Kawana regarding minimum waste collection charges [ 2859 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: It also suggested that, because no charge was imposed on ratepayers in 2009-10 in southern premises, council was out of pocket $1.2 million and that the $151.30 imposed on southern residents this year would still leave council out of pocket. Council’s blunder and budget black hole imposition will be subsidised by the ratepayer.

People are already under an enormous strain from cost-of-living expenses. Under the mismanagement of this incompetent Labor state government we have seen electricity prices spiral out of control, registration go up, fuel prices go up and now water prices go up--just to name a few. Now rates and levies and charges are just another form of tax on residents who are struggling to make ends meet, and the people who are hardest hit are those on fixed incomes such as pensioners.

The Premier once said that council amalgamation was supposed to save ratepayers money. On 10 March the Courier-Mail reported in an article entitled ‘Councils wallow in debt as forced amalgamations force rates hikes’--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Rates are soaring as Queensland councils struggle with rising debts two years after controversial amalgamations were pushed through by the State Government.
XML.Hansard-Body: In the same article the Sunshine Coast Regional Council deputy mayor said that the advantages are not apparent at this point in time. He said that an additional $14 million a year had to be found over the next few years to fix the council’s financial woes.

We heard today the Premier of Queensland stand in this place and finally admit that the state Labor government has not been listening to Queenslanders for the past 12 years. But now it is sending all its Labor state members out to listen to people. The LNP has been listening to the people of Queensland. We will help reduce the cost burden that each and every Queenslander has due to a state Labor government.

Mr WETTENHALL (Barron River--ALP) (10.19 pm): One of the fastest growing areas in the Barron River electorate is in the Freshwater Valley, including the suburb of Redlynch and a number of major new residential estates in the area. In fact, the population has grown from 1,164 in 2001 to 2,520 in 2008, at an average annual rate of just under 12 per cent compared with an annual average growth rate of just under four per cent for the electorate as a whole.

Typically, residents of the valley are working families with school-age children or younger children who will benefit from early childhood and kindergarten services. The demand for new services and infrastructure generated by population growth is the central challenge for our government. I am pleased to say that we are meeting that challenge in Redlynch.

Nowhere is the foresight and good planning more evident than in new education facilities in the valley. This is true in both the government and Catholic education sector. In addition to creating a new multimillion dollar state P-12 college at Redlynch, our government has also invested heavily in the development of St Andrew’s Catholic College, located just a short distance away.

Recently, I had the pleasure of officially opening stage 9 at St Andrew’s comprising 13 new general learning areas, modifications to the middle and senior libraries and various other extensions enabled by a $4.5 million contribution by the state government. In July 2008 I opened stages 7 and 8, which received more than $6.4 million from the state government.

Our investment is not limited to expanding schools. Last year, I also took part in the official opening of a new $1.8 million multipurpose sporting field and courts on land owned by St Andrew’s. In partnership with the Cairns Regional Council and the school, the state government pioneered a new approach to developing sporting facilities that benefits students but means they are available for community use as well. This model is now embedded in the new sport and recreation infrastructure program. This year, our government will boost participation levels in sport with a further $175,000 grant for the installation of lighting at these first-class sporting facilities.

Complementing these developments, St Andrew’s has been chosen as the location for a new federally funded 75-place long-day-care centre. Meeting a 2009 election commitment, our government will contribute $450,000 towards the construction of the centre to include a dedicated kindergarten room from which a sessional kindergarten program will be delivered by a qualified teacher for up to 48 children. I congratulate foundation principal, Laurette Graham, and everyone else who has supported the development of St Andrew’s Catholic College and whose faith, energy and vision have helped create a wonderful community asset.

Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind) (10.21 pm): Today I have been provided with information from a medical professional that an outbreak of an antibiotic resistant bug has occurred at the Bundaberg Base Hospital’s medical ward. Half that ward has been isolated. There is a clean-up process in place. The antibiotic resistant bug is called vancomycin resistant entrococci or VRE. A medical website which was supplied to me by the Parliamentary Library states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In 1986, the first VRE strains appeared in Europe and, in 1989, the first case of VRE was reported in the United States. Between 1989 and 1993, the percentage of enterococcal tests that were positive for VRE in the United States rose from 0.3 percent to 7.9 percent.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The website also states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Enterococcal infections that result in human disease can be fatal, particularly those caused by strains of vancomycin resistant enterococci (VRE). During 2004, VRE caused about one of every three infections in hospital intensive-care units, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).
XML.Hansard-Body: This medical professional is concerned for patient safety and staff wellbeing. That is why they have asked that I raise this issue in this place. Unfortunately, this government has a long history of cover-ups and has been more concerned with adverse media headlines rather than adverse patient and staff wellbeing. I call on the health minister to explain what he is doing to help solve this problem which has been caused by a number of pre-existing conditions.

The hospital budget is in crisis. There is not enough money to even meet normal running costs. That was confirmed last week on ABC Radio by a senior VMO. Health managers Beth Norton and Kevin Hegerty have called extraordinary meetings with senior medical staff and managers from Bundaberg in Hervey Bay and laid down the law that budgets must be cut back.

The new department of emergency medicine that the health minister bragged about this morning will not come with extra fully funded nursing positions. The medical managers are being told they will have to staff the new department of emergency medicine from the existing nursing pool. There will be no increase in job numbers. They will be robbing Peter to pay Paul.

I am told that over the years there has been a cutback in the number of cleaners at the Bundaberg Base Hospital and that the cleaners who are employed are run off their feet. The extraordinary workload on nurses and doctors increases the possibility of cross infection with patients and the existence of VRE. This all led to a situation where it is understandable that the Bundaberg Base Hospital has an outbreak of VRE--a bug which is normally found in much bigger capital city hospitals. This is also another reason why Bundaberg’s old hospital must be replaced with a new hospital in a new location with double the budget, double the doctors, double the nurses and double the beds.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Carina Leagues Club, Outstanding Junior Player Grants Awards; James, Mr M
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr KILBURN (Chatsworth--ALP) (10.24 pm): I recently attended the Carina Leagues Club outstanding junior player grants awards. The Carina Leagues Club gave out money to four outstanding young Queenslanders who live in the Chatsworth electorate. They were Daniel Butcher, Tianna Mangakahia, Daniel Rolley and Max Goode.

Daniel Butcher who plays for the Carina Leagues Redsox Baseball Club has represented Queensland in 2009 at the Little League China Tour as well as the national youth championships in January this year. He has also been selected for representative duties over the past few years and is well respected in the youth baseball fraternity for his ability and easygoing nature. He was recognised by Baseball Queensland recently when he was offered only one of four under 14 age group places in the Queensland baseball academy’s elite athletes program.

Max Goode is 17 years old and plays for the Carina Leagues Warriors Water Polo Club. He has recently competed in the Queensland schoolboy championships in Brisbane and was selected in the Queensland schoolboy team which competed in the Australian schoolboy championships in New South Wales. Queensland played for the bronze medal, defeating Western Australia 22 to six with Max scoring eight goals on his own. Max was then selected in 2010 Australian Schoolboys Water Polo Team which will tour the United Kingdom, the United States of America and New Zealand in December this year.

Tianna aged 15 years plays for the Southern Districts Basketball Association. She has captained the Queensland under 16 girls second national championship team. She captained the under 16 Spartans who were the state champions. She has played every age group at a representative level. She has also been selected to play the under 17 Pacific Coast Slam in 2011 and has been selected in the Australian under 17 women’s squad.

Last but not least is Daniel Rolley. At the grand age of 10, Daniel participates in the Balmoral Little Athletics Club and has been doing so for five years. He is the club age champion, junior track champion in the under 6s, under 7s, under 8s, under 9s and under 10s. He is the Queensland record holder for the 400 metres and 800 metres in the under 10 boys age group. He has set Queensland’s best time in the 400 metres of 1.03 minutes and in the 800 metres of 2.23 minutes. This year he won the Gold Coast marathon for the juniors. He ran a full marathon at the grand age of 10. What a future.
These young Queenslanders are given grants by the Carina Leagues Club. It is a fantastic club in my electorate that supports youth and provides a lot of help to young people in the electorate.

I would also like to congratulate Michael James and his staff at Carina North Quality Meats who recently won a Queensland business award at the South-East Queensland business awards. He is a great champion in the community and provides a lot of donations to local communities. I congratulate Michael and his team.
The House adjourned at 10.28 pm.
